content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												When I first played this game, I underestimated on how addictive Far Cry 2 can be. I just cannot stop playing it and kept going on for hours.What the game did right: This game is similar to its predecessor but expands the limited open world that the first Far Cry game was trying to construct on.  The environment is now far more diverse, ranging from dry savannahs to humid jungles with thick vegetation.  There is also a dynamic weather system in which fog can overtake the land or a rainstorm can appear and change the way you play.Adding to its wide ranges of landscapes, I can argue one of the more "tactical benefits" this game boasts is its fire.  A lot of games have a blaze kept at a constant size but FC 2 offers greater realism in that part. Throw a Molotov Cocktail at a dry patch of grass and see the fire consume the grass with its voracious appetite but in a humid climate, it will inflict little damage.  The A.I. of your enemies are no longer the same "dimwits" that got slaughtered in FC 1. If you're spotted out in the open or make too much noise near guard posts, they will come for you. They also converse with each other and try to protect themselves from the player which reflects real life. In one instance, a downed mercenary will be helped by another merc. Stealth has been improved. If you're careful enough, your reward is being able to silently take down one enemy after another. For the most part, their awareness is fairly balanced, unlike FC 1 in which the mercs couldn't tell if someone else was firing a loud weapon but still could see the player behind tents and bushes. Also, your choices on when to use stealth makes a big difference. For example, you can go at night where potential assailants cannot easily see you but are alert. A unique feature that FC 2 has is its buddies. They are in the game to help you with missions, increase your reputation by providing optional quests, or save you if your well-being has been thrashed to zero. I do enjoy interacting with them upon taking missions. When combining the aforementioned aspects, you can do missions with almost any mentod you want.  You can either quitely sneak past foes or go in guns blazing. It's all up to you. Exploring doesn't easily get dull and the replay value is high.While I do favor this game, some problems are existant. What the game should have avoided doing wrong:The voice acting for most of the characters is inauspicious. Most of the characters speak too fast and have a flat tone. One of your buddies' dialogue sounds like it was taken from Google translate and that makes it inauthentic. Over time, the side missions get repetitive. The "convoy missions" are the most subjected to this.  It gets quickly mundane to find circling rival arms vendors and blow up their trucks. The worst part is if you want to have better weapons sooner, there's no other way around this other than to proceed through the main objectives most of the time. The "weapon degradation system" is one that I have debated in choosing if it's interesting to keep in a game or conclude it's mostly annoying to have in a firefight. As of now, I have decided that it's a nuisance as some weapons degrade too quickly and jam at the worst times. Also, close to the end of the game, even with reliability upgrades, the game will punish you if your shots miss too much and you cannot obtain new weapons (unless you stored them).Also, the malaria mechanism is very annoying, with no way to ever stop it, only delay it. When you're under attack by that damn disease, you can barely see well and cannot sprint away from danger. Although it doesn't last that long, it may cost some precious seconds for you to flee. The diamond cases in this game may somewhat excite newcomers for a while but it's painful to endure when trying to reach for some diamonds on a cliff. Although not necessary to find, it's just a distraction from what the game can truly offer. I did mention you can interact with your buddies, but that's very limited.  All you can do is accept 2 of their quests and after that, they will just say "hi" if you meet them regularly. The (re)spawning of enemy mercenaries in certain locations is downright stupid. In one case, you can take down all enemies in a base but when you leave for a certain distance and look back with a scope, the place is then refilled with enemies as if nothing has happened. The developers should have put a time limit in how fast enemies can respawn when you're sufficiently far away. The A.I. is good when confronting them but when they drive, it's a mess. The drivers tend to have problems in making a  U-turn and are horrible in judgement. One time, a patrol car tried to run me over but it missed and plunged into the water.Finally, the storyline is woefully linear. Though understandable, your choices are very narrow and don't have much impact on the game. Trying to avoid providing spoilers, it's the same "bad" ending, if you decide to detonate some explosives or bribe some border guards to help out a fleeing country in need. Other: I haven't tried out multiplayer yet but I have heard that it's dead, which is sad. However, if you feel like allowing your imagination demanding to make a map with the African landscape, there is a map editor that is easy to use. Shamefully, it's quite limited and it's meant for multiplayer. Customizing this game is almost impossible to do, unlike most games. For those who wish to mod, they will be sadden that this is almost unachievable. Still, there are a few mods that can enhance the game (and perhaps tweak balance), like Dylan's Realism Mod. Conclusion:This game is definitely worth a purchase. While it may have cons, the pros in this game will entertain you and not disappoint you for at least one playthrough. If you're bored of playing games that trap you in confined spaces, get this game and feel how open it is.

Posted: November 29, 2016
												Out of all the Far Cry games, this one is the most difficult and I love it. Let me tell you why.All the good stuff in game down below.● The AI might seem simplistic at first, but they are sharp as knife. They hear you whenever you stealth kill a guard, pull out a weapon, move in bushes. Every move you make, they can hear out and instantly know where you are. For some, this might be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but for others, a pleasant thing. This makes you get creative about destroying outposts etc..● Bunch of weapons to choose from, from flare guns to IED's. Variety of ways destroying convoys, assasinations etc...● The setting itself, it looks just as Central-Africa, large deserts, jungles, savannas and  animals moving around. There is just something about that orange look I love.● Fun and appropriate side missions, enjoyable assasinations, blowing up weapon convoys, same goes for buddy missions● At some point story becomes cool, intense as♥♥♥♥♥♥● Golden AK's, nuff said.● Exploring with Glider is the most enjoyable thing ever until you get one shotted midair by a guard with a fricking pistol miles away.● Weapon jam, suck it FC3 and FC4● Malaria to remember you that approximately 30-40 mins in real life have passed by.● Instantly respawning guards at guard posts to make you mad and waste your ammo and health kits. Hell I love this, wish FC3&4 had it.A few negative things also though- Basicly every mission requires you to drive someplace far asf and the instant spawning guardposts might trigger some players.- Glitches here and there.- Cars doesn't feel like cars, they get stuck everywhere, always the same speed, sound...Definitely a great game, 100% recommend!

Posted: October 19, 2014
												Heard a lot of negative press about this game, and while some of it was certainly true, the flaws were far from bad enough to ruin the game.I really enjoyed this, I can't really put my finger on why though. The wide open spaces were enjoyeble to wander through, and though there was no variety in enemy you could create your own variety in the tactics you used to deal with them. Weapon choice seemed to have a big impact on combat, you could try and pick them off from afar with long range weapons or maybe run and gun with a shotgun and some grenades. How about starting a fire and using the resulting confusion to take advantage of the situation? Maybe just take a different route and avoid combat all together. The environments were much better looking and more varied than I expected and although there could have been more variety in the missions, I never found them to be a drag as they usually made you explore new parts of the map.

												Beautiful but empty world.The guns are a blast to use but the knife is horrible. You can't stealth with a knife??Driving is fun but not after hours and hours and hours of it. WAY too much back-tracking. The few fast travel spots are always out of the way and you're better off driving/running/boating which eventually makes travel an extreme burden.Practically all the missions are fetch quests. Get mission, go out, do X, come back, repeat. I wouldn't mind this but the fact that you can't have multiple missions makes me want to cry because the game forces you to do them one by one.Story is extremely bleh.Enemy respawns becomes a pain. Enroute to location A, I clear out enemy post B, to make it to location C. On the way back (because the fast travel locations are rarely useful), enemy post B is full of enemies again even though I was just there 5 minutes ago. This is how a game tells you that your actions do not matter and have no effect on the world.FC2 had potential and it's exhibited FC3 as they fixed most of the problems. If you have played FC3 prior to FC2, DO NOT PLAY. You have been spoiled with all the fixed mechanics. I certainly was.

												This is a game you either really love or really hate. Everything in the entire game is there for 1 reason only: to kill the player. Ranging from infinite respawning guard posts to jamming weapons and malaria (oh that malaria...), every freaking thing is hell-bent on killing you every step you take.Should you buy this game, I have two recommendations: Install a realism mod and up the difficulty a bit to at least hardened. Both this mod and this one are really good. Recently a new supermod in the form of this one was released. Take the game at a slow pace. The faster you want to finish missions, the game, your enemies, or anything for that matter, the faster the game throws everything it has at you. And don't be mistaken, you will die. Take it slow, plan your attack a bit. 99/100 times your plan goes awfully wrong, so all that you're left with is complete and utter chaos anyway.Do yourself a favor and buy this game. Nevermind how much is wrong or broken, it's an experience you will never ever forget. (I've played through it 3x on my Xbox and 1st time on my PC now, I still enjoy it!)

content:
Posted: March 5
												Not much of a review guy, so this will probably be the only game i'll ever review on steam. This is also going to be a little biased and you'll see why in a second.Okay first off, the world itself is amazing. For a game made in 2008, the level of detail in the world and atmosphere is phenomonal. The music that comes along with it is great, changing whether or not the game detects you being in a fire fight or not. The character models are also good, no two seem to look the same although they do have similarities. Only gripe would be the voice acting; characters mouths dont always seem to move in sync with the dialogue. The map is massive, and you'll spend a good amount of time driving to locations or maybe just walking like I usually do. If you're not a patient person, and need to have some kind of action 24/7, this won't be for you. The action is there, and explosions and gun fights happen frequently, but if you're expecting the rushed delivery from something like CoD or Battlefield, stray away. Theres a good selection of weapons to choose from once you've done a bunch of the convoy missions. Some include different snipers (Dragunov, AS50), submachine guns (MAC-10, UZI), Assault Rifles (AK, AR-15) and theres rocket launchers, a dart rifle to sneak around with, a mortar and a 6 round grenade launcher. Theres more aswell I just dont remember everything. All will deteriorate and jam once used too much, so you've got to keep an eye on your loadout or you'll run into an outpost empty handed and get slaughtered. You can only carry 4 weapons at a time, and choose wisely or you'll be stuck in long range engagement with a shotgun, pistol and a flamethrower. You can choose how aggressive or passive you want to play depending on your loadout which gives the game some replay value if you went through the campaign once and only played a certain way. The game is a ton of fun once you get past the tutorial (which only lasts about 10-20 mins).If i have to mention some cons, here are some. The respawning enemies at outposts can be annoying sometimes I suppose, but if they didnt respawn youd clear out all of them and then just be driving around an empty map that sure is well designed and beautiful, but wouldnt have any of the action youd expect from an FPS. Sound design from gun sounds to weather to just everything in general is really good, but if you're bothered by a characters mouth not being in sync with their dialogue then...yeah. AI can be a little finnicky sometimes, you can be on a rock in some cliff sniping down on an enemy outpost, put a bullet in a guys head, and his friend right beside wont even notice or react. Other times they'll find your location right away and immediately start firing at you. Enemies seem to take a little too much damage sometimes. When I played this game before I always carried a sniper so i could kill most people from a good distance with a headshot and its a one shot one kill, but if youre going in with an AR and thats all, you can put around 15 rounds into someone and they wont die. Other times they will. Its weird sometimes, but it doesnt really take away from the game in my opinion. It's just something you get used to. One thing I was disappointed by when I bought this was there not being any multiplayer. I try to create a Ubi.com ID and it just says theres a problem with the Far Cry 2 servers. Not a big deal, for only 3.50 its a good pickup especially for a great campaign. Theres some things i've probably missed, but for just 3 dollars, please just try this game. Its an absolute masterpiece. I played this game for YEARS literally when I bought it on PS3. Had thousands of hours invested online and beat the campaign dozens of times. Havent played in a while so I figured I'd pick it up on PC and give it another go. That's why this review is biased though, I have so many memories with this game and it's what got me into FPS games which lead me into COD4 and then into the cods after that. It sounds nerd as ♥♥♥♥ but Far Cry 2 had a special place in my heart and I wont forget this game. Not too many others I can say that about. 10/10.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Far Cry 2 is a open world first person shooter with some small RPG elements set in the African savannah.You have a aim, killing the Jackal, the person who supply the African war groups with weapons and causes the whole country to suffer even more.When arriving in Africa you get driven by a taxi driver to the main city Pala.While driving through the magnificent looking landscape you see several things and also notice your Malaria.You get a Malaria attack and get unconscious.You wake up in a house in Pala and see your enemy, the jackal.He decides who lifes and dies and he lets you alive.After this you have to get out and get unconscious again after a while.You get saved by a group called UFLL. There are 2 groups who have war against each other.UFLL and APR. Who is the good and the bad have you to decide even though both are not perfect.I personally prefer the UFLL. Only my opinion though.On your way through the story you visit a lot of places and meet your buddies who help you.I wont say more to dont spoiler too much.The gameplay is actually very nice. I love the first person weapon handling.It feels realistic and there is a big range of weapons to choose from.All being buyable in the Weapon Store for diamonds.Thats the currency of the game.You can also buy upgrades for you and your weapon.Your weapons degrade! Maybe too fast for some but for me its fine, especially with upgrades.You can change them for free in your Weapon room and "repair" them like that.I wouldnt recommend using weapons of the enemies, they are weak and in bad quality.You often get quests to finish certain aims. The mission variety is fine even though not big.But its fine for my taste. You mostly get diamonds or medicine for completing quests.You can also find collectables in the game. Diamond suitcases with 1-3 diamonds in each and Jackal tapes.There is a incredible amount of this stuff. Also there are 8 gold AKs in the whole world.The difficulty is higher than normal. Dont try rushing over the enemy, this mostly wont work. You always have to watch out. And the health doesnt regenerate, at least not completely. You need some sort of medics to heal yourself and you cant carry unlimited of those.The open world is extremely big and you have your feet, cars, boats or the bus to reach several places.Busses are helpful for those who prefer fast traveling even though the busses just have 5 stations per map.Enough for me though. The fact that you have to travel actually I like about the game.Its nice visiting the landscape and I like this sort of oldschool traveling.Some may dont like this sort of system but I love it.While travelling you will often pass some sort of checkpoints of the enemy who will shoot you on sight.Each of those checkpoints have some special ammo or medicine. Mostly with around 5 enemies at each point.A little bit annoying about this game is the way how the Enemies respawn and hunt you with their cars after they saw you. You mostly have to kill the car until you can continue passing. Also the enemy is often faster than you. After you erased a point, the enemies will respawn fast after going away and come back and that is the most negative point about the game. I got used to it, even though I agree its not perfect. Beside of those checkpoints there are also other places which are often specially named. Places like bases of the enemy. Trainyards, camps, whatever. There are often 10+ enemies and you should watch out, most of those places you see automatically while doing missions.There are also animals in the nature, around 5 sorts of animals in the whole game. Realistic behaviour and they shun humans. I often think they could add more animals and also hunting animals but on the other hand its not as unrealistic as in Far Cry 3. The animals there are to much if you ask me.The graphics and engine in general are amazing.I rarely saw so much realism. The whole engine simulates real world nature. Wind, rain, sun and day cycle.The graphics in general look amazing. Especially fire effects. Definitely 10/10 in terms of graphics especially for 2008.Some say Crysis or CryEngine 2 is better but I think they are equivalent. The Dunia Engine just has its aim on realistic day/night cylcle and weather cycle. A little part of the CryEngine is in the Dunia Engine btw!The Music is also amazing and fits perfectly into the whole setting.The African setting like that is pretty unique and thats great.The Multiplayer is ok.Some sort of CoD sort of Multiplayer which is just more realistic in general.Not many people play it online anymore though.Fortunes Edition DLC:This is a small DLC which adds 3 new weapons, some new cars and some new Multiplayer maps.Nothing special but not bad either.And now our favorite part.Can it compete against Far Cry 3?I say yes.Its maybe not everyones taste but Far Cry 2 counts to my favorite games and can compete against Far Cry 3.It maybe doesnt have so many gameplay tweaks as Far Cry 3 but I like this rustical way how Far Cry 2 handles everything. Reminds me a little bit of oldschool games. Not a lot of gimmicks but everything thats neccessary to have a nice game. I love the atmosphere of the game. The whole nature is amazing and the music fits perfectly into the game. Maybe its even better than Far Cry 3 in this part.Some of you are maybe spoilered of Far Cry 3.Try ignoring the things that Far Cry 3 does better.I already played the game 2009 and I loved it back then.Far Cry 2 maybe isnt perfect but it does a lot of things right and it has a great experience.You should definitely try it especially because of the price. I think the game will get 9/10 from me, maybe overrated but I think this score fits good for me. Make yourself an own picture of the game and dont listen to people who say its bad.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												OK, and now for the review i have been waiting to do......What can i say about this game, aside that i believe it's about as close to perfection as a game can get...???  From the AI, the weapons, the amount of immersion, graphics, story, sound, everything in this game just oozes awesomeness.  This was a game that managed to draw a fine line between what people enjoyed and didnt.  Either you absolutely hated it, or you loved it dearly, with no middleground.  Most of the complaints revolved around the respawning checkpoints, which didnt bother me because, well, IT IS a shooter afterall.  If you're playing a shooter and you're not shooting something, then it can get a little boring sometimes.  First on the discussion list is the story.  Loosely based on the short book titled "Heart of Darkness," the story has the player hunting an arms dealer named The Jackal who supplies two rival factions with an armory to start, and continue waging war against each other.  On your journey you aid both factions in search of information of the Jackal's whereabouts.  Now, this isnt a story that unfolds like you initially think it will.  Far Cry 3's story is very similar in context, but told in a more dude-bro lingo, while Far Cry 2 does so in a rich, yet immensly dark tone that will test what kind of man (or woman) you would become in this situation.  Considering that you're thrown into a real-world senario in a fictional African country, the story is constantly unfolding without the player even knowing.  Many games these days have taught us that the story is only told through dialogue or cutscenes, but this game has a story that unfolds with every bullet you fire, and every death you cause.  It's a morailty tale that might give each player the insight as to who or what kind of person he or she is, or will become.  The gunplay is some of the best i've personally encountered in any game.  From the sniper rifles, to the assault rifles, to my personal favorite, the 6P9 silenced Makarov, every gun feels rather unique in its own right.  Each sniper rifle has a different characteristic, the 2 rocket launchers each perform differently, even (most of) the pistols perform differently.  And, of course, everyone's favorite is unlockable very early in the game:  the flare gun.  Spreading fire was the key innovative feature in this game, and when done correctly is a very strategic tactic when taking on the numerous guardposts.  The AI is unscripted and acts accordingly to you.  If you haven't engaged the targets, they talk amongst themselves.  If they think someone is nearby, they will slowly approach the location of the disturbance.  Also, your reputation determines how aggressively the AI will combat you.  The lower your reputation is means the AI will hunt you down because they dont fear you.  The higher the reputation is the more cautious they are, meaning they may find cover or try to flank you.  The graphics and sound seem very dated in 2015, but for it's time it was top notch.  Some might argue that the graphics in Far Cry 2 are better overall than Far Cry 3.  When you factor in small details like shadow resolution, texture quality, and Ambient Occlusion, Far Cry 2 does have the upper hand over 3.  Lastly, the immersion plays a pivotal role in this game.  There is next to no regenerating health and health is restored using syringes or water bottles.  Malaria can attack you at any given point, although as your symptoms improve the time between attacks increases.  When very low on health your character performs a "surgical technique," in what is basically described as one of the coolest animations in a video game.  Gruesome, sure.  Cool???  You bet!I've logged over 600 hours in this game on steam, and another 200+ on disk, and almost all invested in single player.  I can't even describe why i keep coming back to this game so much.  Maybe it has to do with the fact that this game allows my imagination to run wild in the combat senarios.  Maybe because the story is that engaging.  I don't know.  What i do know is that since this game came out 6+ years ago, i've only found 1 other game like it, and it still doesn't hold a candle to this sheer brilliance.  Advice for new players reading this???  Give the game some time.  Allow yourself to sink into the story and REALLY think about your every action and what it's doing to you.  Study how every decision you make affects YOU, not your character, but YOU.  And for the love of god, play with all the guns.  There's only 31 guns (with DLC).  9.8/10

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is an action open world game developed by Ubisoft Montreal and published by Ubisoft. It was released in October 2008. You, play as a mercenary sent into Africa in the midst of a war between the APR and UFLL. Both sides are wanting power and control of the nation. This review will discuss the campaign and the open world element and provide a general recommendation in the conclusion.  Campaign  Far Cry 2 features a very good and tight campaign. The story is simple, you are a merc and you will bid for any of the factions that pay you the most. The caveat is you have to complete missions for both sides, which do eventually learn that you are doing work for the enemy. Story-wise, the game really drives down the power hungry aspect of things in which you have to assassinate leaders, and multiple of them. It’s a strong narrative and I immensely enjoyed the story and the twisting elements of it. Furthermore, I did not experience the 'Ubisoft bug' where it hits about 15 hours in the game and it feels like a chore to complete it, which is a refreshing thing to say about an older Ubisoft game.The main characters in the game, whether it is enemy characters or allied buddies, have distinct personalities. In particular, your buddies have a very brief journal in the game that allows you to discover and learn of their background. Buddies are important because when you gain a main mission they contact you to provide an alternative approach to the mission, which has many benefits including making the mission easier, increasing your reputation and upgrading your safe house. Further into the game it becomes fairly irrelevant as you get more powerful.  Open World  The open world element is very nice, it isn't too large but it isn't small. There are two maps, both have safe zones, and a variety of areas including enemy guard posts, gun shops, and so forth. All of these provide the open world aspect of it. Furthermore, the side missions actually add to the game. For instance, you can get missions from the church to help you cure your malaria illness, which is essential. Or, you can go to the gun shop and do their specific missions to unlock more weapons for you to purchase. In other words, side missions are not filler, rather the majority of them add to the experience of the game. The gameplay portion is absolutely fun and realistic. If you have shoddy weapons for example, they can jam mid-battle causing you to flee before retackling the objective. The story is realistic in that there is no money, rather the currency is diamonds. I enjoyed the little things in the game per say as they added realism to the game.  Issues  I experienced some notable annoyances and glitches. The first was the health system because the enemy somehow have very accurate accuracy as it hurts if they hit you and it takes several bullets to hit them, which actually becomes annoying and unrealistic. Furthermore, I absolutely hated enemies automatically respawning at guard posts. Second, when you answer the phone during missions or at any time during the game, the dialogue does not pop up on the screen and there is no sound, meaning there is a glitch. Lastly, there were multiple crashes when trying to save the game.  Conclusion  Far Cry 2 is a pretty good game. It features a thrilling story that is both compelling and immersive. It provides a very realistic and accurate take on the current state of civil war in Africa in contemporary times. I enjoyed the gameplay, in particular the elements that made it more realistic such as weapon jamming and weapons getting rusty. In contrast, there are major glitches relating to dialogue and crashes that did hurt my play-through. I feel this game would have been excellent provided there was no multiplayer and the focus was the single player as it was nearly great. In saying that, I totally recommend this game, as I enjoyed it considerably.  Rating  8/10  Pros  	- Excellent story with twists and turns.	- Gameplay.	- Realism. 	- Side missions as they did not feel like filler content.  Cons  	- Crashes.	- Bugs within the game.	- Enemy AI, in relation to gameplay but also enemy respawning.If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group Antwog's Analysis (Reviews).

Posted: February 17
												This is a classic challenging Fps game with very little hand holding, devepment and plot. You are attacked by both factions on every mission because you are a Mercenairy, every mission explains this.The outposts respawn (get reinforced) because they are at strategical map locations in a war torn country. Your guns jam and deteriorate because you are in a humid jungle and well guns just ♥♥♥♥ing jam (something no other games hold Stalker, have implimented) which is so realistic and only adds to the experience. The world becomes more alive and realistic than other farcry games with better pixels because of a slight breeze, blowing dust and circling birds. The absolute pinnacle of this game is the guns. Oh my the guns are done very well. The sounds, the effectiveness of each different one. Every single shot you fire ejects a shell which makes a corresponding sound depending on what it strikes. Its the Primitiveness of the plot and story and the extremely advanced weapon handling system that make this game so great. All the things i listed are what casuals think are wrong with this game. Yet they make the game prob one of the most immersive best fps titles you can experience. Im glad that this game is a love or hate it affair. Its the perfect example of a game that seperates real elitist hardcore players who want to be pushed and challenged and actually feel like they are in a hostile environment. Instead of casual vaping hipsters playing one of their 10 titles of the day for 1 hours and writting it off as broken or bad within the first 30 mins. Really nothing compares to Farcry2 for immersion. The only thing i can think of is Stalker: SOC which is superior even completely broken and glitched.This game is smooth. It lacks any drama ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t plot that seems to glue most current gen games together. Its primitive raw FPS like games of the past. Its the Darksouls of FPS games where any wrong move or a venture down the wrong path can mean immediate death.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is one of those games that any reviewer on youtube loves to♥♥♥♥♥♥all over, hell alot of Steam reviews will♥♥♥♥♥♥all over it and rightfully so. Despite being an amazing game, Far Cry 2 has a lot of design issues. Outposts can respawn within an hour, there are long periods of tedious traveling and driving to destinations followed by sporadic moments of shooting two dudes in a car, all of the missions are basically the same "kill this" or "blow this up", the buddy system is underdeveloped, picking a character has literally no effect on the game and the soldiers of both factions are out to kill you, even when your doing a mission for one of the factions! With the lazily given reason for this being that your mission is supah secret and no one knows about it. The Malaria gimmick is more annoying than an interesting part of gameplay and the world feels very static, with no sight of civilians around the country-side (which the intro cut-scene shows). Instead  they're hiding inside huts waiting for you to give them passports in exchange for your malaria medication. The actual world is populated by respawning soliders and mercenaries and the wild life is just there so you can watch the hilarious ragdoll physics go into effect when you hit them with your car. Finding Diamond briefcases can be frustrating (and also makes no sense), increasing your "reputation" does nothing except make the enemies say different dialogue and have better weapons over time. And finally the way you heal damage by viscerally resetting broken fingers and pushing bullets out of your gaping wounds is brutal and awesome to watch at first, but reaches Monty Python levels of comedy when it is done multiple times in a single gunfight.And yet, This game is ♥♥♥♥ing fantastic because what it does it does better than almost any other game. Its firefights are fantastic with smart A.I. that leaves you with a exhilarating sense of an adrenaline rush combined with a real sense of fear due to the fact that the enemies will do everything in its power to ♥♥♥♥ you. Along with a fire mechanic that frankly is nothing more than a gorguous piece of artwork as you watch it spread throughout the dried grass and trees of the country-side and into the enemy base with the backdrop of an orange setting sun. The African environment feels so real, like you can really feel just how hot and unpleasant it must be just by looking at that beating sun in the sky and the shriveled up grass in the plains. Enemies constantly complain about the heat and there are empty plastic water bottles scattered everywhere. Furthermore, when you enter the bases of the Factions, you can almost feel the humidity and the laziness it would create as papers and garbage are thrown on the floor as its occupants are to drenched in sweat to really care. It reminds me of my apartment in the Summer. NPC dialogue is interesting to hear, especially in gunfights as they try to take you out and their hectic screams and grunts make them seem less like the super badass soldiers from every other shooters but simple mercenaries who are desperate to survive and leave this♥♥♥♥♥♥hole country. A combination of their smart tactics and scared dialogue makes them seem like a threat that would play out similarly in a real life scenario and at times you even feel bad for them as it's clear despite their advantage in numbers, they're just as scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as you are and do their hardest to look out for their fellow comrades.In fact the sound design is fantastic all around, all the voice acting is great and the standout performance of the "villain" The Jackal, provides a small amount of social commentary as he justifies his lifestyle as an arms dealer. All of the guns sound really good and the cracklings of that fire are pure eargasm. The music of conga drums being violently beaten as combat starts really provides a minimal but effective approach that makes the firefights even more savage. Though an issue with the latter is that the congas start anytime you fire a gun and only stops when it's clear you were just ♥♥♥♥ing around with a goat or chicken. lulz.Alot of the issues I mentioned in the first paragraph were fixed with Far Cry 3, which is also an amazing game. The world is lush and colorful and there is a lot to do other than shooting, there are soldiers that are on your side and also patrol the country side and will fight with you. There is Flora and Fauna that is actually dangerous to the player along with a hunting aspect. The Story is more developed with popular characters like Vaas, and of course, the ♥♥♥♥ing bases don't respawn. But Far Cry 2 still manages to remain relevant despite all of the improvements the third entry made. Simply because Far Cry 3 can't beat the 2nd game at what it does best: Gunfights and its fire mechanic. Far Cry 3 is an amazing game, but it feels very "video gamey". Far Cry 2 is less like a traditional Game and more like a simulation. But more than that it's a extremely unfair simulator with the cards very clearly stacked against you in every encounter, often with snipers and rocket launcher dudes covering all entrances to bases and a group of a dozen or more soldiers ready to flank you and kill you quickly while you're in the midst of suffering from a sudden bout of malaria. It's a game that is unapologetic in how dirty and below the belt it plays. Which is why the game suddenly begins to click when you, the player, begin to play like just as much of a dirty ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, if not more so. Use flamethrowers and molotov cocktails to make fires spread to bases and mow down the fleeing soldiers, throw grenades in areas where there are ammo boxes so that bullets begin exploding and hitting any enemy near enough to get sprayed. Buy an upgraded camo suit and silently one shot enemies in the head with your silenced pistol before taking your machine gun and killing the rest while they're off guard. Learn the layout of the land and use it to flank enemies, plant IED's on your jeep and then jump off it as it speeds into the base, then detonate it. Use a ♥♥♥♥ing mortar to scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of the enemies and make them scatter so you can pick them off one by one.And my personal favorite. Give a non fatal shot to an enemy so that he is crying and crawling out in the open. His buddy, his dearest friend in the whole wide world will come out to try to hoist him up and get him to safety. And you just kill them both.While Far Cry 3 is a very pretty game, with that whole paradise in hell motif going on. Far Cry 2's world is just as beautiful but in a more gritty and harsh way: Everything seems grimy, dusty and dirty, weapons that you pick up off of dead enemies and not from gun stores are rusty pieces of♥♥♥♥♥♥that break easily. The houses barely look like they can stand (a detriment to the game that you can't actually blow them up red faction style) and villages themselves look depressing with the lack of civilians and only soldiers, giving you an impression of what happened before you arrived on the scene. All the characters you interact with are greedy, evil ♥♥♥♥♥ that actively bring suffering upon the local populace for their own gain and their various mercenary lieutenants and your fellow buddies are more often then not, just scared people who got scammed into a war whose factions don't actually have the money to pay them and they're stuck unable to get out. It's an ugly, nihilistic game which despite its flaws ironically makes it one of the best games to come out in that decade, despite all its problems.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Some kind of paradox, that game is. It takes name from very famous FPS Far Cry - and giving a very diverse experience. So, basically, like heritor of Far Cry - it sucks really. First Far Cry was in its core quite oldschool shooter (like Doom or Half Life) - just with so many fixes as one could imagine 10 years back (like outstanding physics, witty and challenging level design, clever AI behavior).There, in Far Cry 2 - we have a nice engine, yes. AI may not be very smart... but it has some explanation by overall agenda. We're talking about setting of that game. It rests in the middle of some civil war in Africa, in one of many so called "countries" where state wasn't existed at all and people continuosly swallowing by warmonger tribes habits. That quite realistic setting lies so far from "just a tropical island afar from anywhere, where some mad doctor making a war mutants from mercs" - base of first Far Cry. But not a sip of realism made diversion between first and second games. Far Cry 2 is a sandbox. That's her bless and curse.Let's start with bad side: I quote there since I cannot say better: "Driving across beautiful but lifeless world while fighting infinitely respawning enemies to complete unimaginative missions for people who all try to kill you" (yougamers)Where first Far Cry gameplot offers dramatic episodes "like in the movies", sandbox game just leaves you to entertain yourself by continuous driving through the countryside, killing almost everyone on sight. Gameplot is awful, storyline doesn't have any cultural value. Just a reference to a movie "Lord of War". Protagonist (any of them) its just a brief bio like "Tall, strong, divorced, reserved, alcohol habits". No personality besides that. Mandatory "twist" in the midst of game just slightly changing decorations, nothing more. Ok, there are some little "twists" around every story mission, but it's just a choice between two shootouts, with big blood or with much-more-than-big blood spilled. Oh, and story motivation - running from one dose of drug to another - kinda frustrating, I guess.Now, question - is it worth playing at all?Well, yeah, there is a good part.This particular FPS game still a way more wiser than any flat but overrated shooters like whole bunch of Call of Duty series. While it's not as complex and addictive as Stalker games, for some points it's easily beats Ukranian games. For a start, it's size feature. Big vastes can be depressing, but, when you are planning to hit a conwoy or clear up a fortress full of soldiers all by yourself, you surely need some room for elbows (Bewegungsfreiheit, as Germans might said). And, all of sudden, moving in these vastes could be quite relaxing. Natural. Really, I've just played Far Cry for 7 hours not completing any missions. Just wandering around and collecting hidden diamonds. Game setting fits just right to simple wandering around. Almost like you're on vacation, on safari, of kind.Sadly, we have a very few FPS games in one-player modus, that allows player choose it's destination, planning your moves before rushing forward in battle, and using long-range rifles from distance more than 100 meters. Project IGI comes in mind now, for some missions (not completely). Xenus (another Ukranian game) - an ambitious sandbox, but poorly executed. Op.Flashpoint/ARMA are too simulating to be fun. What else?Overall: While many might find Far Cry 2 too boring, it has its own place. Like it was with Assassin's Creed 1, which too was a pretty boring openworld experience. If you can look behind its bad sides, game's good one, with some originality, charisma and clever details.Fair 7.5/10 in my collection.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												Possibly the most hostile and cruel game I have ever played. It drops you in an open world with guard checkpoints, snipers, rocket launcher dudes, patrolling machine gunners, and enemy millitary bases with nothing but the weapons you can scrounge together and the vehicles you steal. This might sound like every other far cry game, but this one takes every oppertunity it can to beat you down further. "Are you enjoying blasting people with that shotgun? Too bad! it's jammed now!""Do you like driving really fast away from machine gun trucks? Too bad! Your engine was shot!""I bet you love that rocket launcher. Too bad because it just spat a defective rocket at your feet. You have <1 second to run away."Unlike the later entries in the series this one does not try to accomodate the player. It won't "give you," anything. You have to get it yourself. The vehicles wont get you out of a sticky situation. You have to get yourself out, possibly while using vehicles. Every cool thing that happens in the game is all because of what the player "forces," to happen. You have to actually think about what you're going to do. For a clearer picture: You are pinned down by enemies in a base. You see a truck. You think you might be able to crawl your way to it without taking too much damage, but you also know that you need to drive it into cover before the enemies bust the engine. You remember seeing a river a short distance from the base before you snuck in. You figure that the river might have a few boats on it near the docks. Now you have a plan. "rush to the truck, drop it into the river, get out, swim to a boat. hope nobody sees you escaping. All while every part of your plan goes wrong in exactly the way you thought it would." Weapons fizz out, truck breaks down just as you flip it into the river." None of it is scripted, and all of it is trying to kill you at all times. The fun of the game all comes from beating the system rigged against you. That is why I reguard this as the definitive Far Cry game. Too bad that the multiplayer doesn't work without modding though. Also: if you suck at video games, this one will kick your [Censorship]Sidenote: The game is actually far more rewarding to play on higher difficulties, while only allowing yourself to save outside of military outposts. It's not a genuinely difficult experience unless your getting pinned down by as few as one or two enemies and having to ration out your two or three health syringes. You will die a lot in the beginning, but as you learn the ropes of how to survive, the game will become far more enjoyable than it ever was before. Much like the artificial progression of the third game, giving the character abilities that make him an awesome warrior, this one slowly transforms you into something similar, but instead of giving you abilities, you actually become better at the game and thus, equally badass. Instead of watching a character grow more powerful, you are the character, growing more powerful.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												Give me FarCry 2 any day. Destroyable gas stations, respawning checkpoints (I have no idea why people hated these with so much passion. Park the truck, pull out a launcher and blow the ♥♥♥♥ up!!), diamond discoveries, different landscapes with unique terrain. FarCry 3 is like the hot supermodel that doesn't have all the intelligence that a normal girlfriend does: She's great to look at but the depth of conversation and the ability to draw you in are severely lacking. I have an extremely difficult time believing that the main character matured from no combat experience to wiping out an entire cartel.This was my review for FC3 but I feel it also belongs here.  I won't play FC4 and probably won't touch Primal either.  FC and FC2 were by far and away the best of the series.  What other games allow you to burn dry grasslands to draw out your enemies like the cocaine runners did in Crocodile Dundee 2?  None.  The AI is spot on in all their responses and for a game this old, they take cover really well.  Landscape was incredibly well detailed to the point you would think it's a Bethesda title and this game made you WORK for victory.  Shame on all you crybabies that ♥♥♥♥♥ed and moaned about Malaria or jamming guns or respawning guardposts.  Y'all missed the damn point of the revolutionary gameplay that made you HUNT your enemy.  I felt like a lethal predator sneaking around with my silenced handgun, silenced shotty (Anton Sigur, anyone?), and a flamethrower.I also learned that the only tool you'll need in life to fix engine, radiator and body damage is a ratchet.

content:
Posted: March 2
												After beating Far Cry 1 I have to say Far Cry 2 followed it's own unique gameplay of endless waves of bad guys, and twist plots within the story. It's a good game. I had to have my patience while getting through the first half of the game. If you pay attention to the story line it helps you stay engaged till the ending. I believe Far Cry 2 was the, "next gen," of the series allowing the player to experience an open world scenario. If you're looking for the same game play as FC1 you're going to be taken on a different path of an experience. The story is rather dark. My best advice to you is to just play through the main missions. Do your malaria missions as well. I didn't have the strength to upgrade my weapons, or do ANY side missions. I strongly suggest you just do the missions, get your malaria pills when you only have to, and bypass the enemy checkpoints as much as you can while driving on the road. The game gets better after the first 50%, literally. I promise. Here's my pros and cons.Pros: Fluid combat. Easy to aim. Intense gun fights. Decent story for a Far Cry fan, rather dark though. Game is fun if you play through only main missions and only having to do about 4-5 malaria pill runs. Missions aren't too difficult. This game is much easier than Far Cry 1. Cons: I don't like to put a bad vibe on a game I enjoyed, but there are elements of this game that will drive you nuts. First off I didn't figure out that one can do a "quick save" until literally half way through the game when you get to the next part of the map. If this game only ran off of the save spots that you have to physically drive to on your map this game would be horrible. The amount of A.I that you have to fight is redundant almost. Enemy checkpoints located on your map will ALWAYS re-spawn. Just drive through them. They do NOTHING towards completeting the game. There's ammo and health packets in most of these though if you really need them. The driving in this game along with following the map is a time stealer. The arrow doesn't match up with where you are on the road exactly. The GPS's in the automobiles are off as well, plus it's too small for you to follow. I had to drive with my map out 99% of the time. The story is confusing if you don't pay attention. It's also very dark if you pay attention too. That's actually a mutual feeling, but the con about the story I do have is Ubisoft could have fixed the ending just a little bit.Overall I give FC2 a positive review. It's a good single player shooter. If the shooting wasn't fluid at all and the last 30% of the game wasn't interesting enough then I wouldn't give it a review at all. I plan on playing all the Far Cry games. I'm a big fan now. If I could give just one suggestion to anyone wanting to play this older game in the series I'd tell you to have patience and get through the first half, literally the first half. You can check your progress on game completetion in the "statistics" category when hitting esc. It's a good game! Hope you enjoy.

												Just from 4 hours into the game, this is an AMAZING game.Pros:1) The guns are amazing. Yes it has the AK-47.2) The map is big from my gameplay.3) Four weapon slots: Machete, Secondary Weapon, Primary Weapon, and Special Weapon.4) You can drive and pilot a boat.5) Awesome self-healing animations, including taking the pills (for malaria) animation.6) Grenade Launcher :)7) You can burn things.8) The running animation is amazing.9) The game looks pretty, and it doesn't need a good pc/laptop to play the game.10) (cont. from 9) You can adjust the graphical settings to your liking from "OFF or LOW" to "VERY HIGH and ULTRA HIGH"11) The minimap is a map you take out.12) There are a lot of the same sounds from Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 4.13) You can slide, just like in Far Cry 3 and 4.14) There are so many pros that I don't have enough patience to type them down.Cons:1) Driving a boat is horrible.2) The introduction takes like 6 minutes to shoot some god damn guns.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Please read what I have to say. Let me hear you out, I have listened to so many complaints these years ever since I played it that I want to puke from casual complaints. I will answer you. Please read what I have to say.WHAT THE GAME IS ABOUT:You, a hired mercenary on contract for some client, hunt down a famous white african weapons dealer called the jackal, so you stop the two rivaling fronts of killing each other as he delivers weapons for both. You get paid in blood diamonds and you get deceived sometimes. The game is all about the irony of man in times of hatred and prejudice. African mercenary civilian tribal wars and the morality of weapon dealing. Deals with the death.GRAPHICS, OPTIMIZATION AND ENVIRONMENT:First, the graphics. This dunia engine was close to realistic depiction of what we all wanted in 2008. Sharp Textures, nice shadows and such. We didn´t have screen space reflection, meaning no mirror reflections, but we had ATMOPSHERE in the settings the game played in, in this case AFRICA. And we had nice weapons and animations!We also had mature themed scenarios and plots. The geometry is great for its time, only that we lack high poly counts or ambient occlusion. What we could do in FC2 though was burn stuff and let the fire consume it in a dynamic manner. Bushes and trees catched fire and spread! We could use molotov cocktails or a flamethrower to drive the enemy into a corner! Because no one used it effectively, we never ever have seen it again in a game, what a shame... With enough level design, we actually could have used it to our advantage. Sadly we never did. The jungle environment was beautiful for its time and still does even now. Never had any modern FPS, except maybe something older like Vietcong, showing such beautiful jungles and atmosphere! It simply isn´t ugly, it´s more of outdated as it lacks many modern graphics elements like advanced shaders and reflections, occlusions and lighting techniques. The game is optimized for everything from 8800GTX to GTX 480 or RADEON 2900 to 5970. It runs on any CPU with two cores and uses 4GB Ram. The game runs maxed out on my old GTX460 in 1080p on 4xMSAA with average 71 FPS. So.... everything these days probably can run it. GTX 285 run them perfectly maxed out. GTX 260 can run them maxed out non MSAA and even 8800 GTX run them on high 1080p. Even Core 2 Duo E8000´s and AMD Athlon II X2´s are perfect for such a game and max it out.WORLD, STORY AND SCENARIO:What we didn´t have was the choices! Do we still have them? Maybe.... in FC4 we can decide between two factions, one being religiously obsessed, the other hardcore stalinistic oppression through force industrilazation. In FC2 we play a simple mercenary in a money war raged country though! WE have NO choice except for deciding between mercenary friends or righteous justice. Ubisoft took a inspiration from the book Heart of Darkness from Joseph Conrad. They also looked at Lord of War from Andrew Niccol. It has you gripped with it´s realism but at the same time the characters and NPC´s are pretty far away personally and feel like puppets on a war theatre. The game never reaches to fit its role in letting you feel the worlds agonizing universe. Yet it lets you feel helpless and gives you the right impression of ♥♥♥♥ed uppery. GAMEPLAY AND BALANCING:Guns all feel balanced. They all have their purpose and none are too weak nor does the recoil make them unusable. You can decide from your very own gun houses and chambers all over the map. Which gun to equip for the next mission and which to use for your purpose. Useful and nice. Ammo is restockable and guns are buyable through a computer in the gun brokers -/ dealers shop next to your inventory houses. You can buy upgrades like stealth suits and car repair time reductions, but also a quite big arsenal of guns itself. This game has a 3 slot mechanic. Main gun, secondary and special weapon. Like Sniper rifle / assault rifle, pistol or SMG and flamethrower, explosive / LMG. Shooting guns feels amazing with great animations, recoil and details being excellent! Sadly for many there´s a jamming system with rust. If you don´t take care of your weapons, taking cover instead of charging in on enemies will be the needed way of fighting, because the guns will jam HELLA LOT. So take care of them, like a real gun nut and the game will forgive you. I will forgive you....MISSION - / LEVELDESIGN, AI AND ISSUES:The enemies flank you and shoot accurately. Stealth is possible and even sometimes easily the recommended choice. Even on brought daylight! The AI has brain and knows how not to act like a bunch of "running against walls idiots". They hit you quite often and quite hard and are admirable enemies. The AI is fine, except for animals, which happen to be present. Enemies are challenging on higher difficulties. Level design often goes into either scrapyards, facilities, plantages, farms, villages, depots, estates, mansions, docks and desert ruins.... it has a variety and offers you many places to fight in. Nearly everything is burnable and destroyable with decals flying all over the place!Fantastic level design! Many great routes and alternative routes besides the main routes, often you get blue instead of red alterantive routes. Morally good routes and objectives which your mercenary friends offer you to take on instead of the straight morally bad red ones. Good mission design. Many different objectives, from talking to radio DJ´s to making propaganda to execution to hostaging and blood diamond retrieval or escort, sometimes even base assault and much more. The game has you covered. You drive in buggies or quads most of the time, otherwise you take busses or boats to get to your objectives. Many who complained over long travel times never discovered the bus feature! What idiots! And there´s one big issue! The respawning enemy outposts! You can avoid them by driving past them as the map always allows you to drive around the outposts easily! IDIOTS! I SAY! IDIOTS! OMFG fc 2 was♥♥♥♥♥♥becauseof respawning enemies? Yes, one issue of game design! But what I did was drive around them without them pursuing me and if they did, change from the drivers seat to the MG seat and quickly kill the pursuing cars by shooting the driver and MG guys. Took me like max 10 secs! People are idiots.... Don´t be an idiot! Do it like me! This game didn´t have many issues except for that. It could get repetitive often and it had those outposts, but mostly you could avoid it. The way you die is different from other games as well. If you do missions and favors for mercenary friends, they rescue you once you died on the battlefield. They let you know if they are willing to come to your rescue. A real nice bioshock like resurrection feature. But in the end, the flow, missions and such were all nice after all if it weren´t for the issue of malaria! Yes you can get malaria... you need to do side quests for aquiring pills. You can also just let yourself get a malaria induced breakdown or stroke and have your friends save you, so you can avoid the side quests and just play for a long time until you get the stroke again.... That can be annoying. The game is still worth it though.CONTROLS:The game controls really nice and with direct mouse control, even if the menu mouse is kinda wonky. Aiming and moving is fast and accurate with no input lags and you have most common standard first person controls.ENDING AND GAME LENGTH:The game length is around 25 hrs+ with two maps and plot twists.The game offers you a nice ending with the decision to either save friends or hunt down the jackal with a nice twist at the end. Nice ending and satisfactory game length.  A fantastic game with fantastic gameplay and fantastic atmosphere ahead of its time. I wish many more would approve of it.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												I'm just gonna go ahead and say that FC2 is my favorite game in the series. I found Far Cry 3 to be casualized and easy. There was no challenge from start to finish and it follows the same Ubisoft open world formula from recent Assassin's Creed games. Far Cry 2 is vastly different and I prefer it over Far Cry 3 and 3.1, I mean 4 for a number of reasons. I mean just the fact I don't have to climb any radio towers to see more of the map or having the map littered with collectable icons are great. The feel and sounds of the guns are also really good for a 2008 game. Every gun in FC2 feels unique and don't feel like a toy compared to FC3 and 4. Guns jam, they have recoil, they show signs of wear and tear, and more. They don't feel like brand new military weapons but rather feel like they fit the African milita setting of the game. Every gun in FC3 and 4 feel like they're brand new and the sound is muddy when shooting them. In my opinion the gunplay in FC2 is some of the best I've played in a first person shooter, and I play quite a few of them (check my Steam game list if you want).The AI I think is pretty decent for a 2008 title. There are games released today that have far worse AI than this game. In Far Cry 3/4 if you're up on a cliff or a decent distance away and you take an enemy down via sniping then the others in the camp or nearby will always somehow zero in on your location. In FC2 the enemies will try to help their fellow comrades by carrying them to safety and search the immediate area, not instantly know which direction the shot came from like in FC3/4.As for the malaria it never really inconvenienced me when out and about, and I thought it was a pretty nice touch to the overall setting. I also don't feel it artificially prolonged the game like say having a crap ton of collectables all over the map.As for the story I'd have to sayit's not the best. In fact I enjoyed Far Cry 3's story more than FC2, but when it comes to the gameplay then FC2 for me wins easily.I give it an 8/10.PS. Don't mind the 2.6 hours on record. I played this game to death when it came out on PS3 and bought it on Steam a couple years ago on sale.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												There are some aspects to Farcry 2 that i actually like more than 3.The gameplay of Farcry 2 is pretty much standard like an FPS would be albeit with some addons and differences. You are able to use a primary, a secondary, and melee weapon along with a special weapon including grenades and molotovs. It is a big open world and your main means of travel is by various types of vehicles. To add a bit of realism, guns will jam and explode after awhile of prolonged use.Unlike its predecessor you can have buddies that protect you and help you on missions. You can pick which character you want to be, though it doesnt really change the outcome. Also unlike its predecessor the setting is completely different as it takes place in Africa and not on tropical islands out on the pacific ocean. While alot of people showed disdain for this setting change, i actually liked the setting and enviroment.The story of Farcry 2 is gathered via information when you accept missions or when you find cassette tapes left behind by the games main Antagonist "The Jackal". Essentially the lore of this game is in the background and you have to research it and pay attention to understand whats going on.Farcry 2 still holds up well in its Graphics Department for a game from 2008. The Dunia Engine makes use of fire elements burning the enviroments grass and trees, as well as showcasing a day and night cycle and weather effects not present in the previous game. As for the sound design the explosions, guns etc are all top notch while the voiceacting is pretty decent. A few music tracks caught my attention in this game; i really enjoy the calm music transition to the fast battle paced ones when a firefight is happening.My only minor gripes with Farcry 2 are having to constantly get Malaria pills, and the long drives it kinda takes to get to some areas. Other that that i recommend playing Farcry 2.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												After my first review that didn't seem helpful to a lot of people and the fact that I had nothing positive to say about the game, I gave Far Cry 2 a second try. The graphics are great and the weapons and upgrades are good as well. There is plenty of action, diamonds want to be found and the map is huge. Unfortunately I still find many things that I don't like and that still annoy me a lot. First there is the car driving, this gets annoying really quickly as you constantly have to drive from one end of the map to the other and back again. It doesn't help that you cannot truly clear out road blocks, enemies will respawn even though you have cleared the camp. You can just "scout" these camps, thats all. This way, you will have plenty of shootouts as you often have to step out of your car and kill people before you can head on. Im also missing a fast travel system to locations you have scouted or at least to safehouses. Driving becomes a chore.Secondly there is this awful map. It is a good idea, but ultimately it is obstructing your sight and is annoying. This minimap is missing several options, you as a player should have control over. Hold the GPS in one hand and a pistol in the other for instance. Or have the map in your left hand be set on the left side of the screen and not right in the middle. Or have a GTAish GPS in your HUD. Instead you can hardly see whats in front of you. The buddy system is interesting, but ultimately lacks the immersion to bond with your partner(s), they seem expendable and are badly written.The story is bland: Kill the Jackal. I'm totally missing storyline here, that leads you through the game, tells you an actuall story. Instead the game presents you unrelated quests of killing that repeat themselves. After all you don't even know what you are actually doing and why you are in Africa. Are you there for a Malaria cure, that you got there to begin with? Are you there to befriend the Jackal? Kill Factions or not? What was the purpose of it all? Bring refugees across the border?I thought Im a mercenary, there to make a profit, well guess I lost my identity.The AI is pretty annoying as well, granted they try to surround you, but it seems even if you are hiding they always come from behind, spot you through obstacles and shoot you through high grass and plants where you could only make prediction shots.SPOILERS: But the worst of all is the miraculous ressurection of your so called buddies. First they will be killed in  the bar. Then at the end every buddy is there again in a shootout for some stupid diamonds. Even if you shoot a buddy yourself during the game, but whole clips in them, they will come back. This makes no sense at all, "story" or otherwise.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is the sequel of the FPS Far Cry, this time set in the heat of Africa. It involves hunting down "The Jackal", the feared arms-dealer that fueled the war between two nations. Meanwhile, you're also constantly fighting against your contracted malaria.PROS: + Pretty long gameplay+ Good graphics despite its age and can run well on lesser devices+ Immediate freeroaming (in both areas once you reach the next)+ A good variation of satisfying-to-use guns + Lovable open nature of flora and fauna (as cheesy as that sounds)+ Raiding outposts and towns is incredibly fun+ Has a map editor which is pretty funny to fool around with+ Packed with the Fortune's Pack DLC which includes a few more weapons, alt machete, vehicles and lore+ Fair price/content ratioCONS: - The missions and various subjects (music, sounds, voice lines, etc.) are slightly repetitive- The health system and certain damage sources are a bit odd/unrealistic- The voice acting sounds like it is sped up somtimes- During my probably 200 hours on both the disk as well as the Steam version I've come across numerous small bugs like missing or invisible textures, sound malfunctions, AI glitches, odd mechanical behavior, etc.It's a little hard to explain why, but this game really feels like a masterpiece; it plays smoothly, it's fun, let's you freeroam rather quickly and feels a little realistic as well. Definitely one of the most enjoyable and memorable games I've ever played.The "Mostly Positive" rating on Steam is totally ludicrous. This game is a little gem.My rating: 9/10

content:
Posted: March 18
												I played this years ago, and returned to it as I enjoyed it; also that I have no game time on this account.  Farcry 2 excels at making the game fun just through the gun play and traversing the land scape;  I would describe it as a gleaming example of what a game should be - as oppose as some superfluous plot with rewards dispensed through progression, Farcry 2 is fun to play at the core.Its true Farcry is not perfect, there are so many obvious bugs; but it does almost add to the game rather than mock it.  The bugs are often hilarious, i.e. there is pretty much a constant bug where you enter an area and an AI militia will levitate up into the air and suddenly drop.. As lame as it sounds, it is very funny to watch whilst scouting the place out is always amusing.I think the best thing about Farcry is the stealth and standard FPS mix.  There are many stealth games today, but not necessarily in the past, I don't think it was as frequent.  And despite the stealth component still being very primitive, I can still creep around and kill an entire group of militia with a knife without being detected (even though knife kills are often or not going to get you detected.).  It almost feels at times that the stealth element wasn't meant to be a major aspect of the game, but I think it works reasonably well.There are quite a few characters , though playing as a different character does nothing any different.  So the character system is quite superfluous which is a shame.  Though its interesting how it all pans into the story.  Story was good enough. Although it seems rather pointless and of course in line with the farcry games - overkill.  The extra stuff such as the chit- chat between the militia is good too, the game certainly has character.  It makes it worth sitting back and observing your environment. However, the Jackal tapes are a questionable introduction.  There are quite a lot to pick up, but once you pick up 5 of them, the following collected say the same thing.  Its almost like the designers were trying to make you remember those words, the hopelessness of war which I can kind of appreciate but it still sucks , they could have added more variation to it.The gun play is very good I felt. Each gun is different and for example, the sniper rifles; the more expensive one, though it is semi automatic does not make it worth forgetting the others.  The guns are nice to use and generally I felt most were worth returning to.  However, the mortar is an interesting weapon, but I have tried to master it and found it doesn't do anything... I may be wrong though, and it would be a shame a weapon like that was put in only to be bugged out -  First person shooters could do with more deviation when it comes to weapons.The game design is interesting too.  Its a case of travelling through areas, so instead of walking through a linear level and you are presented with enemies, instead, you need to get from one point on the map and need to get through check points and other obstacles which respawn.  It makes the map very re-usable and again, as the combat and the ai is as-it-is, it can make it work... I have played farcry 3 and found everything about it was an extension to this game, so logically to say it would be an improvement would be expected, however, it does not play as well as this - it is definitely more boring.  This game is probably the best in the series , or that is my opinion.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Many games try to be immersive, but Far Cry 2 really pulls it off. In this war-torn African country, you are a mercenary and everyone hates you, even the warlords who employ you. You'll need a stealthy approach, but there are no detection meters, only careful attention. You'll need to trek across a beautiful open world, but there's only a paper map to get you there. You'll need money, but the only people worth saving in this country have no money, and the mission will earn you $0 on completion. The guys who have money are first justifiable, then amoral, then despicable, but by now you're hooked, and besides, the arms dealer promised you a grenade launcher if you took out his competition.Have you ever had to watch your friend die in your arms because you weren't fast enough at clearing out an enemy guard post, or because your gun jammed in the middle of a firefight, or because you had a sudden attack of malaria, or because you set the entire complex on fire and blew up the getaway car? You will, after you play Far Cry 2. Where Spec Ops: The Line is a self-aware jab at the player for playing an FPS, Far Cry 2 takes the time to engage you first, and trusts that you will realize what a monster you've become once the missions start being things like "The enemy can't fight if you blow up their water supply."I described this game to an African coworker and his response was, "Sadly, that's what happens in Africa."

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												This is one of the best shooters I've ever played, better than the games afterwards. The open world activities are structured in a very simplistic way, but achieving your objectives is anything but simple. You constantly feel like you're under threat of being attacked when you're outside, and you have to spend about 15 minutes preparing for each mission. Picking and replacing your weapons and maybe even getting new Malaria pills. There's a lot to contend with, you have to take cover and buy yourself time to heal yourself, you need to make sure your weapons don't jam, and you need to defend the buddies you bring with you because they absolutely can die, leaving them gone for the rest of the game. All of this means that pulling off the missions feels INCREDIBLY rewarding.Honestly I've never played a shooter as immersive as this, and yes the malria and guard post respawn issue is annoying, but not enough to break the game entirely. It's dynamic, it's dark and the world actually feels hostile to you rather than an open world playground. If you're willing to put up with its quirks, you'll find one of the most rewarding shooters of last gen here. They don't make 'em like this anymore.

The difference between Far Cry 2 and the others is night and day.Far Cry 3 is a decent popcorn experience which gives nothing and takes nothing.Far Cry 2 is a game with admittedly some rough edges, but the whole is greater then the sum of its parts.If you have the will to stick with it to the end, you will question the decisions you've made throughout the game; and the morality of you yourself and the people you associated with. content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												In my opinion Far Cry 2 is the best game in the series. If you liked Far Cry 3/4 but found it too easy or dumbed down, you will love Far Cry 2. Lacking features such as crafting and such from the more recent games (crafting is too overrated), it gives you a gritty experience of guerrilla warfare in an African state.I'd recommend playing with Dylans Realism Modification (gives the game an extra tweak to make you plan your attacks)I'd also recommend installing Far Cry 2 Graphical Enhancement Suite (to make sunsets and the overall atmosphere look even more beautiful)The game engine is solid, the only occasional physics bugs you will encounter will be when one vehicle crashes into another, or when you walk around the safe zones and the AI  occasionally gets killed by the physics objects. This can be hillariously funny, especially when the wildlife gets involved. (It doesnt happen often enough to be something to worry about, it's only happend to me about 3 times in my entire playtime). I have never had the game crash, ever. Even with the use of Dylans mod and the Graphical ES.The gunplay is satisfying, people complain that jamming weapons are annoying, however if you purchase your own you will rarely or even never encounter this. I rather enjoy the weapon jamming as it makes the combat more exciting and unpredictable.There is also a multiplayer feature for the game which you could make use of if you want to fight some friends.With a reasonably cheap price, and occasional sales, i'd definatly recommend picking this game up.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												This game is basically Africa Simulator 2008.You play as some faceless, generic mercenary sent to some generic African country to kill some generic arms dealer. Problem is two factions of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are fighting over all the rusted scrap metal and rocks you see throughout the landscape. You are forced to work for both factions and no one seems to notice the fact that you're working for both of them until the end of the game. Like what the ♥♥♥♥, nobody in either of the factions noticed that the guy working for them just ♥♥♥♥ed up their generic bad dude grunts for the 50th time.Also there's malaria, because some ♥♥♥♥wit in Ubisoft decided that running to the church each time you run out of your prescription pills to fight off your malaria induced seizures and doing some lame, repetitive mission was a good idea. Yeah, great job guys, real good.Your guns rust and break and♥♥♥♥♥♥which is pretty neat because it makes using enemy weapons a gamble because they can jam and ♥♥♥♥ you in your♥♥♥♥♥in a fight. Instead you buy your own weapons using some sketchy black market and some blood diamonds you find sacttered across the countryside that 12 children died trying to mine in a Congolese slave mine.The generic African country makes for a pretty dope map. There's deserts, savannas, jungles and more. Also thre's outposts. ♥♥♥♥ING OUTPOSTS. Every time you clear one the enemies just respawn. Like how many of these ♥♥♥♥ers are fighting here? How do they manage to return to each outpost 5 seconds after you just blew the ♥♥♥♥ out of it with an RPG? There's towns too but they're pretty lifeless, just more generic mercenary guys standing around.There aren't a lot of menus in the game. You press a button to bring up the map in your generic mercenary dude's hands and you actually have to look down at it. It's neat but it makes driving a ♥♥♥♥♥. There's some fast travel but only to certain points on the map for all you♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥who like driving 40 miles in a game just to get to the mission and die immediately to do all of that driving again. Immersion!You also have some people you meet in the game which are called buddies that can come save you when you get downed by enemies. They can actually die and when they're dead they're dead for good, which is pretty neat. They also help you out in missions with different approaches and ways to earn more Congolese slave diamonds. Once again, the buddies are all generic mercenary dudes. They try to inject some character into them but it doesn't really work out. I only liked the old Yugoslavian guy out of all of them.There are wild animals too like zebras and whatnot but they just stand around and watch all the dumb♥♥♥♥♥ fighting over nothing.Anyway its a pretty sweet game, get the Fortune Edition because you get an OP♥♥♥♥♥crossbow with exploding bolts which is just sick. Basically the game has everything; war, exploration, jungles, gunfights, companions, generic mercenaries, a pretty cool story once you get into it, and infectious disease. Something for everyone and definately recommended for the best Africa experience in a game yet.
