content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Far Cry 2 has nothing to do with Far Cry 1 and you can not compare them to each other because of that. Which is great. Because Far Cry 1 was a mess. It wasn't inherently bad of course. Hell, it was cutting-edge at its time! But I didn't like it too much.Nontheless, Far Cry 2 is just as hard as its predecessor. You're in Africa. You got malaria. Everyone wants to kill you. Ammo is scarce. Weapons jam frequently. Cars do, too. And I'm sure there's one bad person the dev team didn't like for every god damn guard post in this game. Oh the guard posts. Also, the AI is pretty good, especially on higher difficulties, making some fights seemingly impossible to win. Perfect for the masochistic player.One could argue that the main objective of a video game is to be fun. And you would be right. Seeing all these elements in Far Cry 2 and playing it for myself I can't say the game is always "fun". The game can be a frustrating, challenging and enraging piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥that slaps you for wanting to play with it. At times, Far Cry 2 doesn't like you nor does it want to play with you. Essentially, this game has a lot of conflict between casual video game fun and stress. But that's what makes this game a good game.It's not outstandingly great, by any means. But it's pretty solid. Although a lot of the missions come down to "Kill this guy", "Blow up this thing", "Steal that thing" or "Collect 1000 of these, pretty please". Also, you drive around. A LOT. Seriously. If there would be an african driving simulator, this would be it, I can tell you that for a fact.You could argue that Far Cry 2 can get boring at times. And it does, it certainly does. But then again, I've played MMOs so I'm up for the challenge. I don't get bored that easily. And if you don't get bored that easily like me, Far Cry 2 might just be the right game for you.You like shooting guys in the face with a variety of weapons? You like burning down vehicles, small, destructible buildings, people and gas stations? You like blowing stuff up? You like a gorgeous looking open world FPS? You don't have anything against repetitive quests and objectives? Having a constant, life-threatening condition that could strike you down at any moment doesn't bother you too much? Driving around in a car that breaks down all the time due to tons of guys shooting at it is no problem for you? If you said "Yes!" numerous times in the last 20 seconds, I advise you to get this game and have fun (or frustration - who cares, both words start with f so that's fair enough) with it!I like Far Cry 2 so far and if you think like me, you will like it, too. If you don't, it can't be helped. Not everyone can have a decent taste in video games. But you'll learn, I'm sure of it.

number of helpful: 16 of 23 people (70%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2012
												Wow, talk about a game that misses the point. As an American male, I was raised on a steady diet of action movies and games that fed me exactly the sort of masculine power fantasy that I have come to expect from shooters. From classics like DooM and Duke Nukem to modern masterpieces like Medal of Honor and Call of Duty: Black Ops, games have understood that the best thing to do is inflate my ego to as big as possible by giving me complete domination over enemies and pride of place in the narrative as I, the hero, destroy all evil and save the world. These games understand that from the day I was born, I was given toy guns to play with and taught to idolize soldiers, sheriffs, pretty much anyone in a position of authority with a gun.Which is where Far Cry 2 drops the ball. I mean honestly this game fails so bad it's like it tries to be the OPPOSITE of a power fantasy. You show up in Africa and immediately get malaria. You screw up your mission, nobody cares about you, your guns jam, you have to scrounge for cash, your vehicles keep breaking down, and everyone wants to shoot you. You have to pry bullets out your ankle or pull them out of your arm with your teeth, and you have to watch buddies bleed to death unless you shoot them.Fire will spread unpredictably and burn you to death. AND YOU CAN'T CURE THE MALARIA. You can just keep popping pills, but to get the pills you have to do favors for an underground resistance run by the people stupid enough to stick around while two militias fight over the country.Instead of feeling like a badass when you kill guys, they cry out in pain, writhe around, and respawn 15 minutes later. You are a bad person, your buddies are bad people, and you get missions from bad people to do bad things. You deceive and kill people for no reason other than a potential meager profit. Nothing you do makes the world a better place and you never feel good about it or powerful when you do it.So yeah, Far Cry 2, way to miss the point that basically every other FPS game in the world has understood. Other games realize that I can't get hard without getting a sweet headshot, but Far Cry 2 just makes me feel bad about shooting people. Honestly, what's the point of a video game that doesn't make me feel good about murder? That's like watching a movie where you don't get to see any♥♥♥♥♥♥or explosions. Lame. Plus this game is set in Africa. Who cares about Africa? Why not set your game some place cool like a tropical island? That's what made Far Cry good. Far Cry 2 is brown and sad. Far Cry was green and blue and happy! It was like a sweet vacation where you also got to kill some dudes with some rad guns. That sounds perfect, not like the miserable slog through a hot, insect infested swamp or through a scrapyard with burning tire fires that Far Cry 2 gives you.This game is basically Blood Diamond without the feel good message at the end. Did you get to see Jennifer Connelly's♥♥♥♥♥♥in Blood Diamond? No. Were there explosions in Blood Diamond? A few, I guess. But still. That movie wasn't exactly as awesome as something like The Expendables. And this game is no Duke Nukem Forever.Thankfully it looks like maybe Far Cry 3 realizes where Far Cry 2 went wrong and has brought us back to the "head to a beautiful island paradise, grab a bunch of sick weapons, and kill the ♥♥♥♥ out of some pirates to save your bros." Now THAT is a story I can get behind! And this time instead of African resistance fighters, there's a hot native chick who helps you out, and she's not wearing much! I mean I'm not sexist but it's good if the women in a video game are easy on the eyes. I play these things for entertainment. So with its RPG mechanics (which are great because leveling up is a great way to reinforce the power fantasy) and its return to a hero I can care about instead of the horrific mercenary with zero morals that I have to play as in Far Cry 2, it looks like Far Cry 3 is the game for me.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is my favourite title in the series. It will probably be yours if you like your games challenging and frustrating, but at the same time fulfilling to complete. The plot differs from other FC games; rather than embodying some variety of quirky evil, your nemesis - The Jackal - is shrouded in ambiguity. He sells guns to all sides, and so he must die...however, is it as simple as that?The AI isn't anything special, yet battles are made fun or even thrilling as you are handicapped by several abiding traits:- Malaria - this impairs your vision, ability to sprint or even walk, and total health.- Weapons jamming; this is painfully common in the heat of battle.- Vehicles are easily made immobile, making hit and run style attacks tough to pull off.- The environment of heavy foilage, dull browns and greens means enemies are easily camouflaged.- Health recovery is slow, to the point where fleeing is more viable than taking cover, which also tends to be difficult.Even patched, the game suffers from a few glitches, including one where a side mission failed to start, requiring me to load an earlier file. Navigating, with your handheld map, can be cumbersome. But these shortfalls are forgivable, for Far Cry 2 is punishingly hard, has atmosphere, benefits from a decent story, and makes diamond hunting near-compulsory in service of you getting reasonably equipped; for even more of a challenge, don't hunt or spend them.The visuals, while dated, remain passable several years after its release in Autumn 2008. The tropical forests and plains of sub-Saharan Africa have since been used by popular series such as Metal Gear Solid, but remain generally unfamiliar to gamers. The murky politics and many conflicts of the region make it nothing less than perfect for a Far Cry game, and make the story more believable and immersive.Far Cry 2 is superb, but only if you're the kind of gamer who relishes challenge, and doesn't want his hand held or need his eyes dazzled by cutting edge graphics.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game is one of the best games I have played. This game gets some negative feedback because of its difficulty, but I will explain why you should play it.First off, Far Cry 2 still looks absolutely gorgeous. Africa has never looked better in a game. You will find zebras and gazelles roaming the grasses. You will enjoy mountains, waterfalls, and canyons, travel across the small lakes, visit Pala, Sefapane, and Mosate Selao, and speed across the dirt roads to hunt for enemies.  The gunplay in Far Cry 2 is undoubtedly realistic. This is no Call of Duty; your guns behave like real ones and there is not much "running and gunning" unless you are playing on easy.  There is gun jamming and degradation, so you will need to take care of them. There are weapons for everyone. There are multiple rocket launchers, grenade launchers, pistols, machine pistols, snipers, and explosives. There is even a dart rifle and a explosive crossbow!The missions are fun but may get boring. I would advise playing on Hardcore or Infamous difficulties because when you play on them, the game becomes much more challenging and even more realistic. There are respawning outposts with enemies, and these provide good fun since you never run out of people that are trying to kill you. Many people are not used to such a harsh game; expect everybody outside of the Ceasefire zones to try to kill you. Is that good? Your call.There are tons of weapon upgrades and some vehicle upgrades, plus upgrades that will allow you to carry more ammunition or molotovs. The second half of the world unlocks when you complete half the missions in the game, and this second world adds new Jeeps, boats, and guns, plus new locations to explore.Fire is my favorite part of the game because it is so well-done. The fire is better than Far Cry 3 because it was not designed to play a large role in Far Cry 3. Far Cry 2 has seasons and rain, so expect fire to work less effectively when the grass is green or there is a downpour. When the grass is dry and there is no rain, fire becomes the game changer. If I feel overwhelmed during gameplay, I may throw a molotov cocktail into some dry grass to start a (potentially massive) fire. This fire scatters enemies, forcing them to change their attack plan; if you are lucky, you may even get one to burn to death. The audio in this game also never ceases to impress me. You can hear birds and monkeys in the trees, the wind rustling the leaves, the whine of the mounted gun as it swivels. When you are around enemies, you will hear their conversations (they sound believable). The music in this game is a nice change as it is what you would expect and African band to play. You have malaria during the game, and it puts an interesting spin on your gameplay. You may have to wait out a malaria occurence, and this can kill you. The best tactic to do is throw a molotov and hurry to cover.Note that it took me 30 hours to complete my first playthrough. After that, you can do a new one on a harder difficulty (feel free to change difficulty anytime you want). The ending of the game is unexpectedly deep. All in all, this is a game like no other. Everything I said above amount to an amazing experience. This is an experience like no other that can be had, during a sale, for just $2.50.

												For game that came out in 2008 this is realy awesome looking game. It have some glitches/raw moments especialy with mouse sensetivity and video/display settings... so you got to get used to it due time. Whole gameplay reminded me a bit a movie Blood Diamond with Leonardo DiCaprio... the atmosphere here is kinda the same. This game is Part/Open World shooter with some minor survival elements. Playing this game on Hardcore difficulty making it pretty challenging. Comparing to other shooters of that time in this game is a bit hard to aim and shoot and everything is very situational. And its different type/genre to FarCry 1. Basicly its one of 1st of very few open world shooters that came out on PC. CryEngine (aka Dunia) here looks realy beautiful (for 2008 ofc). Cant say that i'm pleased with storyline but also cant say that i dont like it... maybe just i wanted it to go a bit different way. I was playing this game for few months 1-2 hours per day and now when im looking at Steam and see that i've finished it to the ending for just 55 hours ... im kinda surprised... to me it seems like i was playing it for at least half of a year and spent much ... much more time. Also i realy like that idea of healing self by talikg out bullets and other stuff from your body pieces ... every time i was watching this i got my teeth tight creaking ))). 10/10 for this crap.So: Sound/Voice/Music - 9/10. Graphics/Visuals - 9/10. Story LIne - 7/10. Gameplay - 8/10I would reccomend this game to everyone who like non-linear 1st person shooters with some minor survival style things and constantly have some free few hours for gaming.-W-

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Pros:+Good variety of very different weapons, and they are all fun to use.+Beautiful graphics+Great deal of freedom when doing missions and freedom to do things when you want to do them.+Gun degradding, wound healing, and no pausing to look at a map add to the immersion.+Always plenty of guys to shoot and generally good AICons:- GENERALLY good AI. On harder difficulties, they can see through vegetation unusally well, but not consistently. They're also bullet sponges if you don't use explosives, shotguns, and sniper rifles. Sometimes they are smart and try to flank you, other times they bum rush you like it's their first time playing a shooter.- Voice acting is very odd; it feels rushed. Considering what kind of game this is trying to be though, this isn't a big deal because...- ... the plot is more of an excuse to be shooting people in Africa than an actual story.- Driving to objectives is a 'female dog' (thanks for the PG censorship on an M rated game, Valve) and a half with all the patrols and guard posts that respawn if you walk more than 100m away. I opt to go on foot most of the time becuase, aside from discovering more that way anyway, it's safer.Objective score: 8/10It's a tremendous amount of fun to feel like a hunter and methodically approach every conflict, but you don't have to always be stealthy. Constatnly changing up your play style is what makes this game so much fun. It's my go-to game if I just want to relax after a hard day. I like to take my time, slowly pick guys off one by one with the dart rifle, then finish off any remaining bad dudes with a shotgun. But again, I switch it up often. Silly ways to have fun:+ The flare gun is a one hit kill and magically kills everyone in a car, even though it doesn't set the car on fire nor directly hit anyone inside. +The AS50 can shoot through more than one person.+ Sneak up behind an enemy, place an ied, back up, *boom*.+ I never get tired of sniping guys in boats. They fly out sideways about 5-7 feet in a perfectly straight line.Subjective score: 10/10 - Would bless the rains down in Africa again... but fire spreads more easily when it's dry.Sorry I got that song is stuck in your head now :)

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Far Cry 2 is one of the best open world games out there. Set in a war-torn African country, there's a wide variety of places to see: from deserts, to deep jungles, small towns...The story is pretty good. You arrive at this country in order to kill the Jackal, the guy who armed both sides of the conflict. Things go wrong, and you end up taking jobs from the different factions in order to gain their trust, and, in exchange, getting information about your target. Luckily, you're not alone in this mission; although the troops will shoot you on sight even if you're working for them, you'll still come across several buddies (foreigners, just like you) who will help you out during missions.There's plenty of stuff to do in this game. Besides the main missions, there are different missions you can take, including taking convoys transporting weapons, assassinating certain targets, and helping your buddies out. Also, you'll encounter enemy outposts, and, although taking them out is fun, they respawn quickly, which gets tiring after some time, and you'll end up trying to use fast travel (which, by the way, is only available at certain locations, in the form of bus stops) as much as you can to avoid the outposts.The environment, as mentioned, is quite varied, and the map is huge. You can move around it using different vehicles, including jeeps, trucks, quads, boats, to name a few. You can unlock safehouses on the different areas, and there's hidden stuff to look for.Another interesting mechanic is the sickness level: your character is infected with malaria, and there's nothing you can do to cure it, you can only take pills in order to control it. While it's an annoyance most of the time (especially if you have a malaria attack right in the middle of a firefight), it's still an interesting mechanic. There's also weapon degradation, meaning that you'll need to get new weapons from time to time, or run the risk of a weapon jamming at the wrong time. Luckily, weapons bought at stores are always available at armouries next to them.Well, in conclusion, this is a really good game, one you should really play.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												Great game even though its 2016. I already owned this game for a couple of years but never completed it for various reasons. I've played Far Cry 1 + Far Cry 3, so I've got some experience with the Far Cry franchise.I did not play this game vanilla, I installed these compatible mods from the beginning and I can recommend you to do the same:- Dylan's Far Cry 2 Realism Mod.- Real Africa - The Ultimate SweetFX Config ( Best graphics mod, trust me).- Night Vision Mod for Far Cry 2 by Masson.First of all, what immediately striked me when playing this game was the nature. From the way the wind was blowing trough the grass and trees, the birds and other animals making their pressence known. It just felt alive and breathing.The transition from day to night, the different weather types, every little details adds up to something really beautiful. TIA, from Blood Diamonds, one of my favorite movies, comes to mind.I haven't finished the game yet, but I can already tell the story is realistic but not really fascinating to me.The villain in this story is intriguing, but Vaas was way more badass. Then again, wich game villain was ever more badass then Vaas? I like the buddy system, it adds another layer to the game. Especialy because they can die.Obviously if you quick save allot then you can prevent this, but I like to play hardcore and only safe in safehouses.If they die on missions, they die. Brutal, but this game ain't about fairy tales, such is life.I already mentioned the nature and sounds, combined with the mods, the atmosphere in this game is absolutely perfect. When you are shooting african warlords or south african mercenaries, you get a sense of the cold (or should I say warm) hard reality of Africa. There is no higher moral ground whatsoever, you are in it for the money/diamonds, altough at times you are portrayed as the Good Bad Guy doing some of the dirty work that must be done for the good guys.Something I don't like in this game are the limited amount of vehicles and there is a weird invisible speed limiter at 70/110 (kmh), depending on the vehicle. I know it's africa and they don't drive Lambo's, but I feel this aspect could have been done better. Then again, this game was published in 2008 so I can definitely forget this flaw.The four weapon slots one weapon each are a bit anoying. But for gameplay purposes I can understand why they have done this and it fits the grim realistic setting of this game.The weapon jamming of rusty old weapons you got from killed enemies can be a big liabilty in battle. A grenade-launcher jamming in the middle of the battle with two nearby shirtless wild african UFLL soldiers screaming for your blood, can be a little daunting to put it mildly. The reloading and unjamming animations are awesome and rewarding. At times it makes you want to play with unreliable rusty weapons, just for the thrill and risk of having to take cover in battle and unjamming your weapon as a badass, maybe opting for your machete when the enemy gets close. Russian roulette at its best.The navigation map was very frustrating for me in the beginning, but I've gotten used to it. I still prefer a radar in the corner of my screen, but it's playable and again fits the setting of this game.There are some animals in this game, but they could have added more variety, like hyena's, rhino's, flamengo's et cetera.  All and all, I've already taken way too many screenshots of this game and I'm going to enjoy finishing it.So far this is my favorite Far Cry and I think it's way too underrated. I wouldn't say this game feels old, to me it feels more like a 2012/2013 game.I hope there will be another Far Cry in the future with this setting, because it's one of the best. I give this game a 9 out of 10.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												If you are looking for a great open-world first-person shooter, than you should take a look at Far Cry 2 in a Steam summer sale. This game has nothing to do with the first Far Cry game because it is a completely different world and setting. StoryMain story: The player takes control of a mercenary on a lengthy journey to locate and assassinate "The Jackal", a notorious gun runner. He is the one who is selling weapons to the people and the main reason for the escalation in Africa. To find him you must take missions from two factions during a civil war: the APR and the UFRR.  “The jackal” will finding you, so you have to be like him to gain his attention.GameplayThis game takes place in Africa and has a very big area with 50 square kilometers and many different terrain like deserts, savannas and jungles. There is a dynamic weather system that has a day-night cycle and different weather conditions such as storms and strong winds. The time of day also affects the behavior of AI, in terms of enemy alertness and aggressiveness. To travel through the game you can use many vehicles including cars, trucks, quads and boats or you go by foot.To defeat your enemies you have access to a large arsenal of weapons. Assault rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, machine guns, explosives and a flamethrower. You have four weapon slots but only three can be chosen, because the first slot is always a machete for melee attacks. You can use hand grenades and Molotov cocktails too. Weapons can become dirty and prone to jamming if you use them to much, so you should change them from time to time.The realism in Far Cry 2 is very nice. Apart from the weather and the weapon degradation, the player needs to hold a physical map and a handheld navigation system to get around, no minimap in this game. The greatest feature is the fire. For Example, a small fire can become very large in an area like a savanna with strong wind. You are able to burn complete outposts with one Molotov.If you are not on a main mission you can collect diamonds to buy better gear, take save houses and spy outposts or kill all the enemies in there. Or you take side missions to get more diamonds and take special missions for antimalarial drugs.You can use many different play styles. Being like Rambo and use LMG’s, shotguns and a flamethrower or being like a ghost with a sniper rifle and kill them silently? Your choice. A negative point is, that the enemies respawn to fast. If you cleared an outpost and turn around after you drove 50 meters, they are back. That’s annoying. GraphicsFar Cry 2 was released in 2008 and looked very beautiful. In 2016 it is still looking very awesome and runs perfectly on newer systems. The Dunia Engine has the best vegetation I’ve ever seen, very realistic and nice. Lights and shadows are also very nice, only the nights are too bright and in 2016 the rain looks a little bit unrealistic if there is no sun, but 90% of the time your eyes will enjoy it. [Outdated]Far Cry 2 includes multiplayer and an awesome map-editor to create your own maps for the multiplayer with strict rules, that the map is balanced at the end. You can create realistic maps, recreate maps from other games [de_dust2] or just build funny maps like a race map. This is the easiest map-editor and I created a lot maps in 2008. The multiplayer was funny but today I think, no one is still playing that. Far Cry 2 is a great Ego-Shooter with a large open-world, a realistic and beautiful setting with a weak story bur strong gameplay elements. Most of the time you are a lonely wolf in a big and beautiful world and anyone is your enemy. It is an open-world adventure more like a sandbox game as a theme park title. This is not an action-title like Far Cry 3 or far Cry 4, so if you want that, then don’t buy it. If you loving large open world games and playing with different play styles, go and buy it on sale for less than $5,00. It’s absolutely worth it.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Probably one of the most thematically difficult games to experience due to the graphic potrayal of real-world issues: conflict diamonds, arms races, disease-attrition (malaria), internally displaced persons/refugees, and ideologically-fueled factions fighting for control over scraps of impoverished landscape. Unlike it's sequel, FarCry 3, this game feels less cartoony and emotionally vapid because it keeps the player vulnerable, evenly equiped with enemies, and isolated in the vastness of the maps. This can be frustrating at times, but ultimately (I argue) makes for a more valuable experience. Your mortality is quickly equated with that of the world's other NPCs and inhabitants, and so the destruction, or implied destruction, of those lives is more profound.While FarCry 3 represents a huge step forward in gaming technology and is a worthwhile experience in it's own right, it's emotional impact and themes fell flat for me because of how the game held your hand throughout and superpowered the player very quickly with outrageous rewards for menial tasks. I played FarCry 2 after finishing the third game, and felt a much deep connection to the aesthetics of this one. Although I think it's fair to say that the plot is almost non-existant, and certainly not a coherent narrative than a series of similaraly motif-ed scenes joined by some key characters and locals; the plot only really comes together toward the end of each "chapter" when the principle antagonists are reintroduced to the game after remaining shadowy figures, alluded to but not seen or felt. Overall, a fastastic game with some flaws, but one that has given me more pause to consider the real world than anything else I have ever played.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												It’s a great African driving simulator. But really…I had high hopes for Far Cry 2. I saw the great reviews it got. But only 5 hours into it I had to stop playing. It was a combination of complete boredom, frustration and knowing I’ve already experienced all the game would have to offer.Far Cry 2 is a very open world game. After the first guided mission you are free to go wherever you want, which is nice. Except…Here is the formula for every Far Cry 2 mission I encountered in 5 hours     +Drive to a place that has a mission available     +Drive to the waypoint on your map for that mission. Which is always far away.     +Get shot at driving through areas you’ve already cleared.     +Repair your vehicle.     +Take down a random vehicle with a turret.     +Repair your vehicle.     +Complete mission.That’s it…that’s how it was for 5 hours before I knew that was all the game had to offer and show me.I might have been able to push through if the missions were close to one another. But, there’s SO much driving in this game. I didn’t mind that in itself. The fact that it’s not even enjoyable really killed it for me. I thought after clearing a checkpoint it would be good from then on out…WRONG. Enemies always respawn everywhere. Which means you get in constant battles when you just want to drive through an area you already cleared. It makes me feel like I’m not accomplishing anything and gives me no incentive to kill enemies. I just resorted to flying through the checkpoints and killing any vehicles that gave chase to me. Far Cry 2, in my opinion, commits several cardinal sins in video games.      +Respawning enemies     +Enemies that can hit you from a mile away, consistently. Even with a shotgun?!     +Enemies that can instantly hit you each time you break from cover     +Enemies that know your exact locationPros+Open world style of gameplay+Graphics+Good shooter at its core+Capturing the African environment and culture+MusicCons+Respawning enemies+Extremely repetitive gameplay+Too much driving around+Enemy AI+Didn't feel rewarded for doing anything+Strange run on sentences with the voice acting4/10 Below averageFar Cry 2 really does have some good mechanics and systems it employs. But the negative things I mentioned above far outweigh the positives. I couldn’t continue playing and therefore can only recommend if it’s on a big sale and you’re really curious. Otherwise, stay away.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2013
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Far Cry® 2: Fortune's Edition Original Release: 2008 Genre Tags: FPS; Action; Open World;   My Overall Grade: B Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 12-25 hours Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Fans of the intellectual property; Aesthetes; Game atmosphere connoisseurs REVIEWMany people were disappointed in Far Cry 2, and it does have its flaws, but I still found it to be an enjoyable experience overall.  The game succeeds in being immersive and captivating, and the actual gameplay is exciting and has some novel mechanics. Also, there is an interesting story aspect imbedded in the main campaign. These qualities can help some people overlook the minor annoyances; others however may feel like it’s not worth putting up with them, especially if they aren't as interested in the narrative and atmospheric aspects.I felt that the environments were well-designed and the gameworld was a pleasure to explore. The graphics are pretty solid, and the animations and effects are noticeably good.    Far Cry 2 definitely has a nice setting.  If you enjoy immersing yourself in foreign gameworlds, you should like this.The gameplay is also pretty fun overall. There are a lot of good ideas and unique nuances in the game. Also, the combat can be exciting and the open-world allows you to plan your route of attack any way you would like.  There are some annoying aspects to the gameplay, though.  But there are some pretty awesome missions sprinkled throughout the game that make putting up with the annoying parts worth it.As for those annoying parts, there are two main aspects of the gameplay that can become tedious at times. For one: the gun jamming. The idea of implementing mechanics where guns found on the ground have little ammo and jam frequently sounds interesting on paper, but it needs to be executed well. In Far Cry 2, there are times it winds up being far more annoying than interesting. And the other main gripe with the game is the extremely frequently respawning guard posts.  Clearing 5 guard posts every time you want to travel on the map gets old fast. But both of these annoyances can be extensively minimized by just playing on easy.  Guns will jam far less often, and you will able to drive right through the guard posts instead of clearing them out every time. So I suggest you don’t play this particular game on a high difficulty.  You will only magnify the aforementioned faults with the game and allow them to overshadow the fun parts. And as I mentioned, there are some really fun missions in the campaign.So if you would be interested in this kind of game, and feel like you would be able to enjoy the good parts, then Far Cry 2 should be something you consider checking out.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												As much as I want to recommend this game, I can't. There are just too many immersion and game breaking bugs that will never be fixed.I'll admit, I did have fun for a while. Sneaking into a heavily guarded fort on a rainy night, killing the target and sneaking back out after only killing one guard with just a knife felt pretty awesome. But there are just so many annoying factors for the majority of the game, and let me start off with the two biggest issues:THERE ARE PROGRESSION BLOCKING/SAVE CORRUPTING BUGS THAT FORCE YOU TO RELOAD AN EARLIER SAVE.And you have no idea when they occurred. I had this happen to me twice in one playthrough, but luckily I had many save files to fall back on and find the ones that still worked, which set me back 4 hours. I almost rage quit and I wouldn't blame anyone for doing so. Having that many save files is also annoying because it takes forever to open the load menu because each save is ~5MB. I'm not completely sure, but I noticed that when the door guards tell you to go look for a guy in captivity, your game is about to break. Look at the map to see where the buddy is, then reload a save that was before you talked to the guard and go find them on your own. I have heard of other bugs like key NPCs vanishing or just refusing to talk to you, but I did not personally experience them.THERE IS A BUG THAT ONLY LETS YOU LISTEN TO 11/18 JACKAL TAPES.Jackal tapes are the ramblings of the arms dealer you are sent to kill. The Jackal is the main villain. These tapes are the only way you can get inside his head and see why he behaves the way he does...and you can't get them all in the current state of the game. This is a pretty big part of the story that just goes missing, especially because those last few tapes reveal a lot about the character (because the majority of the game doesn't tell you anything story related). How do I know that? Because I looked them up on YouTube, the only way to listen to them all now.The game crashes constantly with DX10.Use DX9.Enemies and supplies respawn after they go out of draw distance.Go too far away and come back, and they'll all be there again. Not only is this annoying when you're trying to get somewhere that involves backtracking, but it makes you feel like nothing you do matters. It just wastes your time.Enemies know exactly where you are the instant you miss.Good luck trying to take out a base without save-scumming. The instant you miss one bullet, they all know your exact location and start closing in and shooting even if you used a silent weapon like the dart gun. This is a glaring flaw because you have to plan your attacks on every set of enemies. They can very quickly overwhelm, flank, and kill you on higher difficulties so you must try to take out as many as possible from range. Don't even think about turning down the difficulty, because...Enemies are stupid.Even if you crank the difficulty up, which gives the AI the ability to flank you and such, they'll still do some really dumb stuff. I once blew up a barrel from a distance and the AI decided the best way to investigate the situation was to gather around it. About 6 guys just grouped up and I shot them one at a time. They never took cover, just spun around looking for me. On easier difficulties they'll "run" up to you, stare at you for a few seconds, then fire. They seem to have overreacted to far cry 1 difficulty complaints.Cell tower and arms dealer side missions are always the same.There is absolutely no variety in any of these. The cell towers have you assassinate one guy always dressed in a suit with a desert eagle in random heavily guarded areas. Sometimes he's in a car. Sometimes he's in a cease-fire zone. The arms dealer missions are EXACTLY the same: it's always blow up a truck with a technical in front and behind it driving in a convoluted circle on one of the 9 map squares. Always. There is no creativity whatsoever, and it's pure padding.Most of your time will be spent driving.Almost every mission will have you travel across the whole map repeatedly, and because of respawning enemy camps this can take forever. Good luck driving through an outpost because the AI will get in their cars, cheat by going faster than you can to catch up to you, and blast you away. The only time you can "drive" past an outpost is when you go full speed in a swamp boat, the AI doesn't seem to notice/catch up in those cases. There are 5 "fast" travel points across the 9 map squares in an X shape, but that's not enough and normally you still have to do a good bit of driving to and from them. Driving in-and-of-itself is annoying as well because...Vehicles have horrible behavior.They struggle to go over the smallest of obstacles and handle like arcade racers. If you manage to get your vehicle stuck on a 6 inch flat rock or in a dried up river bed while it's upright you can't push it off, you just have to abandon it. But if you drive your open top vehicle off a 50 foot cliff and it ends up sideways or upside down after bouncing around a few times (not damaging your health at all) you can just go to one side and spam the use key to flip it upright. All of this is very immersion breaking.The vehicle repair animation is stupid.I realize you can't expect them to put in a completely realistic fixing animation where you rebuild the engine or something, but at least have some variety. All you do is put a socket wrench on one nut and twist it for a few seconds. That's it. For every vehicle. If you get a repair manual, you twist faster, but only for that specific vehicle that the repair manual was for. Apparently buggies, ATV's, trucks, technicals, and even Jeep(TM)(R)(C)'s all have a magical nut that will instantly repair a vehicle to factory conditions when twisted. Who knew?There are no civilians outside.There is no friendly/neutral AI except the almost stationary buddies. This situation only makes sense at the very end of the game due to the story, but for practically the entire time there is no reason for it. Every single person outside is armed and dangerous. Every story mission you are an under cover operative and both sides will shoot you on sight unless you are in a cease-fire zone.There are infinitely spawning mobs and clairvoyant AI in Cease-fire zones.If you shoot anybody in a cease-fire zone, every single AI in that zone will (1) know your exact location and (2) infinitely respawn as hostile until you leave the zone and run a bit further, then you can immediately come back and they won't care. This hostile behavior happens even if nobody saw you take the shot with a silent weapon. Very immersion breaking.Weapon durability only applies to you.I get why durability is in the game, it makes sense to have a weapon degrade over time. An enemy's weapon never jams when he wields them. However, the instant he dies his weapon becomes utter♥♥♥♥♥♥and will jam like crazy until it explodes in your hands three reloads later. Some of the weapon design/behavior is horrible.The two that stand out the most to me are the MGL (that revolver like grenade launcher) and the dart gun. Now I don't know too much about guns, but I do know that the MGL (1) Has 6 grenade slots and (2) reloads like a revolver. It doesn't have 4 grenade slots in a magazine style reload system. This reload animation is just insulting. As for the dart gun, apparently it's hard to carry more than 10 darts the size of bullets. What is the point of having a silenced sniper rifle if you can only use it 10 times before you need to find ammo. Not to mention the gun has the worst reliability and on easy can break before you even run out of ammo. Wut?!I'd go on but I'm out of space. DON'T BUY THIS GAME!

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is one of the best shooters of all time. Like any good story, it's loosely inspired by Heart of Darkness. And believe you me, the story, barebones as it might seem (no traditional cutscene until the very very end), is shocking and incredible. Trust no one, shoot everything that moves, you will be friendlier with your ingame buddies than your real life ones, all that good vidyagamey stuff.Far Cry 2 avoids many of the flaws of its successor - a game I would best describe as Robinson Crusoe for somebody who wants a power trip. Not knocking its many successes (the animal system, etc), but many RPGs make the mistake of letting the player get away with pretty much anything in the lategame. Far Cry 2 is not an RPG. You will make decisions, but you're not in search of XP: you're in search of a better chance at survival, and if you're feeling lucky, maybe you'll try to keep your buddies alive too.Far Cry 2 is an experience.I chose to disable the crosshair because muh immersion (note the presence of ironsights makes that decision slightly less punishing compared to, say half-life) and I highly recommend you do the same as well, because this game, despite having questionable graphics from the mid-2000s, works best when you're immersed and twitchy and prepared mentally for the worst.Far Cry 2 gives you nothing. You have to earn every buddy, hoard every high quality weapon you own, build your reputation with the factions brick by brick. Regardless of your choice of APR or UFLL - pick your own lesser of two evils - your greatest enemy is the jungle itself. Your guns will jam and even break (usually when you need them most), the harsh terrain and many, many faction guard posts means that even a trip between two safehouses a mile apart must be planned and taken with the utmost caution, and don't even get me started on malaria. If you play Far Cry 2, prepare to be challenged.Far Cry 2 is a first person shooter that does not encourage combat. Even one soldier is a very valid threat of death. You do have a safety net in the form of your buddies, but don't rely on it. It's almost always better to detour around or sneak past a guard post than to plow through it. Stealth is encouraged but not rewarded - you can stealth kill, but guards will almost always scream out upon death, meaning that a kill threatens you more than helps you. Even carrying a sniper rifle at all times (highly recommended) and engaging from a great distance carries great risk, from multiple guards jumping in jeep and running and gunning you down, or mortar strikes, or a random patrol invalidating 90% of your hard work. Recommendation? Be ready to move, always keep your health high, and your life is worth more than anything else, even (especially?) the mission.Far Cry 2 will not leave you in the same place you began it. Many (most?) video games place you as the most important person in the world and give you all the tools to your success. This is not a power fantasy. This isn't even an underdog fantasy. This is hard work, and any reward will be in your head alone. You will be beaten down and beaten up, but if you beat the game, you will genuinely feel accomplishment and success unlike any game out there.

Posted: March 21
												If you're the type who plays Far Cry for the map editor like me, then Far Cry 2 is by far the best. Unlike the later games, Far cry 3 and 4, Far Cry 2 offers unlimited map editor possibilities. You can do almost anything you please just as long as it's within the maps limitations. I've seen maps players created that were replicas of Grove street from GTA: San Andreas, The Deathstar from starwars and Megaton from Fallout 3. Not to mention, the story is also really good. It's a little short compared to the others however. Ubisoft butchered the map editor to the ground in the later games. The limitations were so great that I lost interest in the games. Far Cry 3 has an amazing story, I give it that, but the story wasn't all that the players loved about the game. Unfortunately, Ubisoft didn't understand that as some of you know.

content:
Posted: April 2
												Far cry 2 is like the dark souls of the far cry games. It's a game about getting from point a to b not exploring or ticking off all the open world optional stuff like far cry 3 and 4. The game really shines at the harder difficulties Hardcore and up.   PROS- -very interesting mechanics like: --- malaria.(the lower the malaria level you have the longer you can sprint) --- weapon degradation.(weapons break or jam which makes the gameplay tension --- fire affected by wind(removed in future far cry games; no longer are fires affected by wind or grass type). --- wounding an enemy to set up as bait for other enemies. --- cars break down a lot more than far cry 3 and 4. --- buddy system allows a way to cheat death. --- shooting ammo crates causes shrapnel to occur killing people around it.   -graphics although dated a bit looks pretty good still.  -realism is much greater in this game any of the future titles.  -the story is pretty good, P.S your not a hero in this game, in this game everyone is horrible including yourself.  CONS-  -the response time of checkpoints or locations are ridiculous short. Avoid the checkpoints and find routes through the rough ground (makes the game way more fun), you are also rewarded in game for doing this (with diamonds or tapes and sometimes guns)  - buggy phone calls, sometimes the dialog during phone calls doesn't play which sucks.  -no animal hunting or threats like in far cry 3 and 4,   -ending buddy story also kinda sucks.   Buy it on sale

content:
Posted: January 3
												"I was hoping to get some BBQ and some cold icy beers at Mike's Bar...and after maybe some buffet at the weapons store to load up on some lead and explosives." This was the thought that ran in my head as I play Far Cry 2.  In some ways as I relate to the story, I felt sorry for the world particularly with imagery thoughts on all the refugees and children homeless and sickness as the game starts, BUT unfortunately it didn't do a really good job in showing just how serious and bad the world has become.  It seems like you yourself is suffering from Malaria while all the NPCs and people you meet not one is suffering from malaria.  Also there are no refugees wondering about or getting shot at or threatened by mercenaries, no brutal executions or things that people see in wars on TV in the game.    The game is great and it plays well, BUT its too quiet...in between missions and fighting against enemy guard posts or driving around the land, there's nothing else except looking for diamonds. The control mechanisms are well done and the weapons really are AWESOME.  Especially the weapons degradation JAMMING! During gun fights I was always forced to swap from my assault rifle to my weak♥♥♥♥♥Makarov pistol as my rifle jammed in the middle of run and gun, and I became desperately looking for a stronger weapon....and there it was, an assault Jeep! GET ON THE GUN!   It was great because it was in these moments where you were put to make snap decisions, you run? or your going to fight them with a pistol?  OH and the Malaria kicks in just in time...with enemies come after you with full firepower...Run ♥♥♥♥♥ Run!   But no worries, when you ran out of health and knowing your going to die, your buddy shows up! Shooting down enemies as he drags away saving your♥♥♥♥♥ I'm pumped to get up again and ♥♥♥♥ some♥♥♥♥♥♥up once more!  However, later in the game you realize, your buddy...Is he or she really your buddy!?   It's really easy to relate and immerse into the game because the world is so familiar we may have seen it in war movies and how refugees are migrating and escaping from wars etc...I just hope that it could've have done just a little bit more with putting in interactive NPCs like helping some refugee families, rescuing civilians from oppression by random mercenaries, and then you can earn your own reputation by your deeds which could effect how the story of the game could see you as good or bad.   I really do hope that Ubisoft can remake the game...however that is impossible..because I'm sure that if they remake this game again, it'll be great with all the new stuff added like NPCs and the total expansion that gives a more feel to what war torn Africa is like, would be another added treat along with titles like Far Cry 3 or Far Cry 4.

content:
Posted: January 16
												In Far Cry 2's chaotic world of mercenaries, gunrunners, and armed militias, you'll find yourself dropped into a dizzying web of shady clients and paper-thin alliances. All manner of names and faces are introduced during the course of the storyline, but the real star isn't anyone brandishing a smuggled weapon in search of blood diamonds; it's the daunting and awe-inspiring 50-square kilometers of African landscape that make up the game's open-world setting. Aside from providing the opportunity to soak up an amazing sunset, Far Cry 2's free-roaming terrain brilliantly harmonizes with the first-person combat. The diverse landscape and myriad environmental factors work alongside a wide assortment of weaponry to give you tremendous freedom to approach each mission. Combined with solid multiplayer, Far Cry 2's sheer breadth of action provides you with plenty of reason to stay lost in the African wilderness despite an underwhelming plot and the occasional sense of tedium in navigating from one location to another on the gargantuan map.Far Cry 2 is quite the looker.Far Cry 2 is quite the looker.Far Cry 2's story is filled with potential. You're a mercenary working for a client who's sent you to an unnamed African nation engulfed in civil war, and your job is to take out a notorious arms dealer known as "The Jackal." He quickly proves to be an elusive figure, so you'll need to begin working for various warring factions that the Jackal has armed so you can trace the supply line back to your target. The two primary organizations at the heart of all this bloodshed are the militaristic UFLL and the revolutionary APR. You'll spend the bulk of the story working for these two groups, getting to know their power structures, and taking on all of the violent tasks they throw your way. Complicating things is the fact that your character has malaria, which means you'll need to occasionally play nice with the more ragtag Underground, the only group with the medical connections necessary to keep your potentially life-threatening symptoms at bay.Each story mission can be played in multiple ways. There are 12 potential buddies randomly scattered throughout the storyline who you can befriend (nine of whom are available to choose as your silent protagonist), and they're often keen to tack on their own interests to the quests handed out by the UFLL and APR. Instead of just taking out a target, you have the option to earn extra reputation points by working alongside your buddy to first squeeze any remaining assets from the soon-to-be-deceased. This also earns you the ability to increase your level of companionship with that buddy. It's a neat reward, but it doesn't shed much light on their backgrounds. But that's par for the course; the main story is delivered in such a rushed, quick-and-dirty way that you never feel very involved in the game's overarching conflicts. The plot is less Blood Diamond than it is early Grand Theft Auto, a long roster of changing faces that scroll by far too quickly to capitalize on the politically charged setting.Although disappointing for a single-player campaign that could easily drain more than 30 hours of your time, any shortcomings in the plot are mostly forgivable thanks to Far Cry 2's overall structure. The game is organized in a way that provides a daunting amount of freedom to explore, earn currency, and wreak havoc on the game's landscape and its denizens. It's all laid out in a manner typical of sandbox action games. Pulling out your map reveals a collection of icons that signify available missions and points of interest that you can meander toward at your own leisure. Among these are dozens of side missions that you can take on, with various forms of rewards. Delivering transit papers to trapped refugees earns you malaria medication, destroying rival convoys for gun merchants unlocks new weapons for purchase, and performing assassinations for mysterious voices at the other end of your cell phone rewards you with diamonds. You can also rough up militias stationed in small camps and turn their dwellings into your own safe houses. The side missions can feel a bit repetitive when played through in rapid succession, but they offer a great change of tempo when sprinkled throughout the main narrative. But what's most clever is how their differing rewards intermingle so wonderfully with your needs in progressing through the story: Malaria pills keep your HP and stamina up, diamonds buy you new weapons and ability upgrades, and safe houses provide temporary shelter to stock up and save your game.With so much ground to cover, you'll be spending a lot of time driving, boating, running, and swimming.With so much ground to cover, you'll be spending a lot of time driving, boating, running, and swimming.The freedom of choice that goes with selecting which mission you want to perform carries over to how you execute them, and that's where Far Cry 2 really shines. There are a variety of factors that affect the way you approach each mission, from the number of people you need to kill, to the landscape, to the weather and time of day. If your job is to take out a key figure hidden deep within a militia camp in the jungle, you'll do well to take a nap at your safe house until nightfall and silently stalk your prey under the cover of darkness. If it's a windy day and you need to take out a bandit outpost in the dry plains, you can start a fire from far away with a flare gun and let the breeze and arid conditions collude to spread the flames toward their camp, finishing off the survivors with a sniper rifle. Need to clear out a bunch of scattered guards? Why not shoot an oil drum near an ammo stockpile and watch as the bullets erupt in every direction like deadly pieces of popcorn? Of course, you can also get up close and personal with pistols and machine guns, but the moments in which elaborately planned assaults succeed are some of the most gratifying points in the game. The whole process of staging an attack only becomes more intricate and rewarding as you slowly upgrade your safe house into a full-blown armory and unlock new weapon and vehicle abilities--all done through the gun shops.Overall, Far Cry 2 is a game in which you can quite literally get lost for hours at a time. But that feeling of exploration is precisely what makes the game so much fun; your creativity never feels stifled when approaching a mission, and the game's overall structure of side tasks, friends, rewards, and upgrades is a diverse ecosystem rivaling the landscape itself. No matter whether you're a PC fan whose played through the similarly structured Crysis or a console owner new to the world of open-ended first-person shooters, you won't be disappointed by Far Cry 2.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is an open world FPS where you play as a merc hunting down "The Jackal"; a notorious arms dealer that has armed two warring factions (APR and UFLL) in an Unnamed African Country (UAC).In terms of gameplay, you will spend most of your time doing the following: -Driving through the jungle, savannah, desert, and rural town settings of the UAC. -Shooting, exploding, burning, or sniping your way through hostile outposts, infrastructure buildings taken over by enemies, and the roads of the UAC. -Looking for diamond cases.-Completing main missions for both the APR and the UFLL; (kill this guy, destroy this outpost, destroy part of the UAC’s infrastructure) and side missions that include buddy missions (kill this guy, blow up this structure, retrieve this object) , underground missions (give these passports to these refugees to get Malaria pills) gun runner missions(blow up this weapons convoy), and assassinations (kill random guy in suit and his bodyguards). These are all the mission varieties you will ever have.I listed driving first because you will be doing it A LOT in this game. There are only four fast travel points (bus stations) per section of the map (two sections); and most of your missions will force you to drive even if you take a bus to be closer to your destination. Unfortunately, driving in Far Cry 2 is hampered tremendously by two things: enemy patrols and the overall terrain. You can't go for even 4 minutes of driving without some patrol truck hunting you down. It gets worse at the second act of the game, when they get heavy mounted MGs and even one hit kill grenade launchers. Your vehicle will get stuck all the time in small holes in the ground, rocks, tree roots, small trees, other cars, etc. At least there’s a wide and believable variety of vehicles to choose from, ranging from trucks, ATVs, actual Jeeps, and even a buggy. The shooting in this game can be immensely satisfying. You can either go in guns blazing with machine guns, snipe from afar, use a mortar to thin out enemy positions, burn them with a flamethrower, or blow them up with RPGs. Stealth is supposedly an option, but the game isn’t really built for it since shooting even with silenced weapons alerts all the enemies in the vicinity.There are a lot of weapons to choose from, including assault rifles, pistols, machine pistols, LMGs, RPGs, sniper rifles, grenade launchers, etc. Experimenting with these will be your main incentive to obtain more diamonds, which will allow you to buy more of these weapons and their respective accuracy and reliability upgrades. Weapon jams and explosions are a feature of the game. The longer you use a weapon, the more prone it is to jam and eventually explode, and since all enemies use worn out weapons, buying from the arms dealer with your diamonds is a must.The combat AI in this game is well designed for the most part. Wound an enemy and his ally will come to his aid, allowing you to kill them both. Enemies will shoot towards your last known location, and if you’re no longer there, you can flank and shoot them with ease. The AI feels dynamic and believable, but it is relentless. If you’re spotted by an enemy patrol they will chase you, even on foot, and shoot you until you take them out. It can be quite overwhelming to face more than five of them at a time, because the foliage will prevent you from shooting back properly. Now, this game has several underdeveloped ideas that all aim towards a more “realistic” experience, but only interrupt gameplay and annoy the player. The worst offender by far is Malaria. You will need Malaria pills to treat your symptoms for every 40 minutes of real time. If your Malaria goes untreated, you will faint and magically reappear at the nearest main city. It breaks the flow of gameplay during exploration and missions. Were it not for Malaria, you wouldn’t even touch the Underground missions.You can repair any damage to your vehicles, (from explosions to machinegun fire) by tightening a single socket in the engine. Buying the vehicle’s manual (10-20 diamonds per manual), allows you to tighten the socket faster, but there are no changes in the animations or in the way you repair vehicles. Overall, it’s much simpler to find a new vehicle instead of stopping every 5 minutes to repair. In terms of player progression and overall changes in the game world, this game is quite lacking. When completing main missions,none of the factions will care that you recently murdered their leaders and hundreds of their comrades. Your missions are supposed to be “top secret” which supposedly explains why every outpost and soldier wants you dead even if you’re doing missions for their faction. But really, it’s too obvious that the developers simply didn’t code friendly AI for the soldiers. You will destroy a lot of the country’s infrastructure: the train tracks, the morphine production centers, the Malaria pill shacks, the WATER PIPELINES, the diamond mines, etc. You can visit these places again and see the destruction firsthand, but the amount and types of enemies, the amount of drinking water, diamonds, Malaria pills and the way to obtain them, will pretty much remain the same. Your efforts to support either faction end up feeling pointless.The same happens with buddy missions. You can have two buddies: One for upgrading the many safehouses throughout the UAC, and one that can come to your rescue if you get fatally wounded. You earn points by doing additional mission objectives for your buddy, or doing buddy missions, which is really pointless considering that a “level 3 buddy” will give you all the same benefits as a “level 15 buddy”.  You never learn anything new from their stories, which are summed up in two or three sentences at most. Hunting for diamond cases can be a lot of fun, but some of them seem to be impossible to reach. Nowadays it can be regarded as a way to pad out game length, but I found entertaining.*SPOILERS* The story in this game won’t pick up until the second act. You will support the equally tyrannical and selfish APR and UFLL because you’re looking for information about the whereabouts of the Jackal. But your character never really tries to learn where the Jackal is, and your employers never tell you anything. You will NEVER hunt down the Jackal, and by the third time you see him, you will be working with him. It just feels nonsensical because of all the people and infrastructure you will destroy for killing a single guy who probably caused less death and destruction than you did. The game justifies this change of heart by presenting the Jackal as a “humanist” who is tired of the war and wants to save the civilians, but it all feels forced. The developers need to be given credit for how gorgeous the game looks even for 2016 standards, and the style that they chose for the game. The game runs smoothly and beautifully on modern rigs, and asides from a few AI glitches, everything looks, sounds, and feels as if you were in an actual African jungle, savannah, or desert. Structures, vehicles and weapons look used, broken down, barely functional, worn out. It really adds to the immersion in a spectacular way. The way you can create dynamic bushfires in this game is amazing and a viable strategy in the drier regions of the map.Despite all all of its problems, inconsistencies, glitches, and underdeveloped ideas, this game can be a lot of fun. It took me a while to complecomplete my first playthrough on Infamous difficulty, along with all the side missions, almost all of the diamond cases, and all the weapon and vehicle upgrades. All the while, I was having a blast on the combat segments; even if the driving wasn’t so smooth and game progression was non-existent. I can safely recommend this game to anyone remotely interested in open world or FPS games, just know that this ride can get a bit bumpy.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												It took every part of my being to push through and finally see Far Cry 2 to the end. This is because it's not only mentally exhausting, but emotionally as well.Let's get what it doesn't do well out of the way, because it doesn't do a lot of♥♥♥♥♥♥well. There's all sorts of fun things that people hate like weapon degredation, the malaria mechanic which gives you a vomit-tinged screen until you press H and pop a refreshing malaria-fighting Certs into your mouth, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ open world which is full of repetitive quests that revolve around shooting the other soldiers of fortune you're working alongside of, or shooting a man in a suit, or blowing up a truck that's driving around in circles. It's really, really ♥♥♥♥ing grindy too. The secondary missions don't offer much more than just your stupid mercenary friend calling you up in the middle of your mission to ask you to do something so he can be a bigger, more amoral ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for dollars than you can. All it is is you being an unpleasant little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for money to other unpleasant little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s also here for money. Are you still with me? Good. Because it turns out that this game has so many flaws it has essentially developed Three Stooges Syndrome, the syndrome where it has lots of bad ideas yet they all don't end up killing the game, but rather strengthening it.All of the things up there would normally have killed my interest in this game really ♥♥♥♥ing dead. And they did the last two times I tried to play it, all the way back in 2010. But today, the game clicks for me. I don't know whether it was the depressed state I was in or whether I've realized that AAA video game design has been so design-by-committee that this was the thing I ended up dying for. This game ended up satisfying something I wasn't aware that I needed than, say, Grand Theft Auto 5 or Saints Row the Third, which are just straight-up celebrations of how awesome you are. Far Cry 2 tells you to your face that you're just another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in a jungle with a barely functioning weapon, and that you won't matter if you live or die.But also at this point in time, the mental state of your mind also is very, very helpful when getting into this game. In order to actually sit down and play it, you must learn to accept the environment that the game is forcing you into. Everything is♥♥♥♥♥♥ War is constant. The missions suck. Nothing really works. You are accepting missions in order to make like worse for everybody. Your guns get dirty really fast. You're trading rough diamonds for all the guns you can get your hands on. Absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥♥in buggies and jeeps and cars will drive off the road to try and run you down for no other reason than you are there, and you are a target, and everyone hates you. Everyone hates you here in Africa, and if it means that you will die so that there's one less target to shoot, you're gonna get shot. The work is absolutely repetitive, the fast travel system is the worst, and if you lose your car because some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s blew it up because they were trying to shoot you while you were using your car for cover, you're gonna have to hoof it. You are a person in a♥♥♥♥♥♥tornado. And the♥♥♥♥♥♥tornado has everyone you know and love in it. And you all can't stop ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ into the♥♥♥♥♥♥tornado. And because you all can't stop ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, the♥♥♥♥♥♥gets into your eyes and mouth and face and you're swearing bloody revenge on the people who keep involuntarily ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ into the♥♥♥♥♥♥tornado, and soon you're all at each others throats while your lives become nothing but♥♥♥♥♥♥and tornadoes and blood and broken teeth.That's what it's like to play Far Cry 2. I don't recommend it for everyone. Hell, I don't know who I can recommend it for. It's a great game because it evokes that experience and keeps it consistent up to the end, but it's such an unpleasant experience that I'm surprised it got published at all.Besides, didn't Spec Ops the Line do this sort of thing, but within ten hours?

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												What's best about Far Cry 2?The true answer is that there is no one thing that can be considered best about Far Cry 2. Its brilliance lies in the fact that it is more than the sum of its already impressive parts. Essentially the game is a playground that caters for whatever mood players find themselves in. Want to storm into an enemy encampment in broad daylight John Rambo style, perhaps running a few unfortunate soldiers down with a MG-mounted Jeep before letting loose with your grenade launcher? Go ahead. Prefer to fast-forward the incredible day/night cycle to midnight by taking a nap in one of the Safe Houses and sneak in under the cover of darkness before slicing and dicing from behind with your machete? Be the game's guest.Ubisoft Montreal isn't, of course, the first developer to do open world shooting.But it is so well executed, so technically proficient that I can't help but feel it at least matches and in some areas even surpasses other games of the genre.After choosing from a selection of nine refreshingly un-clichéd mercenaries, ranging from a 45-year-old Mauritian to a 38-year-old Algerian you're thrust into an unnamed African country being torn apart by two warring factions.Your mission: To kill The Jackal, an arms dealer who's fuelling both sides of the conflict with weapons, and making a mint as a result. You immediately run into problems - malaria wraps its diseased mitts around your innards, forcing you to collapse as soon as you arrive in town. You wake, groggily, and find The Jackal standing ominously above you. He knows everything - who you are, why you're here and how defenceless you've become as a result of the malaria. In pity, he hands you a machete and a hand gun, and lets you live. This is where Far Cry 2 kicks off.Outside, all hell breaks loose. The United Front for Liberation and Labour (UFLL) and the Alliance for Popular Resistance (APR) are going at it in the streets. You make a break for it, dodging bullets as you head anywhere as long as it's away from certain death. But there is no escape - either you're shot or you collapse from the malaria. You wake in a slaughter house just outside town. A merc, one that you did not pick to play as at the beginning of the game but is determined by that choice, now reckons you owe him a few favours on account of him saving your♥♥♥♥♥ From there, it's up to you what jobs you take on, whether it be paid work from the UFLL or APR, malaria pill jobs from various good Samaritans, weapon vendor jobs that unlock new purchasable gear, buddy jobs that improve your 'history' with the NPC mercs or assassination jobs dished out by a disguised voice heard from communication masts. What they all have in common, however, is combat, and it's here that Far Cry 2 initially frustrates.I'm used to developers holding my hands so tightly during game tutorials, and even beyond, that Far Cry 2 will at first jar with many due to the fact that it's actually pretty tough right from the start. Simply shooting stuff is difficult. Unlike the console versions, the PC version doesn't have a snap to target function when you zoom down the barrel of your gun. This is fine - the PC keyboard and mouse set up allows for a degree of FPS accuracy console controllers simply can't. But this doesn't stop your weapons, especially at the beginning of the game, from being, frankly, crap.You'll find the recoil offensive, the jamming so regular you'll tear your hair out and the enemies so hard to spot in your splendid surroundings that it won't be long before you grab a mouthful of dirt. The healing system doesn't help. Whenever your health dips you can inject yourself with magic hit point juice. That's fine, but when your health bar is almost depleted healing will instead trigger an animation where you gruesomely pick bullets out of the holes in your skin. The problem is that this animation, which takes about five seconds to complete, is interruptible by enemy fire. Some will applaud Ubisoft Montreal's approach. Some will criticise it. Whatever your opinion, persevere. Soldier through the difficult opening few hours, keep earning diamonds, keep reducing the recoil and reliability of your weapons with upgrades, and above all, keep experimenting, because it's only through experimentation that you'll realise Far Cry 2's undoubted potential.The save system differs from the console versions in that you can save absolutely anywhere and whenever you want. There are no checkpoints in Far Cry 2, at least not in the traditional sense of the term. Instead, you'll get a pop-up asking you if you want to save after you complete mission objectives, when you use the coach transportation system or when you go to sleep using one of the Safe Houses. The many guarded checkpoints will annoy some, but for others they will reinforce the feeling that you're never safe. Because the map is so big, you'll spend a lot of your time driving around. If you're going to stick to the road, you're going to run into at least three checkpoints along the way. Every soldier manning the checkpoints has a shoot first, ask questions later policy, too, making driving more a case of survival than sight seeing. The enemies respawn, too, so you can never once and for all clear enemies from that check point on that road you keep using to get to and from town.Obviously if you're a shooter fan you should buy this game. A simple glance at the score should confirm in your mind, if there was ever any doubt, that Far Cry 2 is nothing but brilliant.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												This is a fantastic game with one of the best environments and gameplay I have ever experienced. Despite this, I have heard so many complaints and gripes about this fine title. Many jump into this open world game expecting the many side missons of FC3, or the hand holding of many modern FPS games, and complain when FC2 does not accomidate them. Many also whine when the story does not cater to their ideals and makes them make hard, immoral, decisions. "The story is crap," they say "The ending made me feel bad." I've also heard many complain that playing as an often heartless merc made them feel uncomfortable. How can that be bad? If a game can provoke an emotional response like that, then it has done a fine job. I have heard people, in the same breath, complain about the fast respawn time for enemy outposts breaking immersion, then say that the method of quick travel (finding a bus to take you to another bus stop after a loading screem) isn't easy enough to access and traveling is a pain. I say false to both statements, especially since they contradict each other. Having a world full of hostile entities makes you prepare for such encouters, and also refills the world with more enemies to fight, something that I feel FC3 lacked after you cleared out outposts. As for having to drive for awhile for any mission, I never could go more than a minute without something exploding, cathcing fire, or shooting at me. With all of this being said, I do acknowledge that this game is not for everyone. Since it does NOT hold your hand in, and instead is fairly abrasive, be it via malaria attack, a lucky mortar strike, or a jamming gun, it likely doesn't appeal to anyone who is looking for some mindless fun/action a la Metal Gear Rising or FC3. This game is rough, and can be frusterating at times, but because of these same qualities, I love this game for not being afraid of trying something different. As a result, I have never played another FPS that has gotten my heart rate up so much everytime an enemy appeared.Play it, try it, but DON'T expect FC2 to hand you anything.
