content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												TL;DR ... for all its faults, FC2 is a "summer popcorn movie" video game that's enjoyable if you just switch your brain off and go with the flow.~~~~~~~~~~~BackgroundFC2 came out when "open world" and "50+ hours of gameplay" started becoming buzzwords on games. It comes from the generation of games that were more focused on creating massive playing areas, then didn't have enough time to pad them with actual game play.So, they slapped in a bunch of repetetive, cookie-cutter missions, scavenger hunts and enemy AI that's stupid but makes up for it by being programmed to cheat.I got this game when it first came out, b/c I had just built a new dual-core rig (when dual-cores had just come out), and wanted to see what it could do by playing Crysis, Far Cry 2, and other games of the time. Picked it up again during steam summer sale, and the good and bad come rushing back.To pro/con it, I have to break it down by components, since each component has pro/con.~~~~~~~~~~~PLOTPro: it tries to delve into some deeper aspects about moralityCon: It gets pretty pretentious and self-righteous for it's own good. It's hard to follow as you're thrown right into the middle of confusion without much explanation, and even your journal and cut-scene tip text doesn't help much. But, overall, you're not missing much. You're basically a lackey for everyone, so switch your brain off and ignore thinking.~~~~~~~~~~~NPC'sPro: there's large varieties of themCon: They were trying to cut-down on file size, so it seems they sped up everyone's dialogue after recording it. Everyone talks super-fast, which makes it difficult to follow, especially ones that have accents.~~~~~~~~~~~ALLIESPro: you get a "buddy" that can help revive you out in the fieldCon: it feels like what they wanted to do was let you have an AI NPC follow you on missions like a side-kick. Instead, they were rushed for time, couldn't implement that, so instead they just implement some half-a**ed cutscene with a buddy helping you out, then acting completely stupid in fire fights as they die from either standing out in the middle of now where, getting caught in a brush fire like an idiot, etc, etc. Basically, to enjoy the game, just think of your Allies as nothign more then quest givers, and ignore any aspect of them "participating" with you...because you will feel it is very lackluster if you do think of them as a "companion".~~~~~~~~~~~MISSIONSPro: there's lots of themCon: they're all the same cookie-cutter design ... go here, kill everything, collect this. I don't mind that so much (again, we're switching our brains off to enjoy this). What bothers me is you can only have 1 quest at a time. And the quest giver and the actual quest are usually on opposite sides of the massive map. So, you get a quest, spend half an hour getting there, complete it in 5 minutes, then spend another half hour getting back to the quest giver. While out and about, you will see other quest opportunities. You can't take them, or they will cancel your current quest. This is beyond dumb. For a map of this size, they should let you gather quests, then take care of all of them at once when in the area of operation.~~~~~~~~~~~ENEMIESPro: there's a variety of enemy dress and faces, plus they use guns you can useCon: the enemy AI is a bipolar mess of smart and dumb. You sniper a guy, and some will take cover while others try to investigate. Some will flank you and surprise you, but you realize they can only do this because their footsteps have been purposefully made extra quiet so you don't hear them. So, it feels cheap when they ambush you. The ones taking cover behind buildings won't come out. You can sneak around and pick them off with a sniper from a distance and they stay in duck-n-cover formation. I literally looked over a cliff. Saw two guys hiding. I shot one. The other guy didn't do anything. He just saw his buddy die, but he keeps hiding there. I shoot him, too. *facepalm* The devs purposefully made the AI cheat to give them a competitive advantage to challenge you. They will use their amazing eagle eyes to spot you through foliage and cover then chase or snipe you even though they are nothing but a dot in your sniper scope. Their clothes blend into the color pallette of the game, so it's hard to detect them. They will make next to no noise while walking through brush looking for you even though you sound like a herd of elephants while crouch-sneaking. When the game first came out (before patches) they were even able to run 50mph to catch up to you if you were driving through a checkpoiint without engaging them (thankfully that seems to have been fixed). But, basically... don't expect super impressive AI.~~~~~~~~~~~GUNPLAYPro: FC2 let's you load out with a primary, secondary and support weapon. This is pretty ingenious, because it lets you tailor your load out to your play style and/or mission.Con: I usually consider myself good at FPS (grew up on Doom and Quake), but FC2 has been brutal in run-n-gun play style. The PC is slow, can't sprint very far or fast, and likes to stop moving to do lots of activities (eg: malaria kicks in... better stop in the middle of this street while getting shot to take a pill instead of letting the player make me keep walking while doing so). Machine guns are jump as all get out, but sniper rifles have completely perfect, stationary zoom making head shots from a mile easy. Standing 10' away from a guy, you will watch as you can't hit him point-blank... unless you bring up your iron sights to target. You get a silenced sniper rifle (dart rifle), but it's not considered a primary weapon and is severely hobbled on ammo. There's just all these baffling design decisions.~~~~~~~~~~~WORLDPro: it's largeCon: everything is the same color pallete of "browns and greens that easily blend into each other". The world is so large that it takes half an hour to get to your mission site. There are so many mountains that all driving feels like "corridor" driving in that you rarely have very open areas to zoom through. Plus, when there are, there are so many trees and rocks in the way you can't really go too fast. There doesn't seem to be any permanancy in the world, too. You take a car from a place. Come back later... the car is there again, reset, as if it was never taken. And nobody gets upset over you taking vehicles. There are "checkpoints" throughout the place where enemies hang out and make it hard to pass through. You clear one out. Come back 5 minutes later...it's repopulated again like nothing happened! This makes you feel as if your actions are pointless / worthless, and dissuades you from clearing places out. (ie: you would have incentive to clear a place out if it stayed cleared out, but since it respawns 5 seconds later, you start to just avoid conflicts by going out of your way to go around those places since they just become time wasters). Diamonds are used as currency to buy new weapons, and they spread HUNDREDS of these suit cases to go scavenger hunt all over the place to pad the game with "game play" that isn't really compelling game play.~~~~~~~~~~~Did I mention you need to switch your brain off?There's a lot "wrong" with the game, but it is what it is due to the open-world fantacism + huge push for better graphics that was all the rage back then (and still sort of is).Overall, I still recommend the game, because it's entertaining going on missions and clearing places out. Sitting on a rock sniping people, pulling out a grenade launcher and blowing up vehicles with occupants still in them, tossing a moltov and lighting up a bunch of grass to burn people to death... it's mind-numbing fun.The game is best if you fire it up, spend an hour running a mission, then turning it off for a bit.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Let me start by saying that this open-world FPS isn't for everyone. I started playing this game years ago, and i finally finished it only a couple weeks ago. This is partly because of the massiveness of the game, and partly because of the repetitive nature of it. One review i read of this game said it's the game that "doesn't give you what you want, and slaps you for asking". This is very true, the game presents many obstacles (guns that deteriorate and jam, malaria that makes you have to take medicine at any given point in the game, lack of ammo & resources, etc.) and doesn't have a single auto save. Every save is manual. Every. One. Fast travel is hardly any faster than driving across the giant map, because you can only travel to and from one of 5 fast travel stations on the map. And let me tell you, vehicles in this game do NOT go fast.This giant stew of inconveniences is what gives this game it's value. The setting is Africa, a wasteland containing only violence, disease, and scarcity. By making the player endure these frustrations, Far Cry 2 gives every convenience you recieve a kind of personal importance. The regular attacks from enemies beat you down until you become a proud killing machine. The slow and dangerous nature of transportation in this open world gives you a familiarity with the map, and maybe (what happened in my case) an unprecedented respect for the design. The story plays a passive role in this game (kill things, get payed, get closer to completing your main mission), but it fits into the violent & depressing theme. The ending, however, is fantastic. This game is slow. The combat is relentless and routine. You have to struggle to complete each mission, and the characters are all shallow. By stripping away all the usual comforts you would expect to find, Far Cry 2 does something extraordinary. It puts you outside of your comfort zone. You're alone in this troublesome world, and you have to discover for yourself how to make it out alive.

												This game is all about the gunplay and I do mean ALL about the gunplay. The missions and the dialouge are highly repetitive and it's only made worse by the long travel times between objectives interspersed with infinitely respawning enemies who make the long travel times even longer by shooting up your car. And don't get me started on the story, mainly because there barely isn't any. It got to be that I started playing it as an RPG, creating my own character and motivations but at the end of the game you're only given two choices on what to do, neither of which fit the character I had created, basically nullifying my whole experience.The game has its problems but the gunplay is its great redeemer and in this case it's enough.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												You are dropped in a war-torn african country, you have one mission. Kill the man that has been arming both sides. The gameplay is simpley amazing. The gun-play is next level and the environment gives you a feeling that the country is in horrible conditions and help is a far cry away. The most complaints i hear about FC2 is the weapon jamming and outpost, but for me it makes it more real. The outposts makes you strategicaly move from point to point and the jamming can ruin a firefight for you. It all makes it more difficult to survive, and instead of holding your hand all the time the game lets you approch how you want to. There are a lot of unlockables, weapons and uppgrades to let you play how you want to. Either run-n-gun or ninja style, and it does this well. Lots of games offer this, But FC2 manages this in a terrific way. The only complain i have is that the missions are very similar, little variety. But the different playstyles is enough to keep things fresh.All in all i would say this is one of the best games i have ever played. It is almost 8 years old, but is a though competitor for even the newest games.Im giving this 8/10 bacon strips.

												Far Cry 2 is the most epic Far Cry game I have ever played the story for this game is just amazing it really keeps you hooked in the open world just blew me away there is so many things you can do after you have finished the game and really we don't get much FPS open world games and I would say Far Cry is probably one of the best FPS open world games out there. This really is a huge improvement over the first Far Cry being the first FC game to have openworld it really has developed a lot of new features that the first Far Cry didn't have. FC2's multiplayer you can invite your friends to join you but watch your back as you never know who your true friends are and who might betray you! All the single player technical features are also present in multiplayer mode. In Far Cry 2 you have a chance to explore a war torn African state and you are forced to make deals with corrupt warlords on both sides of the conflict this game's story really keeps people entertained and makes them not want to stop playing it is just an amazing story. They have changed the gameplay features of Far Cry 2 so unlike the first FC game there will be a lot of things that are different about the game and with the Fortune's pack DLC you can get access to new vehicles and weapons that are not in the game unless you bought the Far Cry 2 Fortune's Edition. Overall I give this game a 10/10 it is just a fantastic game to have in your collection and I think this game is definitely worth the money. So I suggest you go and get this game bros I am sure it will not disappoint you in anyway at all!.

Far Cry 2 is one of a kind experience and although is quite criticized by fans of the franchise I find it to be one of the most underrated games I have seen.50km2 of awesomness	Set on Africa, you take the role of a mercenary who finds himself in a middle of a war. The Government has been dismantled and there are now two factions trying to take control over it. Your goal is simple: kill the Jackal, an infamous drug dealer who benefits from the war selling guns to both factions.	In order to do so, you must shot your way to the Jackal. You can ally with both or just one faction which makes for a non-linear story; something really appreciated for those who value replay-ability.	Powered by Dunia Engine, the visuals are really well done and you will find yourself on savannas and desserts within a effectively designed world. The engine does a good job improving the stealth aspect thanks to day/night cycles that actually varies the way the IA work as well as includying dynamic fire propagation on the grass along others. Inmersive and awesome to explore	As the franchise got as accustomed, the world is filled with cars, trucks, hang gliders, boats and ATV's. Throughout the story, you will need to take pills that help you to control your malaria. Oh, yeah! You got malaria at the very beginning of the story. Failing to take said pills (which runs out really fast) will make you pass out and you will have to restart the mission again.	There is not a big selection of guns on this one though. I have to note also just how minimalistic and inmersive the interface on this game is. You don't check the map by a popup window in front of the actual gameplay but rather, your character holds an actual map wherever you need it and so on with a lot of elements on the game. Those are little details I love to find given they improve the impression that you are really there.It definitely has its problems, though	I hope you like driving, because oh boy, you are going to drive a lot. Not that it gets incredibly tedious. During your driving you will find enemies along the way which helps keeping things interesting. However, you are still going to drive a lot.	Likewise, to be considered a realistic game it's surprising how long it takes to kill enemies. Not everyday you see a regular person wearing nothing but a t-shirt get shot six times on the chest and still count the story, but enemies on Far Cry 2 sure can. Nevertheless, it works both ways considering you can walk to an enemy from a good distance while he is shooting directly at you and still kill him with a machete. The story is great, with interesting dialogues and memorable quotes but I really could never put my heands on the multiplayer, something about Ubisoft's servers not responding when I tried to sing up. I have never heard of it being shut down but to be honest I haven't bothered to look up much on the subject. Multiplayer was just a feature in this game, singleplayer is where the fun part is at.Playing this game on the Hardcore or Infamous difficulty mode makes it so much enjoyable, really. Because you can't get shot nearly as much as Normal you start making better strategies than just show up with your car in the middle of your enemy's base and start shooting everywhere like you were blind-folded. So, should you buy it? You're damn right you should. Far Cry 2 has to be one of the most enjoyable shooters I have ever played. An awesome game about exploring, surviving and killing so you can get a sweet, sweet revenge on everything the Jackal has put you and others through. Oh, and also, about driving. A hella lot of it. Let's also take a moment to appreciate the fact that this was (and probably will) be the last Far Cry without uPlay DRM. Anyway, despite all the flaws (which aren't that many, really) Far Cry 2 is well worthy of your money.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Cabela's African Adventure 2 is a thrilling joyride to the heart of the African soul and spirit of hunting through the eyes of a mute foreigner who has come to visit his old pal Steve Rambo, who has started a new life as a hunting instructor and a Nietzche fanatic. As you, the noble white man, enter the country, the atmosphere instantly contracts you with Malaria and you have to face the ultimate test of survival to find your old pal Steve Rambo. In the game you hunt the most dangerous prey of all, Malaria pills. In the process you must cope with the locals who are  actually all foreigners too, but all the locals have left, so does that make the foreigners the locals? This is one of the mysteries the game gives you, the story keeps you guessing as you do work for two guys who hang out with foreigners all the time. Bill and Ted give you folders of diamonds instantly transferred to your International Diamond Account and order you to blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up, giving you the dough whether you actually go to complete the task or not. They also warn that their men will also shoot you because it's that much of a black op, but aren't they all foreigners as well? Both the UFLL (United Females Lottery League) and APR (American Punk Rockers) mercenaries look the same, so how can they tell eachother apart? See, this is the level of deep story and imagery the game gives you. Overall Cabela's African Adventure 2 is a fantastic game about learning medical perscription, maintaining vehicles and dealing with the explosive tourism that plagues the country.

Posted: September 3, 2014
												 Far Cry 2: Fortune's Edition is in my opinion a very fun game set in an unnamed country in africa were you get to choose a pre-created character out of a list and go to kill a Arms dealer called 'The Jackel' who is arming both sides.The game is open world game with differnet types of African terrain and you can travel by foot, boat and Car. The is also the fact that over time you will need to take malaria pills so you dont die and do missions to get more, Also guns in the game will slowly worse in condition and you will need to find a new one or go to a gun shop using the game's currency of Diamonds which can be found in the game world as well.10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Where to start with this game, it's definitely a step up from far cry 1 and I would put it quite close to or slightly better than far cry 3. First I would like to add that it's a cool feature having guns rust and jam after a while. The terrain is very accurate to what Africa is, with both desert and jungle filling the maps. Very good graphics. It's interesting how you can choose your character with the only affect is that you don't appear as an npc in the game.One of the problems I had with the game is that the story stretches out too long so I end up forgeting what im supposed to be doing in the first place. Enemies can also appear out off nowhere and kill you, sending you back to the last save (which happens alot when your on the hardest difficulty). I'm also a bit disappointed that none of the animals tried to kill you, we're in Africa aren't we?The main problems with the game is the fast travel system because the only fast travel you have is the five bus stops in each of the corners and centre. The more you quick save the harder it is to load the game manually. (Unless you delete them which I forgot to do). The AI is sometimes dumb and occasional fires through walls. I loved this game, but it is not for the inpatient. 8/10

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												ONE OF THE BEST FAR CRY'S TO DATE AND THE BEGINNING OF THE OPEN-WORLD FANTASY THAT IS  THE FAR CRY SERIES.  Not too heavy on story more for the explorer, but not too much depth where you lose yourself in the side-elements of the game,  you get back on track pretty quickly and the missions are challenging but dying in firefights is pretty lame, until you gain a few comrades' who pick you up instead of having to re-do your assault missions.  This one doesn't take much from the first Far Cry except the high expectations in graphics and gunplay is more refined in this one.  The Feature of guns wearing after a bit really adds nothing to the game...cept tragedy in the middle of a fight.  There really isn't anything groundbreaking or gamebreaking in this one, a light frills ride through the Exotic African flatlands and forests' and the desterts...One of the best game in the series, has the longest play value, but yet is nothing that you haven't seen before in an open world.  I Had fun with this one.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												My take on the game:+ Big map that is separated into two regions connected by a stripe of desert + very good sound not only for guns but also other things (superior to FC3)+ good AI (will flank you, try to drive over you with cars, mortar shell you from a distance, ...)+ Much to do (with anonymous murder contracts, two warrying factions that both are your contractors as well as enemies, ...)+ road blocks and military posts make sure you'll be occupied when travelling between places+ Unusual story+ public transport as the only way to fast travel (and structured in a way that makes you value it)+ "buddies" offer alternative ways to complete missions+ kinda good collectables (like very rare golden AK-47, interview recordings with your main villain, ...)+ Guns realistic with old guns jamming and breaking often, ...+ Very good (fire-) physics and dynamic things (at least three times everything FC3 and 4 did / achieved...)- map is cluttered in a way that often seems to artificially, unneccessarily stretch routes so it takes longer to get from one point of the map to the other- missions and targets are often placed literary as far away from you as possible (like: you very often have to travel from one corner of the map to the other...)- there are sounds for animals that are not actually in the game as entities (you'll be hearing lions and so on but only encounter zebras and gnus...)- AI trying to drive you over can be very annoying if you haven't saved in a while (it also sometimes makes some sounds cars make glitch out)- some guns and some enemies are configured in a way that makes late-game enemies bullet sponges which will fall to the ground but then continue to 'last stand' against you with a pistol.- Main Story takes an incredibly long breather between beginning and end, distracting you with the sub-story of the two warrying factions; also takes a rogue turn during the last mission / with the last mission.------------------------------------------------------------Zu Deutsch:Was ich vom Game halte:+ Grosse Karte die in zwei Regionen unterteilt ist, die durch einen streifen Wüste verbunden sind+ Sehr gute Geräusche nicht nur bei den Waffen aber auch anderswo (besser als bei FC3)+ Gute KI (Flankiert einen, versucht dich mit Autos zu überfahren, bombardiert einen mit Mörserbeschuss von weitem, ...)+ Es gibt viel zu tun (mit anonymen Mordaufträgen, zwei kriegstreibende Fraktionen die beide sowohl Auftraggeber als auch Gegner sind, ...)+ Strassenblockadenund militärposten stellen sicher, dass man während dem Reisen beschäftigt bleibt+ Unübliche Geschichte+ Öffentliche Verkehrsmittel / ÖV ist der einzige Schnellreise Weg (und so aufgebaut, dass man es wertschätzt)+ "Komparsen" bieten alternative Wege Missionen zu machen+ Gute Sammelgegenstände (wie sehr rare goldene Ak-47, interview Tonbänder mit dem Bösewicht, ...)+ Waffen realistisch indem alte / gebrauchte Waffen schneller klemmen und verschleissen, ...+ Sehr gute (Feuer-) Physik und dynamische Dinge (mind. dreimal mehr als was FC3 oder 4 erreicht...)- Karte ist so vollgestopft, dass es einem so vorkommt als seien Wege künstlich, unnötig in die Länge gezogen worden - Missionen und Missionsziele sind meistens so weit von einender Weg wie möglich plaziert (man muss oft von einem Kartenecken in den gegenüberliegenden...)- Viele Tiere die man als Geräusch hören kann sind nicht wirklich im Game (Man hört etwa Löwen, trifft aber nur Zebras und Gnu's an...)- Dass die KI einen immer überfahren will kann bei längerem nicht-speichern nerven (und sorgt ebenfalls dafür, dass die Fahrzeug Geräusche glitchen)- Einige Waffen und Gegner sind so Konfigueriert, dass sie im Endspiel Kugelschwämme werden welche zu Boden fallen und dann noch mit der Pistole weiterkämpfen- Hauptgeschichte nimmt sich eine sehr lange Auszeit zwischen Anfang und Ende des Games und man wird mit der Geschichte zwischen den beiden Fraktionen abgelenkt; Die Hauptgeschichte nimmt in, mit bzw. bei der Letzten Mission reisaus...

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												Finally got around to playing this game. The only reason i never finished it before is because I was annoyed with the malaria aspect but it turns out only to be a minor annoyance in the game. I finished Far Cry 3 before finishing Far Cry 2, although I started playing it years ago. I always knew I would come back to it and I am glad I finally did. I won't do any comparison to the original FarCry because that is entirely a different game, in my opinion.I found FC3 far too easy, being able to track your opponents, even through trees and rocks nerfed the difficulty enough, and getting special superpowers as you level up only made it worse. In FC2, you have malaria, which is like, the opposite of a superpower and became a hazard if you started having an "attack" in the middle of battle. And also, you have weapon jams which happen randomly as your weapon wears down. A weapon jam might sound annoying but it is a little detail in the game that adds a little realism and extra challenge to the game which I can appreciate. Your "buddys" are randomly chosen from your character choices from the beginning of the game, each with their own look and dialog.  You also have the chance to get incapacitated instead of dying, getting revived by a buddy for a second chance to finish the fight. if you go down too soon after though, it is game over. When you are low on health and apply first aid, the animations go from wrapping up a wound on your arm to pulling a bullet out of your flesh with a knife and plyers. Another way it differs from FC3 is your character is not the focus of the game story whatsoever. The story is really about the Jackal, the factions and Africa, and you are just someone who is in the right place at the wrong time. You do get to choose a character, which only effects how your hands and arms look in the gameAll these little details make a very unique first person shooter experience, and I think really smart game devs can learn from playing this oneIn the end, the only real problem I had with FC2 was not the malaria, but the fact that I couldnt use a custom loadout. Every weapon falled under primary, secondary or special and you could only carry one of each. Meaning I could not use a sniper rifle and an SMG at the same time as they were both considered primary weapons.The good far outweighs the bad though, and if you are jaded with your regular FPS experience, give this one a try.-edit- 2 years after this reviewI'm convinced this was one of Ubisoft's last good games. Also, it doesnt require uplay.

Posted: June 9, 2016
												a must-have for any Far Cry/ Hardcore FPS Fan.Be thrown into an unnamed war torn African Country, as you try to find an arms dealer known as the "Jackal" but as luck would have it you get stricken by the infamous Malaria, and have to fight to survive on the outside while fighting an invader from the inside.as you will come across, the guns in FC2 are like real guns that will jam and eventually break. and you must be careful not to come across these problems in a firefight. these are Cold War/late Colonial era weapons and their age shows. when you first get these weapons from other arms dealer, they will be in pristine condition but eventually as you use them they will wear and tear, and become less and less reliable.P.S. if you get Far Cry 2 run it on the DX9 version, the Dx10 version has a bug that will without warning crash to desktop. Ubisoft never fixed this, so run on dx9 for optimal performance.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												  Hi everyone! Go to my profile to check out some of my helpful reviews!  Far Cry 2 is honestly the most realistic game I've ever played. Imagine Insurgency with missions and a good storyline. Mainly, all you have to do is start out fighting for one client, and from there you collect more, in which you get more missions, in which you get more resources.  The map is a greatly sized one compared to other games'. You have a map and a GPS to always use, that directs you to certain missions. Many of these are made to let the player use his/her own style, such as stealth, agressive, defence, or just plain old sniper from a long distance. The system of the stealth is mostly featuring missions like save the hostage, kill all the men without having a specific one notice, or taking/stealing a certain object smoothly. I, for example, on the hostage mission, enjoy going in, silent as possible, not being detected, killing some guards without the others noticing, and then saving the hostage. Then I shoot everthing.    The graphics are fantastic, as well as the multiplayer function, though my favorite is single player. The gameplay is tricky and fun at the same time, as well as the enemies (AI Units) are actually intelligent! This suprised me, when I tried to headshot one, missed, and they ran in different directions, to good cover, and one behind the hostage.    Also, the cars and planes are very well made. It is so realistic! No crosshairs in the game, no big texts on the top, but it just looks like you are looking from a first person view in real life. Another neat feature is the diamond GPS, where you can detect where hidden diamonds are and use them to trade for weaponry and other important goods that will need to be used to survive. My favorite part is that...

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												Before reviewing this amazing game, I decided to play it for quite a while. As of the time I am writing this, I have two hours. Most of my reviews haven't been helpful, and I really want this one to help people geniunely decide if this is a game they want to invest in or not. Let's start off with the basics. Intro So you start up the game, and click new game. There are 9 characters to choose from, each from different nationalities with different voices, buddies (which I will go into detail of later), and ages. All the characters are male, though. Difficulty Levels There are 4 difficulty levels. Easy, Normal, Hard, And Infamous. On to the next thing.. Unscripted Player-Driven Events! Unfortunately for modern gaming, this is something most new games lack. Far Cry 2 is great for this kind of thing. Something I Found on IGNMarty dragged me out of the line of fire and into the bushes when a random group of guys jumped me on the road. Stupid. You never take the road. A gunner on the back of a truck mowed me down while I fell into my own misplaced Molotov flames. Marty hands me a pistol and opens fire. I find a couple grenades, knock the truck around, and finish the job. When it’s all done, I hear Marty screaming for help. I can’t see him.By the time I find his blue smoke streaming out of the woods, he’s grunting incoherently. I kneel down, jab a regenerative needle into his stomach, and wait for him to head home. He doesn’t get up. He’s still wounded, so I put another needle in him. Nothing, but he slows down, and his eyes roll upward. One more needle. Marty’s head hits the ground, and he stops squirming.I overdosed my best friend.Something that happened to me in game (Not IGN)When I was playing Far Cry 2, I was crouched behind a car. I fired off a few shots at a guy, and he was killed. I realised something; I was wounded! As my health was rapidly pouring away, I quickly healed myself, but while I was doing that, my car exploded and fell on me. Instant death.On to gameplay and stuff! Gameplay The gameplay is quite hard. If you are a newcomer and download the RealMode mod and play on Infamous difficulty for the first run of the game? You will die. A lot. You might die even without the mod. This game is BLOODY HARD AS ****.  Pick up a enemy weapon? Well prepare for it to be unreliable as hell. Snipers explode in your arms without any notice, guns jam, deal less damage... Recoil is a whole different thing. With weapons you purchase at the gun shops, they will do more damage, accuracy, etc. They also have a permanent "good" condition. However, firearms you "borrow" from your dead enemies, are quite the opposite; With inferior range, accuracy, and damage.  Wrap Up & Conclusion This game has its pros and cons..PROS- Amazing openworld experience- Great fun- Is pretty old and still looks amazing- Supports mods- Player driven eventsCONS- wtf is a con there is none buy this gameAll in all... BUY THIS DAMN GAME RIGHT NOW

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												After many hours of stabbing my way through Farcrys 3 and 4, i was overall pleased with the changes made to the gameplay in those titles. Smoother, polished gameplay and greatly enhanced driving is what i enjoyed most about 3 and 4. They are great games, but they also felt like fantasy stories at times. That is why Farcry 2, in my opinion, shines above them.Gritty combat in a dark war torn nation is part of why this game is still the best in the series. Everything just feels so real. If one of your buddies die, tough♥♥♥♥♥♥ he/she is gone forever. Malaria and jammed weapons make this game even more unforgiving. Shooting up an enemy checkpoint to steal their ammo and meds is also a little unsettling when you later see a guy on the ground, bleeding and screaming about how he wants to go home, but he can olny watch as you come crouch next to him and put a bullet in his head. The setting and feel is perfect, and the gameplay follows suit.Simply put, Farcry 2 is a game that requires strategy and patience, which is a great change of pace from the usual FPS realm. An interesting variety of weapons and a storyline that holds more than meets the eye make this game one of a kind. Replay value is very high, considering the unpredictability of the AI, the enviroment, and also how you choose to approach each mission. A satisfiying one man army experience is felt when played on hardcore or infamous difficulty. Ignite the conflict. Make them fear you. 9/10--To get the most out of this game and bring it to its true potential, i HIGHLY recommend installing Dylan's realism mod and sproyd's enhanced graphics mod, both of which are easy to install and can be found at moddb.com--

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Far Cry 2 heavily expands the appealing, basic formula established in Far Cry 1. I would call it the first modern Far Cry game since most of the hallmark Far Cry features come into their own in this title. The core of a Far Cry/Crysis game is fast paced, streamlined, semi-realistic, immersive first person military shooter in large open environments where the player is free to explore multiple approaches (stealth, close range assault, sniping, explosives, vehicles, turrets, or any combination thereof) to overcoming enemies. Far Cry 2 also introduces a large open-world, non-linear mission system with multiple factions, weapon and equipment unlocks, safe houses and buddy companion-system. The central african environments are breathtaking and the game takes great pains to immerse the player in the environment. The HUD is incredibly minimal with most actions and situations being context sensitive and told through actual interaction with the environment. For example, rather than healing being simply invisible (the health bar just refills), you'll see your character inject a syrette in his/her forearm, reset a broken limb, or pull a bullet from a gaping wound in their leg. The map just doesn't appear on the HUD, you actually pull a physical map and GPS out. When your character suffers the affects of malaria, you're vision will blur and turn green and you'll have to pull out a pill bottle and swallow a pill to counter-act the effects. All these things effectively serve to immerse the player in the world, but don't inhibit gameplay. The enemy AI is also very sophisticated and will communicate with one another, actively hunt for you and attempt to surround you (or where they think you are), or even get scared and take cover or run. My primary grievance is that random encounters when traveling can be a bit to frequent and bypassing frequent road blocks and guard posts can get to be a grinding chore in traveling around the map.The mission system that unveils the story is fun and engrossing. The story is not just handed to you, but the player will have to really pay attention if they want to figure out what is really going on. The interplay of the factions, the player, and their buddies is fascinating and keeps the game fresh from start to finish. The side missions do get a bit redundant though, which include destroy arm shipments, and assassinations. Luckily, the core Far Cry gun play is solid and doesn't get old quickly. It is fun when a situation goes from you getting a jump on a bunch of enemies to reinforcements showing up and surrounding you as you run short on ammo and having to fight for your life to break the encirclement and make a run for it. Which brings me to the buddy system which is rich and unrivaled in any FPS/RPG that I have seen. The system is rather organic and you really seem to build a relationship and history with your buddies who are fellow mercenaries try to profit in this little civil war.All in all, there are few games I can safely recommend as must plays for anyone, but this is definitely one of them.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												UbiSoft knows how to make games. The Far Cry series is no exception; in fact, it's probably the best series they've made so far. Far Cry one was good, for its time, but I didn't play it until recently. Didn't quite finish it, because the ending boss fight was a little too difficult. FC3 was the first I played of the series, and it was outstandingly fun. Yeah, it was a little too action-y, but man, did it have a good story and addicting gameplay.Then came FC2. WOW! Can't say enough about how good this game is. Love the Africa setting, love the environment you have to survive in, love the weapons, love the challenges, love the gameplay, and that desperate feeling that you're alone in a foreign country and you're trying to survive, and just barely doing it. My Top 5 favorites of all time keeps changing, and this one just jumped in there with the Batman Arkham games, Alan Wake, and the Metros to take its place among the greatest of all time. And I consider FC3 to be right in there too, along with Blood Dragon, as kissin' cousins. ;-)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												AUDIO: The voice acting in this game is iffy. The Jackal probably has the best voice actor in the game because he actually sounds interesting to listen to. Everyone else sounds bored out of their mind to be talking and they are speeding through their dialogue at maximum speed. The soundtrack is mostly just bongos and drums and the like, mostly for menus and fighting and stuff. Not bad.VISUALS:This game hits the extremes of good and bad graphics sometimes. For example, the graphics look freaking wicked when the sun rises or is in the sky. It's a beautiful sun, one of the best I've seen and it makes everything look spectacular. In contrast, the game is very brown and dark green without the sun rays. It can get pretty dull to look at sometimes, but maybe that's what they were going for. PLAYABILITY: Since the game is open world, it gives you freedom to tackle your objectives how you want. It also gives you more than one way to carry out your objective. The guns are all pretty nice and all of them work well, which lets you develop a favorite. The malaria isn't really a problem. I don't care what everyone else says, I never once had a problem with malaria. It gets repetitive having to travel sometimes though, and hunting for diamonds can get super boring, especially considering that they are currency in this game and you kind of need them.DELIVERY:My playtime was the amount of time needed to 100% this game. That being said, it's large. However, 100%'ing this is very dull. The missions are mostly the same thing over and over; assassinate a target, collect a briefcase, etc. The strongest point of this game would be the buddies. I found myself growing attached to the buddies I got and it made the game much more enjoyable. SUMMARY:Don't spend all your time collecting those damn diamonds unless you REALLY want to 100% this. Take the main missions, the buddy missions, and carry out your goals however you want. Make your own choices and don't think too much. It's not a bad game by any means.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												For start offs this game Far Cry 2 is good value for money, especcially on sale. I clocked over 54 hours on it and there still side missions available or buddy missions. This Game seemed to get a lot of bad press when it came out and in a way thats a reason i avoided it until a month ago. This bad press was unfair in my view, theres a good game in there if you give it a chance. The gunplay is quite good with the added feature of your guns jamming through aging or general abuse, no other game has that feature i have ever seen. This feature actually adds to a firefight when you are in the middle of one in the adrenaline rush to get your gun back up and running. The graphics for a 2008 game are reallly good too and the African countryside of Savannah, desert and jungle are spectacular looking. This open world feature is one of the games strongpoints. I didnt have any real complaints about the game other than mercenary checkpoints do respawn after you clear them out but its no real issue. The Dialogue in the game can go very fast sometimes too.This is an underrated game and for the price is definitley good value.

Posted: January 11
												If you love open world, mission based FPS then you will love Far Cry 2. It is worth every penny especially if you bought this on sale. The game itself is challenging because of the enemy AI. I recommend newbies to unlock Dragunov or AS50 as soon as possible by completing side quest missions. Fighting at a distance and preparation is the key in this game because no matter how powerful your shotgun or assault rifle is, you will get slaughtered by the AI. They love to flank and hide behind bushes and walls. The game is very realistic so it doesn't have an enemy indicator like most games which makes the enemies hard to see in jungle and grassy settings. Don't expect the game to make it easy for you just because you are a beginner.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is set in a large, beautifully crafted rendition of the African wilderness.  It includes very satisfying gunplay and it allows the tactical use of fire in skirmishes - set the savannah ablaze or lob a molotov cocktail to flush your enemy out of cover with realistically modelled fire propagation!  The fire and explosion mechanics are great and the weapons have a good feel to them.  Enemy AI is generally pretty good - they will search for you and respond to stimuli in a realistic manner.  Annoyingly (because it is so obviously incongruous that it breaks immersion), the distinctive black and white character voices often seem to be assigned to minor NPCs of the opposite race.  The wheeled vehicles don't handle anywhere nearly as well as the weapons, but thanks to the beautiful world design, exploring the wilds by track or river is still enjoyable, at least at first.  As the game goes on, the driving becomes a bit of a chore (realism sucks sometimes).  I found travelling by boat to be more immersive and enjoyable - they certainly seemed to handle more realistically than the wheeled vehicles.You play as a mercenary tasked with killing an unscrupulous arms dealer that is supplying both sides of a civil conflict with cheap weapons.  Given your role and mission, you take a fairly detached approach to the civil conflict.  For most of the game, the story was of some interest, but I did not find it particularly gripping.  At times, it felt like little more than an excuse for various assassination and destruction missions, although they were thrilling enough to keep me motivated to do all the requisite driving.  Approaching the end of the game, however, the story became substantially more interesting to me, as a new perspective on the conflict was revealed.There is quite a wide variety of weapons available, although I found myself using only a couple of favourites most of the time.  The world is massive and lovingly detailed.  With multiple African biomes, dynamic weather and wind that affects both vegetation and fire behaviour, it really is a wonderful place to explore.  The excellent gunplay is icing on the cake.By far the most realistic of the Far Cry series, with destructible environment and weapon degradation (including jamming), I found Far Cry 2 to be a challenging and enjoyable game.  The spawning of enemies at checkpoints was annoying at times and I would have liked an option for even more realistic damage levels (people don't often patch themselves up and fight on after being shot with an AK-47).  Although playing this way would have been a very difficult proposition, I think that it would have driven the use of different, more realistic tactics.  With such solid fundamentals, Far Cry 2 had potential to eclipse S.T.A.L.K.E.R. - Shadow of Chernobyl as my favourite First-Person Shooter game ever made, had it been more mod-friendly.  Sadly, Ubisoft had other ideas.  Nevertheless, even as it approaches a decade after release, Far Cry 2 remains a great open world FPS.  I strongly recommend trying it f you like open world games and planning your gunplay engagements from stealth.  The world is gorgeous, the gunplay satisfying, and I think it's worth playing just for the realistic fire and destruction effects.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2013
												What sets this apart from other shooters is the overall theme. Everything feels honest and real, from the syrettes and the malaria to the politics and ultimately the narrative. Without spoiling anything, I'll say your mission from the beginning is to take out an arms dealer, but as you get acquainted with other characters it becomes something much more. No matter which character you play as, you aren't a hero — you're not even a remotely good guy. As the story progresses you will come to terms with that fact, and how you deal with it is entirely up to you. By the end this game delivers a very powerful message. I really like the open world and how missions can be completed in many different ways, both by teaming up with the NPC buddies (optional) and also by learning the enemies' realisitc AI. Enemies react differently based on the weather, time of day, which weapons you're using, etc. It's a really deep system if you want to learn all the ins and outs. Otherwise just play it like any other game and it's still fun. There's a lot of variety in the landscape: jungles, plains, mountains, deserts, etc. There's also a lot of detail: Blades of grass part realistically when you sneak through fields. Hang gliders are a great way to travel and provide some amazing scenic views along the way. The Act 2 map is just as large as the Act 1 map, which I thought was already large enough for the entire game to take place in. That was a really great surprise. The Fortune's DLC adds a lot of new side missions to complete whenever you want to work on them, which add a lot of lore to what's going on in the war torn country. It also adds a little ATV which is by far the fastest means of getting around, and a crossbow which shoots incendiary arrows that explode on impact. Overall I thoroughly enjoyed every hour of Far Cry 2. I found it to be much more immersive than the first game. It still looks great today, and now that Far Cry 3 is out the price is really low!

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												There are three kinds of enemies that can kill you in this game: malaria (doesn't really kill you, but will knock you out cold if a symptom attack catches you without the much needed pills), blood-thirsty mercenaries just like yourself (who duke it out supporting dubious causes for a hefty payment in blood diamonds), and the CoD-ey, impatient, quicktime-event-trained, short-attention-span mentality you WILL have when you first boot up Far Cry 2. All the past years, games in the likes of Call of Duty, Medal of Honor et al. have all created a FPS playerbase with a tremendously short focus of attention, a shocking lack of thinking and planning tactics, and a complete disregard of taking your mind off the shootybanging going on in the foreground, in order to soak in the atmosphere in the background. Far Cry 2 is, apart from a solid shooter, a magnificent atmospheric game, full of engrossing ambience and breathtaking vistas that will provide with a cheap vacation alternative to sub-Saharan Africa, albeit in a much more hostile environment than you would ever wish for. The nature that surrounds you can be both an ally and an enemy if you don't treat it properly, as a vantage point you used meticulously to pick off guards in a distant outpost can become a death trap at any moment, should a raging wildfire cut off any escape routes. Propagating bushfire mechanics can be harnessed to cause chaos and mayhem to enemy positions, but can also uncontrollably harm your character as well. Getting from point A to point B in this game can seem tedious at first, as you will have to walk or drive to wherever you need to be, but as you get more and more used to the feel of the adventure, you will discover alternate routes, shortcuts and safe zones to better facilitate your travelling needs.Don't expect fauna to be a threat, or to have any intelligence. Grazing herbivores are all you are ever going to see, and zebras tend to one-bump-one-kill themselves on your car, even if you are fully stopped. A full time-of-day cycle and dynamic weather effects will paint a much more convincing picture of your surroundings as you comb through the map length- and widthwise.TL;DR- An incredible experience worth the price of admission, it is a must that you should not overlook, especially since it goes dirt-cheap on sales more often than you would change underwear.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Far Cry 2 has nothing in common with its predecessor other than the huge open world that characterised the first game, as well. In fact, the first episode was rather linear (practically, each level was a different island) whereas here you can go wherever you want. There are two maps with an enormous amount of territory to be covered. Just look at the pictures posted on the store page to see how beautiful and varied these areas are. As already stated, the game is beautiful. The jungles, the rain, the burning grass and trees (pyromaniacs will love it) once you obtain a flamethrower. It is just gorgeous! Too bad the story does not hold anything special in it. You complete missions for two competing factions that try to rule the area. If I'm mistaken this is all fictional and there's not even a mention as to which African country you are in.The game is very difficult. Even on a normal difficulty enemies you pass by in a vehicle can shoot you from a distance - I'm amazed how precise shots they have each time. If you go through a single outpost it is almost impossible to do that without being hit by the enemies. Another issue is how the enemies in these outposts throughout the game get respawned for no apparent reason. Mission destination points are usually deliberately placed to the farthest place on the map making sure you need to go through at least a couple of outposts along the way. This is bad as the game is prolonged due to some unnecessary, repetitive actions. Still, overall, this is a good game. It is entertaining and you can have some really funny moments during the combat with enemies. If you are not familiar with the franchise, however, I think the best is to choose the 3rd episode which is a more refined version of the Far Cry experience.

content:
Posted: April 18
												I reccomend this one with a bit of hesitation. Simply because the game has something incredibly annoying for every thing that you find incredibly awesome. Perhaps even more bad than good. I played this originally on the PS3, so this isn't my first time playing.Good Things:- Intense gunfights- Satisfying kills- Good weapon selection that can affect how you play- Lots of content- Fire spreads in a realistic and cool way- Shooting feels better on PC in comparison to the PS3 version (which probably isn't surprising)Bad Things:- Annoying AI- A massive but boring map that forces you to spend 85% of the game driving around- Brutally annoying "guard posts" that make the driving across the map immensely annoying and send out enemies in vehicles with guns that shoot at you and you can't escape because they rubberband to you so badly, and even after you kill them you have to sit and spend 20 seconds fixing your cars engine- Buddy system feels useless and just forces you to watch your buddy carry you for 45 seconds when you get to 0% health as opposed to just giving you a game over screen and letting you restart in 10 seconds- The rusty weapons system that affects not only EVERY enemy weapon you pick up but even your own weapons after a while- Alternate objectives for every mission that do nothing but give you an extra gunfight or two and extend the amount of time it takes for you to complete a mission by 20 minutes simply because you have to drive around more, not to mention they act like these objectives help you complete the main mission but do nothing other than something like including your stupid AI partner to "help" you kill people- Your character has malaria and that does nothing but annoy you- Enemies can take way more damage than they shouldI mean, just look at how big my issues with the game are in comparison to the things I liked. It's worth a few dollars when it's on sale, because you might have a good experience, but don't expect to avoid being annoyed out of your mind at times. It seems like a lot of people consider this one of those underrated gems that people didn't click with when it came out, and I kinda see that, but jesus is this thing riddled with flaws.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Far Cry 2 throws the player into the wild African savannah where you have to fend for yourself. No one is there to hold your hand, and the world offers limitless opportunities. Problem is, you have caught malaria and you are in the middle of a civil war. As a mercenary, you offer your services to the various warlords as you drift ever closer into the dangerous conflict.If you enjoyed the first Far Cry, you will probably find Far Cry 2 quite enjoyable as well. While not related story-wise, the game offers a similar tone in gameplay. The game gives you the freedom to roam a massive world set in Africa. And there is no doubt in saying that the world is gorgeous, yet this is also where one of the most fundamental flaws lies. The world is sparsely populated; there are no massive cities, villages, or interesting locations to visit in the game. The world mainly consists of outposts with 100% goon density. This shallow attention to detail is what makes Far Cry 2 quite repetitive once you hit the 10 hour mark. An impressive addition to Far Cry 2 is the durability of weapons. Unlike most FPS games, the weapons in Far Cry 2 can jam or completely break in the middle of a fight. This makes pre-mission planning much more fun as it promotes the idea of checking the weapon state. Yet this “realism” that Far Cry 2 so heavily promotes can be a pain at times. Your character contracts malaria early in the game, and forces you to do boring side-missions to acquire 1-4 pills. Depending on how long you play, you may have to do quite a few of those malaria quests. It is also bothersome as symptoms may show up in the middle of a firefight.As for story, Far Cry 2 follows in the footsteps of the first Far Cry in that it doesn’t provide an interesting plot at all. The characters are poorly voiced and uninteresting, the plot never really develops, and you could care less what is happening around you. It becomes quite apparent after a few hours that the budget went straight into developing the world and not the story or its characters. At times, you may feel extremely lonely in this intimidating setting.Overall, if you like a sandbox playstyle with goons who will make life hell for you as you try to traverse the African terrains, then this game should be plenty of fun. Even if you don’t plan to play the main mission, go raid some outposts. I found it quite entertaining. Score: 7/10

Anyways, there's my review. This is Farcry 2. Welcome to Africa.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												I played this game when it came out and I must say that although I was very impressed with the game at first, it soon became boring and repetitive.The mission structure is very similar-basically go and blow something up or free somebody etc.Characters are shallow and not interesting.The world seems kind of empty with nothing much to do than destroying camps and dealing with very annoying armored jeeps that follow you when you pass by.Now 5 years later I bought a new powerful graphic card,found some great mods and decided to give it another go.I must say that I'm very pleased with the game.What this game gives you is very unique experience and that is enough to cover all it's flaws.This game made me realise what I've long forgotten.It's that not everything has to be action packed,flashy story,indepth customization of everything,points,cover system....It's just simple and beautiful.It makes you appreciate the time spent just roaming the wilderness with nothing on your screen to destract you from beautiful world around you.Total immersion.We need to stop with consuming games like an always hungry fat kid and appreciate the atmosphere and experience.You will often feel alone and kind of lost in this great world,which coupled with an amazing weather system,beautiful graphics and fitting background music makes the experience very unique.Sometimes it feels like a dream to me.Like you never really know what is going on but you just exist,just to watch that beautiful sunset.It gives you time for thinking between action parts.And action is great and the whole weapon system is designed very well.From buying,upgrading to the shooting mechanics and wearing out including great jamming system and animations.The arsenal is also pretty big with plenty to choose from.The other thing that shines is AI.Although they can act like idiots at times mostly they are smart and they will very often surprise you and flank you.They will also detect you quickly even if you just peak out behind cover to take a quick look.Just like IRL,they are not blind like in other games (Hitman:Absolution for eg) and there is no "detection meter".If they see you, they see you.Your best bet for sneaking is to attack by night wearing stealth suit and even then it will not be easy,because if you are too close they will hear louder sounds such as bumping in objects or reloading etc. and come to investigate.GREAT STEALTH GAME right there.Using quick save and quick load is much recommended.As I don't want to write a book here I will conclude and tell you to try it if you are looking for a trully open world game with a great action,juicy explosions and shooting,GREAT STEALTH possibilities and an amazing atmosphere.You will love Africa after this,or hate it.Whatever.What you will not find is many RPG elements and a great story.But lack of those gives the game its charm and keeps the focus on other things.WHAT I HIGHLY RECOMMEND is getting this mods from moddb:sproyds_FC2_SweetFX_config and VERY important DylansFC2Mod1.4 as it will basically fix the game.Just check it out even if you don't like mods(like me)Play on highest difficulty and enjoy!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												The definitive African civil war mercenary simulator. Equal parts brilliant and flawed, the game is wrought with frustrating game design but is thoroughly soaked in its sweaty, mosquito-infested atmosphere. Be sure to mod the game first to reduce some of the frustrations the game throws at you, Dylan's Far Cry 2 mod is good. Since most won't like the game, I'll discuss the good points first.Far Cry 2 drops your mercenary hide into an ongoing civil war between 2 factions in a war-torn African country, your objective is to hunt "the Jackal", the infamous arms dealer that arms both sides and thus, is fueling the war. The thing about the story is that it's actually not bad. The plot is heavily inspired by Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness, the resulting focus on barbarism and morality is clearly evident. The game has an interesting approach to realism, the attention to detail is amazing. Your gun can jam in the middle of a firefight, performing the clearing drill around enemies creates a new level of tension. Fire is caused by anything flammable, molotovs, propane tanks, exploding cars, etc. And it propagates beautifully, better than in Far Cry 3 even. Your minimap is made of paper and you physically pull it out whenever you want to check it, it baffles me why no other game does this to improve immersion. Heck, even the plants bend when you step or drive over them, you can shoot the branches off trees too. A grenade will send pieces of a shed and the surrounding shrub flying, revealing the skeletal famework and anybody inside that is still alive. The AI is not perfect, they sometimes take turns to be impressively stupid and annoyingly sharp. But once combat starts, they yell updates at each other to coordinate flanks and comb the jungle for you when you are in hiding. At first, you will flounder around the map, attracting the attention of every enemy you meet, a frustrating and demoralizing experience. Slowly, you understand the quirks of the stealth system, you unlock guns which compliment your playstyle, you discover the value of always moving in a firefight. You grow fearless and become feared. You learn how to shoot to wound instead of kill, so that you may silently watch their comrades run out of cover to rescue their buddy and take them both out. As your reputation grows, soldiers in the cease fire areas no longer arrogantly push you away when you run up to them, instead, they mutter fearful apologies and back off. Sometimes, in combat, they will panic and scream about how they just want to go home. As your character uses his machete to execute the wounded soldier on the ground, you realise that the game's mechanics have turned you into the monster you were supposed to kill.Alongside that, an ingenious game mechanic is the buddy system. The game randomly assigns you buddies from a lengthy roster. Most of the time, you will be helping them run errands or get taken along by one of their crazy ideas to complicate the central mission. However, imagine this scenario: you attempt a raid and something goes wrong, a PMC flanked you from the tall grass to your right and you go down in bursts of shotgun fire. Your grow frustrated at the idea of restarting the attack, but then Josip, your hilarious, middle-aged Algerian buddy appears onscreen. He drags you to safety as you recall the time he got you to kill a car dealer for him because "Turns out car is piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥- so *he* is piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; and then awkwardly uses the word "cool" with a thumbs up and cheesy grin. You dig out the bullet from your forearm, the two of you re-enter the fray. However, assault truck pulls up. it's full of enemies and the machinegun on the vehicle sprays at both of you. You dive for cover and take it out with a grenade, only to see your buddy squirming on the ground. You move over to him and give him a morphine jab, expecting him to spring back to life just like before. But this time, he gurgles for more. With realization dawning, you give him another jab, his reply is the same. Now you have no more morphine and a dying buddy in pain. The game prompts you to unholster your pistol and you place it in his mouth. He even thanked you before you pulled the trigger. This is the way you get players to care.Unfortunately, those things only happen when the stars are aligned and the game plays as intended. The unfortunate reality is that in order for your emergent interactions with the militia to occur, the game throws them at you around every corner. This makes traversing the 50 square kilometers of the open world a serious hassle even when you master the art of finding paths of least resistance and take the bus whenever possible. Although it is highly satisfying to sneaking through a village to silence a high value target, it is just as likely that while sneaking through the town, the PMC on the platform at the other end of the town spots you with predator vision and blasts you with his RPG. Usually, stealth plans are thwarted midway because one missed shot from any silenced weapon alerts the whole camp to your position and they will almost instantly fire upon you from wherever they are. Using the machete is also, strangely, not a silenced kill. Making it useless expect in finishing off wounded enemies. I suppose Far Cry 3's magical teleporting knife instakills are an upgrade. The map design also causes fits whenever you encounter a steep cliff that blocks your safe shortcut to the objective. It makes you wish for helicopter travel or at least the ability to climb.Another unfortunate thing is the mission variety, although you are free to tackle them they are confined to 3 types. Assassination/intimidation missions where you either kill or force people to do things and maybe kill them afterwards. Sabotage/retrieval missions where you destroy or steal objects which are in a village filled with PMCs. Last is the convoy ambush, which is exactly what it sounds like. The last type usually only applies to the arms vendor missions which you complete to unlock the possibility of buying new weapons. So for most of the game you will be contending with the first 2. There are only so many ways to skin a cat and nearing the end, missions have the same draggy expectation as a fetch quest. When combined with the frustratingly long and tedious travel, you can see why this game was a major disappointment for many.The frustrations are slightly reduced with modding, Dylan's mod makes weapons much deadlier, increases the ammunition count, improves the effectiveness of your camouflaged suit, reduces the frequency of malaria attacks and jams as well as the chances of being chased when running through a checkpoint along with many other tweaks. As a result, you are more vulnerable and your gameplay will have even more tension. It's a good thing you have an extra life thanks to your buddy. I would advise to play it modded on the highest difficulty even on your first try because all is fair when you can usually down enemies with one round from any gun. Try to avoid conflict as much as possible and save very often, because you may die from ridiculous circumstances. That's all I have to say.

												Far Cry 2 is another sandbox game that allows you to explore the terrain and kick some♥♥♥♥♥ but has a number of flaws that may turn some gamers off. Still, Far Cry 2 is great for some freelance warfare especially given its detailed open-world environment.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												If you look at my profile, you can see that I've spent the majority of my time playing this. It is the perfect game for when you want to have fun, but at a bit more relaxed pace than defeating a boss in another game. It is great fun to burn and blow stuff up and the story is pretty good also. At first, it is easy to get your butt kicked, but once you get some decent weapons it is fairly easy. I also LOVE the beautiful views and it's a way to get a dose of sun on a rainy day. The only real negative is the lack of wild animals like tigers, etc. but they fixed that in Far Cry 3. I still prefer this one though. Tip: try to grab a jeep with a grenade launcher because once you have that, you are almost immortal. The big assault truck is very effective also. And make use of the open space with a sniper rifle. I also found the dart gun to be very useful because you can kill like four guys before assaulting a checkpoint, greatly increasing your odds. The first one goes down and it lures other guards over. Muahaha!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2011
												This game is a hidden treasure that all players must have in their collection. There is so much realism, so much detail, and so many more features than Far Cry. It's unbelievable how amazing this game is, and also how underplayed it is. I've heard people say that it differs too much from it's predecessor to be an official sequel. Although it's made on a different engine and has a surplus of extras not featured in Far Cry, the basic elements are still the same: shoot mercs in a sandbox world set in an exotic locale.If you never played Far Cry 1 and if you were to ask me I would say skip it entirely and get Far Cry 2. It has everything that most people would want in a game, with only minor annoyances. It's crazy how much detail is here: driveable vehicles, mounted guns, fixable cars, unlockable safe houses, weapon upgrades, uncontrollable wild fires, exciting action, riveting music, helpful allies, challenging AI, beautiful scenery, and to top it all off you have a bad case of malaria!

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
 Far Cry 2: Buy it! I am less than 10 h/ into the game, but I can say that it is worth however much money you get it for. The AI for the enemy's can be a little shaky, but for the most part you can actually use their purposly implemented features to your advantage. Scenerio example: You spot an enemy in the distance, in a base camp. Your mission objective is far away, yet you can't resist the urge to make your own fun in this barren wastland. You get a little closer, while still remaining in the bushes and shrubs, and you finaly get close enough to where you think you can make an accurate shot. You crouch down, take aim and fire at their shoulder. You hit, and the rest of the enemies remain clueless as to who fired the shot. They rush over to the wounded souldier, and as they get there you make a dash to get with close range, and take out 3 enemy's with your shotgun remaining unharmed and get behind cover before any other enemy's can get a shot off on you. 3 down, 2 more to get an easy advantage on using the same method with a little more run and gun.The enemy's "caring" features as I would like to call them the feature I made a scenario about above. If you wound a souldier, or put one into a dangerous situation, if all goes well another souldier will move into the same general area, or go to the wounded souldier and help. This is a very cool feature that I like using, but you need to make sure that you are for enough away.The different characters that you can play as all have a different initial spawning spot, which also means that your "boss" at the beggining has different traits (and of course different voice actors) which spices up the beggining of your game differently, which adds to replayability. Of course, I haven't played very far into the game on different characters so I can't confirm that the story/npc's that you meet later are different, but at least during the begining you can choose different characters to play as which gives different startings to the game.  Permadeath. Do it. Seriously. Permadeath is where if you die in game, you can't respawn. Well of course you still can, but if you are following the rules then you delete your save/all other saves corosponding with that character you are playing with. This game has a unique  buddy system , which can be fatal, and helpful. The more buddy's you have, the "safer" you will be. Your buddy's can save your A☻s, but sometimes can give you false hope, like if you only have one syrrette (morphine) left and you are at low health and your buddy is down, you can save them in the hopes that if you "die" that your buddy will rescue you, but your buddy is just as open to dangers as you are, and can die also. Syrrettes are morphine shots that restore your health to full, but you can only use them if you did the non syrrette heal, which is to hit the same key (H) and it will make your character do one of the dozens of healing animations, like biting a bullet out of your arm, using plyers to get a bullet out of your leg, pulling a peice of metal from your thigh, putting your arm back into it's socket, etc. which makes the game feel VERY realistic in the damage sence. Syrrettes are easily obtainable at safe houses, your "boss's" "house", enemy camps etc. but if you are constantly in the feild enjoying the open world aspect of the game, then you might run into trouble, esspecially if you are playing permadeath.Some notes:-If you steal an enemy car from a camp and another enemy sees you, they will engage.-ALWAYS use a vehicle that has a mounted turret. It's as easy as hitting "C" to switch to the turret and within second you have a weapon that can be way more powerfull than your weapons that you carry.-Make your own fun! Don't forget, this is an open world game. You can run around having fun and engaging in casual shennanigans alongside actually completing the game.Anyways, you guys should 100% buy this game! It's worth it if you like unforgiving enemies, multiple ways of completing missions, having open world possibilities, and playing through older games (it was made in 2008). Enjoy!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Let me be as brutally honest as possible, as I'm only given two choices of "Yes" and "No" it's hard to pin point where I stand on this game. Pros: - Something to do with the story, I don't really care about story, too busy shooting things and exploring- Lots of things to do- Good gunplay- Good graphics for it's time, and even still good (to me) todayCons: (and boy, do i have a lot of these)- Respawning guard posts, I know Ubisofts main intention for the respawning guard posts was to make it so that you always had something to do, but when cars are oh so very easily damaged, it's a massive slow down when you can't actually just drive through a base without getting your car shot out by one or two guys- Enemy AI, Don't get me wrong, it's funny to hear them say "I saw atleast 3 guys" over and over, but when your trying to be sneaky, and enemies can see you through random bits of foiliage, but you can't see them, that's a tad bit unfair, a minor set back- The sheer mass of the game, the map is absolutely MASSIVE or maybe it just feels that way due to the fact that it takes ages to get anywhere, paired with the fact that stamina isn't unlimited, makes the exploration factor take a painful amount of time to do. Take this scenario, you don't know that there is one specific part that links the south part of the map with the north (as if the north part wasn't big enough) you take your buggy over to the north part, expecting to be able to get there, but alas, your character passes out and you can't. it respawns you without a vehicle, and you have to spend the next 15 minutes walking to find a randomly spawning enemy car. It has happened to me, it's probably happened to you, and if it hasn't, consider yourself VERY lucky.I could go on, and I may seem to be very heavy on the cons, and not so heavy on the pros, but believe me when I say this, this game has it's moments, it's quite fun, i enjoy it, if it weren't for the MASSIVE amount of driving that you had to do, and respawning guard outposts, this would be the perfect game, and I think i speak for a lot of people, because far cry 3? It's basically what i just described, Ubisoft agrees with it, and the vast populi of people who have played the far series agree with it.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Far Cry 2 is the Far cry 3 i always wanted. I know many people dislike this game; "It is too hard", "there are no clear quest markers", "Its not obvious when enemies can see you". But this game has certain realisms which, for a rising storm/RO2 fan, makes it more appealing.                       Certain features in this game make it just that bit better than the alternatives out there:+Your gun jamming when you have used it too many times. (With a nice rust effect to warn you prior)+Enemies don't just drop money, meaning that sometimes it is better NOT to kill all the lifeforms in a 30 mile radius.+There is a certain variety in the vehicle selection which i really like (The big white 'Tank' is truly a beast!)+Guns overheating, knife bouncing off hard targets; small features like this, and more, make the game beleivable.+You look at REAL maps instead of just  pausing and going to the menue, meaning you can look on the drive! All these features, at least for me, make this game probably the best in the trilogy, and i have played all excessivly (bar 4), and despite the malaria being a bit of a bummer, it is pleasant to have a character who isn't just super amazingly tough and perfect in every way.Would definitely reccomend buying, as long as you are more into 'realism' (as obviosly you can still soak up bullets like nobody else can).9.5/10
