Posted: February 28, 2014
												FIRST: THIS GAME HAS FULL CONTROLLER SUPPORT! BUT IT ISN'T LISTED! (I DON'T KNOW WHY IT ISN'T LISTED...) FANTASTIC game.  Atmosphere is its BEST quality.  Just running around the jungles, deserts, and savannahs is a joy.  Then you get plenty of good action.  And stealth!  VERY effectively-executed stealth gameplay.  The large areas and varied atmospheres give you plent of room to plan your strikes.  All animations and graphics are very good, even fitting realistic motions that a person's head would make!  The combat is fairly standard semirealistic shooting except for the large spaces, but the atmosphere and freedom make combat a discovery in the wilderness.  Discover and survive.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2013
												What I liked:- Attention to detail: Wildfires spread, crappy guns jam, foliage conceals you. So many things are unexpectedly realistic.- Novel setting: Very few games are set in an African landscape, and this one pretty much makes it a main character.- Total immersion: There are no forced third-person cutscenes, and the HUD only appears when needed or when you press the "Reload" key.What I didn't care for:- Buddies are fragile: You can only successfully rescue a near-death buddy three times. This means you have to metagame if you want to keep a buddy alive.Recommendations:- Don't worry about having played the first Far Cry beforehand; there are no story ties between that game and this one.- Play it like Fallout 3 or Red Faction Guerrilla, not like Call of Duty or Gears of War. Explore, take side missions, and approach fights tactically rather than recklessly.- Turn off the music; it's not bad music, but it causes you to miss subtle audio cues.

												The "FUUUUUUCK This Ending Better Be Good" game..........the ending was good.Getting CONS out of the way:Very tedious missions, enemies losing you when you are near their face, pebbles can stop and even damage your vehicle, ♥♥♥♥ING ENEMY OUTPOSTS EVERYWHERE, and long destinations making this game a bit longer to finish. Buildings, bridges, and other structures keeps you immersed the entire time. Sound quality surprised me, the ambient animal noises, rain and waterfalls were great to hear. Design aside, the gunplay and constant firefights kept the playthrough very entertaining. JEEPS EVERYWHERE but was fitting. Good variety of weapons allowing you to enjoy a different style of attacking a group of enemies whenever you want (This game is not that well into stealth attacks, more for receiving the upper hand in fights).Story was great all the way through, lots of lefts and rights keeping you engaged and wanting to progress til the very end.You can shave off tons of hours on your playthorugh by not completing the extra (blue) missions.Yea it's good, get it on a sale. Play it. It's fun.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												I bought Far Cry 2 for $3.39 about three days ago on steam and let me tell you thats a steal. I got about 20 hours of gameplay out of it and I bet you could get more if you weren't like me. (I used -GameProfile_GodMode 1 as soon as I finished the tutorial) So essentially I didn't die a single time in the game. I enjoy games when I'm unstoppable and here's why I think you should get this game. (For no more than $5 otherwise your wasting money). The game is fun as the story goes back and forth and you face moral dillemmas. The game gives you the illusion of choice however. It tells you to complete a mission you can do this or that. But it ultimately doesn't mean anything as you will be forced into the same outcome. Its just the means of reaching that outcome. The story lets you think you are writing it and participating, but you aren't, you're just following along. The game's missions do get repetitive as its only assassinate this guy or blow this thing up. I payed $3 and cheated through the whole game so I wasn't expecting too much. As for replayability, its a Far Cry game so there is none. Also there are no achievements which give me no incentive to find stuff or kill guard posts. In Far Cry  3, there were achievements, and I was playing on Xbox so achievements mean something, so there was a reason to go do something in the game. Since I finished the game 5 mins ago, I don't think I'll be revisiting it. BUT, it was worth all 339 of my pennies and I would gladly pay 339 pennies for another Far Cry game. It is what it is, a shoot em up with nice scenary so don't expect too much.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												FIRST: THIS GAME HAS FULL CONTROLLER SUPPORT! BUT IT ISN'T LISTED! (I DON'T KNOW WHY IT ISN'T LISTED...) FANTASTIC game.  Atmosphere is its BEST quality.  Just running around the jungles, deserts, and savannahs is a joy.  Then you get plenty of good action.  And stealth!  VERY effectively-executed stealth gameplay.  The large areas and varied atmospheres give you plent of room to plan your strikes.  All animations and graphics are very good, even fitting realistic motions that a person's head would make!  The combat is fairly standard semirealistic shooting except for the large spaces, but the atmosphere and freedom make combat a discovery in the wilderness.  Discover and survive.

Without a doubt I'd recommend this game if I could actually play it.  It's not as fluid as the newer Far Cry's, but who gives af; this is Far Cry history!  Hopefully it works for you.  Buy it on sale just in case.UPDATE:If you notice characters not staying on the ground or their heads moving from left-to-right like they're shaking their head 'no', lower the display settings and this should fix the issue.  I changed mine from ultra/high to Low and turned off some of the features and viola, the bugs stopped and the NPCs preformed as intended.  Hope this helps.  Enjoy FC2!

content:
Posted: January 1
												far drive 2, I mean far cry 2, is a sandbox GTA-style shooter set in some african desert-jungle where you travel miles and miles and miles for each mission to merely shoot a guy or blow something up. and each time you hop into a car or jeep, you're tailed by some angry black men who want you ♥♥♥♥ing dead. I could sum up the game like that<, but that would be a bit boring, wouldn't it, let alone pessimistic as all hell. to put it more cheerfully: far cry 2 is a game that is as frustrating as it is enjoyable. make what you want out of that description. for a game where you're doing a ♥♥♥♥ of a lot of travelling, I have to admit that it pulls it all off rather well. the good thing about this system is that the map is lovely and big (it's very geographically diverse too which is even better), meaning you're not going to feel isolated in a tiny urban city area like you might feel when playing a game like saints row or GTA 4. the problem with the large degree of travel, however, is that you can only save your progress pretty much *after* you've beaten a mission. that's a huge problem because if you're travelling what literally seems like miles just to reach the objective, and you die in the heat of a shootout that follows, that means you have to go back to the beginning and disregard the fact that you've just wasted about half an hour of your precious life. either this is a pretty thrilling mechanic where you actually have a lot on the line, or it will send your controller routinely flying through the air.the graphics are surprisingly very crisp, especially for a game made in 2008. I played this game for years on the xbox 360 and the upgrade in picture quality on the PC is quite remarkable. if you had told me this game was only a few years old, I'd happy believe you, because it really does look good for its time. the enemy AI, while very responsive, can be quite bipolar. sometimes I swear the enemies have ♥♥♥♥ing spidey-senses and will spot you from about 100 feet away, even when you're only poking your head out from beyond a tree. they give enemies on MGS4's boss extreme settings a run for their money, that's for sure. but in other situations, you might come walking amongst them for a good 20 seconds until they actually realise that you're the enemy. it's quite a strange AI system. the gameplay itself, disregarding this, is pretty addictive, at least when you're on a winning streak. you can upgrade your weapons in a significant manner by doing side missions and this actually feels as if you're beefing up your character which gives this game a layer of RPG elements. you'll need to beef up your character too or else the game is going to absolutely slaughter you, especially if you're playing on at least normal difficulty. thankfully, these side missions are a nice break from the main story line. the vehicles, too, are very open for your usage and if you wanted to get from point A to B in, say, a boat, or a hang glider, it's all possible, but admittedly either finding the alternative vehicles is challenging or they simply aren't up to scratch (especially the boats when they crawl up the rivers like a ♥♥♥♥ing slug until you hit top speed). the currency system as well, which is rough diamonds, is also pretty nice, and it means you aren't limited to just getting the means to upgrade your rig by doing the missions in that diamonds can be found in the wild. lastly, the buddy system is a really nice new feature in such a game which I think delivers a huge deal of depth for a shooter like this. when your buddies stick their neck out for you and end up getting killed, it really is a sad sight to behold.oh, and did I mention dat map editor? good sweet jesus. pretty outstanding if you ask me. if you wanted to play sims creator mode but in far cry 2 instead, this is how you do it. and it's pretty fun. sure, it might be more trouble than it's worse when it will take you a massive amount of time to create a map that isn't shockingly bad, but so long as you're patient, like you'll need to be in all other departments in far cry 2, then it's worth the investment. evidently, far drive 2 is a flawed game. nobody can deny that. but it offers something GTA and its army of clones (saints row, sleeping dogs, red dead, etc) can't: an actual ♥♥♥♥ing challenge. sure, challenging games can only be challenging if they are occasionally frustrating, maddening and infuriating, but at the end of the day, I'd rather an experience like this where I feel like I'm actually a mortal human than some unkillable son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ - the former is a lot more fulfilling, and thankfully, far drive 2 isn't so challenging that it's unplayable. I'd compare the experience to the dark soul games - it's definitely a test of endurance. if you're an instant gratification style gamer - this game will get a 6 for you, if that. if you're a player who appreciates a good challenge where you actually have to sit tight and be patient - boost this game up to a 9 at max. personally, I'm tending towards the latter end with a 8/10 - not recommended for everybody, but it will definitely please a certain niche.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												I struggle to decide what I really think of Far Cry2. On the one hand, it's a really good pick-up-&-play with a great weapon load-out, decent application of the sandbox model & an interesting premise. On the other hand, the AI seems to have xray vision, you can't really pick a side & the game feels a bit incomplete on some of the details.The premise is simple; you are a mercenary sent to a war-torn African country with the simple task of killing an arms-dealer who is selling to both sides & prolonging the conflict. At the time you arrive, there is a shakey peace, but you contract Malaria & fall ill in the local town. You are found by the arms-dealer, named the Jackal, who decides not to execute you, presumably expecting you die a rather miserable & painful death on your own.You awake some time later with the ceasefire broken & that's where you start; escape the town & get put to work by a member of one of the two factions. The problem is, the game starts to break down even here as you can't choose one side or the other, or neither. On top of that, everyone shoots at you, no matter who you're working for. The excuse is none of the soldiers know which side you're on so shoot first & just forget to ask questions. In reality, the programming for random friend/foe AI was too hard, too expensive or would've taken too long. Or all three. Either way, it can really annoy. The other thing that really annoys me is the fact the AI seems to be able to perfectly spot you in dense jungle, even if you are stood still & behind bushes & trees. The fact you can't see them thanks to the same foliage makes it even more of a fight weighed against you on purpose. These flaws feel like the design team ran out of time to put these mecahnics in, but for me, the making or breaking of a game is the details that really pull you in, & Far Cry 2 feels like is misses that trick.The game does have some upsides; the weapon load-out is well thought out both in what you can carry & what guns you have access too. There are plenty of weapons for stealth & a night attack where no-one hears or sees you until you kill them is very satisfying. The 1-man army load out will also work great if you're careful with timing & smashing a heavily defended check point without taking any hits is good fun. Vehicles handle ok & there is enough variety in the missions, even if it does usually end up requiring you to simply shoot everything. There is a 'buddy' system, where you can befriend other mercenary characters who assist you or give you missions, even rescue you when you're health runs out. The graphics make it a very pretty game & some of the effects are excellent. My favotire thing are the tape reordings of interviews with the Jackal, some are rather disturbing in how cold the guy is, the little details that help you invest in the world.The story is basically two parts. In the first, you do missions for the two sides in no particular order, plus a 'resistance' group smuggling civilians out, you're then asked to kill one of the leaders. In the second part, the exact same thing happens again. Needlessly. It does make the world massive, with a huge area to explore, but it feels a little thrown together.Far Cry 2 is so nearly there; allow you to work for one side or another, allow that to effect how you're seen by each side, make some checkpoints on the roads friend, some foe, some abandonned & make one half of the story cover the whole game & it's potentially a fabulous game.It sounds like I don't like Far Cry 2, but in actual fact, I do. As a pick-up-&-play, for no more than a few hours, it's great. There's little thought required other than how you want to go about your mission & what weapon load-out to go with, it's a lovely game to spend time in visually, the number of guns you can pick from is wonderfully varied & there are loads of missions to keep you busy. But it's no more than that. If you can accept Far Cry 2 for those flaws, then you'll probably enjoy it as a kind of 'library title'; a game to play between the games you get heavily invested into. Because I am able to see & accept Far Cry 2 for what it is, I feel I CAN recommend it, but with the previso to not expect any real depth from it.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Edit:Alright, finally finished it. It became slightly repetitive towards the end, and the ending itself wasn't that great, but I had a good time playing it. Probably won't repeat it, but it's still recommended./EditI'm in the process of finishing this game and I'm having a great time.To new players: Make sure you install the Dylan realism mod and then crank the difficulty UP a bit, because the mod will make you damage people more realistically (they won't survive direct headshots anymore, for example).And to be clear, I absolutely LOATHED the checkpoints the first time I played, and subsequently hated the game. After some time away I gave it another shot and quickly got over it being annoying, simply by following the advice from this article: http://majorslack.com/games-tips-tricks/having-fun-playing-far-cry-2/Taking it more slowly when approaching checkpoints on foot, or just cutting corners or taking shortcuts when driving on the roads, or getting ready to gun them down with the mounted weapon on your vehicle, will help you immensely with the checkpoints.After a while it got so easy for me avoiding them that I started having fun by creating the most sadistic ways of taking them out, like wounding one guy in the leg to lure out others trying to help him, only for me to pick them off one by one with my trusty sniper rifle, or getting the grenade webbing upgrade and tossing a truckload of grenades into every nook and cranny I could find, blowing everything to smithereens and listening to the ensuing screams of terror.Then driving my jeep away, looking forward to toy my way through the next encounter while enjoying the beautiful scenery around me as the sun came up or went down in the horizon.As long as you FOLLOW THE TIPS IN THAT ARTICLE and install the REALISM MOD you're gonna have a game with awesome and gritty atmosphere which any other game will have a hard time matching.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												I'm only about 3 hours in and I'm already hooked.  I'd say its one of the better Far Cry games already.  It doesn't have a perk tree, but I would say that is to it's benefit here.  You have to go survive on your own gut.  After the Malaria of course.  If there was an option to holester my gun, walk around and observe and take in the view, I would do that.  But this is a dangerous world, there are barely any friendly NPCs outside in the world.  It is taken by two factions I believe.  Everyone on the open world is dangerous.  All you have is a rusty rifle taken from someone you happen to find along the way with your Pistol and machete.  I think this game would be fine if it doesn't have a story and is just exploring the medium/large scaled world.  I think the world here feels just right. It has jamming and wear on weapons too. Sounds bad at first, but Africa.  You also have to take pills sometimes because you have Malaria, but Africa. Also play on the Hardest difficulty, or the 2nd hardest one. They give challenge and rutheless enemies. I'd play on the hardest more if they won't stop shooting me through walls, but I choose it anyway because it limits how much I can carry at once. HUD is very minimal, compared to later Far Cry games, they are a mess.  I feel as though this is what a Far Cry game should be.  You don't rely on perks or upgrades as much here, just your own wits and skill.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is a "Far Cry" from the rest of the series, but still is amazingly fun. It's a very hard game, with interesting mechanics, and while it can be frustrating at times, it makes the moments of victory so much more pleasing. The appeal of Dark Souls applies here, in fact, yet the game is completely fair in its difficulty, unlike Dark Souls. Truly, Far Cry 2 is one of the best (and most difficult) shooters I've played in a long while.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												EDIT: I suggest giving Far Cry 3 a look. I hear it's pretty similar to this one but better in most ways. Compare some videos to decide which one you want.First thing's first: it's a shallow game. It could have been better in many ways. They could have made the world more lively. They could have tried a bit harder with the missions. They could have made a better story. They could have (done much more), but they didn't. I haven't looked into it, so consider this anecdotal in the purest form, but I would wager that it was rushed for release or held back by being designed for consoles.One thing you'll notice is that the game is still beautiful 7 years down the road, and despite being a game made for consoles first. The shadows, while not as fine as modern games, are still extremely efficient for how good looking they are, which is what mostly contributes to the beauty of the game. You can play on highest settings and still get very good performance on any semi-modern PC. One of the ways they get such great performance out of good shadows is the clever way they hide the level of detail scaling. If you pay attention during the opening cutscene when the trucks pass in front of you -on ultra- you'll notice how the shadows under them disappear very quickly. In regular play, this is almost entirely hidden by clever level design with high usage of obfuscation; that is to say, very compartmentalized to a big wide open area with a limited amount of "dynamic" shadow objects like cars and characters, supplemented with great-looking grass everywhere and clever usage of trees. The grass and trees, which move and react semi-dynamically to random wind patterns, produce seemingly dynamic shadows (don't know exactly if they are dynamic or static; if it's dynamic, it's extremely efficient on resources; if it's static, they look very dynamic) that react particularly well with the pretty lighting method the game uses. Remember: It was made first and foremost for the limited hardware of the Xbox 360. They deload all rendering of areas you are no longer in while keeping the areas still loaded in memory so there is no loading time, keeping the game openworld. All of the system load in the game is due to graphical fidelity, very low CPU usage is observed due to the mechanics of the game, which works perfectly for consoles which have subpar CPUs but usually good GPUs to keep down prices. You'll notice that console games are rarely complex for CPU-based actions like lots of pathfinding enemies; just an observation I wanted to point out, totally unrelated to this review.The game is "atmospheric" and "immersive", since I'm tired and don't know a more clever way to describe it. It pulls you in and really makes you feel like you're in Africa. It really "feels" hot and dry. You can "feel" the heat applied by the light on your character's arm. The sound design is incredibly detailed, and the beauty of the world never strains your suspension of disbelief.The gameplay is shallow and underrealized. As the Steam review of the game, by the user Koltraiin had said, "No elephants, Lions, Cheetahs, Snakes, Crocodiles." This is indicative of the shallowness of the game; they could have given it more, but it simply wasn't there. With all this in mind, I find the game fun to play. It's a unique experience for a unique game, and despite being shallow in gameplay it's a great deal for 10 dollars and it goes on sale fairly often. The biggest downside to the game is being a Ubisoft title, and requiring a Ubisoft account to play online.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												This is not as good as farcry 3, but it still is better, kind of, eh...Want to travel to Africa and experience a gritty story with no heroes, tuly immersive gameplay, and beautiful vistas? This game nailed that, perhaps too well. Because the realistic approach in this game made you feel like a hard working ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, not a happy super hero with no regrets as in Farcry 3.This game is probably one of the most dynamic and realistic game I have ever tried. There is no handholding and It is incredibly immersive, and difficult. Yet, I have not finished it, and I don't know if I have the time and effort to do so. Because this game is serious work. This is a game to come back to and play over time.What is good?No UPLAYIt looks fantastic, it really does. And runs well without the most amazing graphics-card. In some ways I think it looks better than farcry 3, because is feels more real. There are really beautiful vistas in this game that makes you stop and just look around for a while, over and over.It is very immersive. You are "always" in the game. No menus to constantly interrupt you as in farcry 3. The map is held in your hand for example. I really enjoy this interface-idea, way better than farcry 3. You are no super hero that can take on everybody and thousands of bullets. You have to plan ahead and you have to be smart. You are vulnerable and everything can go wrong. You guns suddenly might jam, the fire you (accidentally) started might burn you alive if you are not careful. Perhaps your car suddenly needs repair? AI is smart and will flank you, hide, and attack you even when wounded and lying down. Foliage is beautiful and will move and react to your running and shooting. You do have some help (well, time will tell). You have friends who offer you help, and can even revive you if you get shot down. How you interact with these friends are totally up to you, and creates varied gameplay and events. You can work for arms dealers and upgrade your weapons and gears. You can find vehicles with mounted guns and a lot of firepower.The game has few and short cutscenes that don't constantly interrupt and tell you what to do all the time. It is up to you, and if you have your wits about you, you can do it. It feels less like a game this way. Farcry 3 is a "Disney roller coaster entertainmnet island". Farcry 2 is serious work where you feel and smell the dirt, the burned oil and grass, the dust and the misery of the place.There is wildlife, but no all over the place. They hide like real animals do. And you don't have to mass slaughter every animal to get a belt, in fact not at all.Guns behave realistically; whatch that recoil, you can't snipe with a handgun from 200 metres away. And the weapons break. I know many hate all these problems with the guns. But for me it makes the game tense, and you always have to be on your toes, comming up with a quick alternative if something goes wrong. - You cannot always rely on your super weapon.What is bad?Well, all these great things, are also the problem. As said before, the game is hard, sometimes too hard, and I found that I enjoyed shorter times with the game, rather than sitting for hours playing it. Every time I came back to the game, I marveled at the greatness of the game, and everytime I finished a session I was a little tired of it. It can be quite repetitive. Traveling around the map takes time and you constantly have to deal with angry people shooting at you, every time you pass a guardzone, even if you took the place out a moment ago - yes the guards respawn. Missions are not very varied either. If you compare to Farcry 3, there is not much to the game in terms of activities. The AI is tough, and sometimes it feels like they never give up. And they see you from far away with fantastic accuracy. It is not easy to sneak.Conclusion:If you play this game like farcry 3, you will be disappointed. The game does not constantly feed you content, and happy colors. Far cry 3 is truly fantastic in its own way and improved many flaws that far cry 2 had, but far cry 2 feels so much more dynamic. The game creates content for you by interacting with the world, not by feeding constantly what to do, say and think. It the dynamic moments that are special, where anything can happen, and how you react to it. The world is more realistic and beautiful than farcry 3. In a way it feels more like roleplay, because the protagonist is silent, and the game really shines when you put effort into it, and you get immersed. But that is also the problem, do you have time to get that involved without being entertained all the time by the game?I wish Farcry 3 (and 4) would be more a mix of far cry 2 and 3. Where you are more free to do what you want, and you are not constantly spoonfed every minute, and less collecting stuff and upgrading this and that. It felt like filler in farcry 3 that stopped you from getting on with the game. Far cry 3 is a better game. But Far cry 2 is unique, special and amazing, and it has created a deeper effect on me than far cry 3.

content:
Posted: February 7
A long due sequel from FarCry and what a difference.Unlike the first game being on an island with secret militia and mutants to fight, here we are in Africa looking for an arms dealer. How Resident Evil 5 was called racist and not this game is beyond me.You get malaria at the very beginning of the game, which really ruins the entire story. At random times you need to take malaria pills to prevent death/game over while also trying not to be killed with regular your health.How do you obtain these pills? Doing side quests, but during the side quests you may need to take more pills, which gives LITTLE room to explore or even do the MAIN STORY because you're always gulping back pill after pill.The weapons all deteriorate when you use them, even a fully repaired gun can blow up the first time you use it, again more to the realistic value but a real pain in the f*cking a**.Repairing your vehicles is easy, tightening a lugnut on the engine makes the fire/smoke stop.The gameplay is still good, the story is decent but it's nothing like the original.7/10

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												[Played on Hardest difficulty setting with music off]If you're a fan of Far Cry 3 and are interested in trying this one out, be warned that it might not be what you're expecting.  It's more closely related to games like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. than any of the other games in the Far Cry series.  It's brutally unforgiving and slanted more towards realism and immersion than action-adventure.  The world is large, but exploration isn't necessarily a large part of the gameplay, as the only real purpose for doing so is finding diamonds, hidden tapes, and golden guns -- none of which are particularly essential to the experience of the game.At its core, the game is about tense gunfights and missions, and the different tactics you can use to ensure your survival.  The game has a robust array of different systems that organically create compelling moments -- last second escapes into the jungle while bullets whiz past you, guns jamming at the least opportune moment and forcing you to flee for the nearest sign of cover, buddies arriving just in the nic of time to save you from an otherwise unwinnable firefight, enemies whom you thought you had killed crawling to their knees and shooting you in the back for revenge -- the list goes on and on, and I'm still discovering new possibilities after hours of play.  Playing with the music turned off increases the tension in the game IMMENSELY, as you never know if there's an enemy around you just waiting for the perfect time to blast you apart and ruin the last ten minutes of progress you'd made.  You'll find yourself checking every corner, listening intently for footsteps or enemy chatter, and cursing yourself when you inevitably miss that lone gunman who finishes you off as soon as you step into the open.The narrative of the game is also smart and very sensible and aware of the topics which it brings up, which is a helluva lot more than you can say for most modern military shooters.  Don't expect to leave this one feeling like the hero.tldr;It's absolutely brilliant, especially if you're into S.T.A.L.K.E.R.-like games and emergent gameplay.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												This is a very good open world FPS.  The strongest aspect of the Far Cry series has always been the ability to attack the missions/challenges in any way you see fit; Far Cry 2 allows you to decide how you're going to take on the bad guys.  Run N' Gun?  Stealth?  Snipe everybody (my personal favorite)?The only negative about the game is the lack of Fast Travel between points you've already discovered.  There's a LOT of driving/walking/boating/swimming that you'll have to do in order to get around the world, but it's not so huge that this becomes a real issue.  You can get to the corners and center of the map via bus stations, but the rest of the time you'll be responsible for getting yourself where you want to go.So get out there and start tracking down The Jackal.  He's not a very nice person, and no one will miss him when he's gone...

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Far cry 2 is, let's say... less than ideal. Long ago I had even anticipated this game to be absolutely awesome, reality however didn't meet my expectations. The original Far cry at the time it appeared was a masterpiece that I enjoyed immensely. It was absolutely gorgeous, engaging to play and overall it just felt good. Far cry number two however falls short or gets you annoyed in several different parts. First of all when I started playing, I wasn't expecting it to be an Africa based awful driving simulator. There's way too much driving around in an open world that has little less activities to do than to shoot at everyone because everyone is extremely mad at you for existing. The world feels empty. How the AI works and behaves is questionable and because the enemy guys' bare chests are actually kevlar or something even sturdier you find yourself asking is this game really a game worth playing. I would go as far to say that it isn't. Too much repetition, too much boring driving and too much forced confrontations with foes that merely want to slow your progress in an annoying way (destroying the engine of your car so you have to stop and fix it). It isn't all bad however. It brings up some interesting points in the story off how cruel a civil war truly is, the greed of mankind and all sorts of nasty things. The game can look pretty freaking beautiful at times especially on daytime. Some of the guns feel pretty nice to shoot until they jam or break completely and won't shoot anymore. I did finish the game and at the end I felt both relief and contentment. There are just a lot more and better FPS games to be had than this. Don't waste your time. The predecessor of Far Cry 2 was a better game and so is the successor as well. Better to spend your money on something completely different. Or maybe similar but better if the type of game ticks well with you.

number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Its an older game so it runs good on my budget Toshiba laptop. Environment looks beatiful for a game. Minor gun complaint - the G3K A4 rifle you get should have the same specs as the FAL since they fire the same cartridge in real life and both are capable of taking down a man at 600 meters or further and are basically 1 or 2 shot kills. But Its still interesting/fun in the beginning stages! I'm playing on easy because I'm a wuss and play for fun. The vehicle dynamics are improved from FC1, but are still a pain sometimes, but the fact that you can repair them (with one bolt!) is a hoot! Using the map is cool, but a bit clunky and hard to see while avoiding trees. Go blow stuff up and shoot badguys!(Updated: Aug31-2015)Finished it. (Spoilers ahead) here's what I felt:Basically the game punishes you for playing it well. If you want to finish the game, you cannot just pick a side based on a moral choice: "Which side (UFLL or APR) behave morally and harm fewer civillians?" No - its all about murdering all the other mercs (like you) for money. The game devs decided to make your amoral (immoral, some might argue) character (whichever you choose to play as doesnt matter a bit) fatally flawed in all important areas of the game:1) Before you even begin playing, you automatically contract Malaria. So your health is compromised from Day 1. The rest of the game forces you to do humanitarian missions for the Underground (the only "faction" that is for actually helping unarmed citizens) in order to aquire Malaria meds in order for you to stay alive so that you can kill even more mercenaries...on both sides. What if I wanted to work exclusively for the Underground...like "The Machine Gun Preacher"?  (A movie based on a real guy in Africa.) Nope. Can't. Stuck being a selfish A-hole murderer.2) Before you even start playing (again) You become a stupid, failed TOOL. Not only do you immediately fail in your mission to "kill the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that is arming both sides" - the idea based on a flawed moral statement built upon the liet: "Guns kill people, not the men pulling the triggers...so therefore to secure peace, we must remove guns.", (which makes it SEEM like the player-character has SOME moral compass) but no, you end up unwittingly working for the Jackal the whole game untill the unescapable, unalterable end. You're just a stupid PAWN!3) Before you even begin playing (AGAIN) You are predestined to be an ammoral murderer who only exists to kill everyone else you see - eventually even your "friends" whom you have saved and who save you numerous times throughout the entire game and yet, they all make the snap decision based on BS to just betray and kill you (and they just spawn in from space apprently too). And the game gives you no choice but to finish them off instead of healing/sparing them. I hated finishing this game. I thought I'd get to feel good about the character by the end, (I played as Paul - the Israeli). I thought I'd get to see him GROW as a person - maybe to become a merciful mercenary, who decides: "Even though violence has its place in this messed up world (that is undeniable)  I will CHOOSE a side in this conflict based on moral absolutes. And by these guidelines, I choose how to live, fight, and die..." It shouldn't be based on money, or the ravings of a greedy, dying lunatic Arms Dealer. But the game Devs said: "WRONG! WE will force you to be a martyr no matter which path (detonate dynomite or deliver diamond bribe to border guards) you choose - You will still kill yourself." Stupid...especially when one path could have easily allowed the player to live. But all my choices were made for me before I even began playing. AT LEAST I DIE SAVING REFUGEES AND NOT MURDERING THEM!!! Thank you for throwing me that bone, Ubisoft. But mostly its like Ubisoft is saying: "Thanks for buying Far Cry 2, an excericise in moral-dilemas with no "good ending". Enjoy wasting 80 hours of your life as you wander aimlessly through this open world, killing everything you see untill...we make you kill yourself.  F^#k you, Murdurer!"

number of helpful: 25 of 49 people (51%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Modern shooters have become little more than corridor crawls. You enter a mission and are funneled through the map with almost no deviation available. As far as the possibility of "next-gen" world building goes, shooters are stuck in a rut. Interestingly enough, Ubisoft made a valiant effort to push the FPS genre forward back in 2008.Far Cry 2 is one of the most invigorating ideas for a shooter that I've ever played. It doesn't always succeed in it's ambition, but the sense of freedom and the massive size of the world lend themselves to some fantastic moments. Those moments are spread a bit thin, though.While the very first thing you do in the game has an objective, the next 16 hours are pretty much you exploring. There are light story elements driving some of your actions, but you would be forgiven for not knowing that a plotline even exists. Your starting goal is simply "Kill the Jackal" and that is about as far as the narrative goes.This is the biggiest flaw with the game. There is no urgency in anything you are doing. You could easily spend years combing over every inch of the game world and never feel obligated or inclined to tackle any missions. While that is very intriguing as a launching point, it makes for a game that feels lackadaisical and pointless.When you do take up a mission, that is when the game starts to breathe. The fast travel spots are rarely convenient, so you are (almost always) forced to find your own path. The in-game map can help you from getting lost, but it doesn't point out any direction to you. You simply need to chart your own course.During your travel to the objective spot, you often run into bandits. This emergent style of gameplay leads to some fantastic shoot outs that have you scrambling for your life. These moments do happen a bit too often to stay truly enveloping, but barely dodging a missile and sniping guys across a chasm never cease to be quick fixes of joy.When you finish a mission, you simply are left with nothing. The currency system in this game is almost entirely worthless. Since your weapons can break down or jam at random intervals, it makes some sense to want to buy fresh ones that you can replenish. Seeing as how you run out of ammo fairly quick, there doesn't seem to be a need to buy those weapons; just grab them off the endless amounts of bodies you pile up.There is also the threat of malaria consuming you, which can make for some tense shootouts where a question of your mortality comes into play. Honestly, though, apart from some flashy effects on the screen, the whole malaria side of the game seems like an excuse to extend the length. You have to undertake missions devoid of originality to get more medication and it just ends up feeling like wasted time.I find it hard to remain angry at this game. It took me several months to muster up the desire to even see the conclusion, but the moments of bliss I encountered cannot be understated. I can't think of any game on current generation systems that even comes close to capturing the amount of freedom you are given.Developers love to throw around the claim that their game will allow you to "go anywhere and see anything." Ubisoft is pretty much the only one that let you do this. Traveling through most of Far Cry 2, though, you begin to wonder if you really want to see every facet of the map.All in all, I won't say the game is bad. I don't even think it's bad. While there are some crashes here and there, everything works as it should. Enemies are sometimes smart and I never fell through the gameworld. I just wished I could travel around faster. I would also have loved to have a sense that my actions were doing something.For the average gamer, though....I would take a pass. A game like Far Cry 2 takes a lot of maturity to conquer. It's joys are not quick and easy to obtain. A lot of effort needs to happen on the player's part to make anything of this game. If you're willing to sit through some rough terrain, you'll eventually find the diamond in the rough that lies at the core of Far Cry 2.6/10

												I got this after Far Cry 3 just to experience more of the series. This has a different feel than FC3. More of a raw, gritty, type of atmosphere that is frustratingly fun. Good story line and a nice selection of weapons. Guard shacks always respawn so it's never "safe" to just cruise down the road to your next objective. Random enemies patrolling in vehicles will constantly be a thorn in your side but that's part of the fun. Enemies aren't always easy to spot. They'll hide in the trees and shrubs and they're clothing will annoyingly blend in to the environment around them. I can't count the number of times I've nearly died just trying to figure out where the hell I'm being shot from. Nothing like thinking you have an area cleared out and then have a wounded mercenary sit up, pull a side arm and start giving one last ditch effort to off you.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												As far as I'm concerned, this was the game that addicted me to the "survival shooter" genre and I have never encountered another game with the same realistic-yet-stylised approach which both allowed the feeling of general superiority over enemies while still maintaining a sense of mortality and real danger. Not quite as gritty as S.T.A.L.K.E.R. but also not an overpowered player character experience like Crysis. Both are also great games, but this is the uniquely satisfying middle ground.Being an older game, it is more limited by its engine in many regards, such as enemies' strange ability to see the player from incredible distances and snipe with improbable accuracy, but forgiving it the wrinkles of it's age, it's still a great experience and one I would recommend to anyone interested in a realistically-influenced shooter without the complications of "hyper-realism".

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Jumping is crap and several diamond-filled briefcases are either impossible to get, or I lack the creativity and jumping skills to get them.With that out of the way, there is no game like Farcry 2. It is a game about violence. It is not a game about violence. You are the good guy out to kill the bad guy. You are the bad guy out to kill the good guy. You have friends, or do you? There is a moral choice; there is no moral choice. If you don't understand my mutterings, play the game and you will. For a game that provides chaotic combat and satisfying action, it also provides its thoughts on war and human nature. A wonderful game to play mindlessly, and a wonderful game to play knowing full well what you're doing in game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												Far Cry 2 is tedious, but if you value immersion above being fast-paced then you'd be hard pressed to find a better game. The empowerment you feel from playing the game comes from you persevering through mechanics that have been made more difficult than it is in typical FPS games by integrating real-world aspects, sometimes to unrealistic extremes. Playing through the campaign at max difficulty (makes you about as squishy as every NPC mook) with the music turned off (when you're on a far hill quietly picking off enemies one by one, hearing intense combat music play definitely throws you out of the moment).-Your "reputation" acts as your EXP level in the game, and generic NPC's react accordingly. Guards will tell you to f*ck off and frequently threaten you at the beginning of the game, but as you level up their dialogue will descend into professional respect and then to superstitious fear.-The HUD is very intentionally limited; the only onscreen effects are your health and ammo and they quickly fade when not in use. The map and compass have to be brought up like a weapon, and simulate a real paper map with pages of different scales. Sometime's it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to be at the very bottom of a map section and not be able to see a decent area around you, but it's frustration with something that would be in real life, not frustration with some contrived immersion-breaking game mechanic so it only adds to the immersion.-You have to drive everywhere on the map but destinations are often close together and the geocaching side-quests, constant threat of ambush, and the detail put into making the "HUD" map feel real keep transportation from being boring. It's a rush to be looking down at your map, hear a close gunshot, and jolt back to the road to see a patrol that just came around the corner.-Guns start to jam around after you fire your very limited ammo capacity, but it forces you to plan ahead like a true professional and make full use of your 3 weapons slots. Necessity is the mother of invention, and the situations where you're completely surrounded with everything but your pistol broken because you weren't efficient with your shots make the game memorable. Likewise, the feeling of satisfaction when an outpost hit comes together perfectly because you stored the right backup loadout in your safehouse really seals the deal that you're a true professional and an unstoppable force.-Despite the game's difficulty, it's very feasible to beat the game without dying. The PC's that you didn't choose to play as can be encountered in-game and and turned into allies, and will rescue you if your health drops to 0. They're not invincible though, and they needed to be protected then met in a safehouse if you want to be rescued again by them.Far Cry 2 quickly became one of my favorite games because of how it sucked me in, made me feel weak, and then let me slowly adapt to it until I truly felt like the hardcore motherf*cker that I was supposed to be playing. 10/10, would recommend to anyone who wants to get absolutely submerged in a game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												As far as I'm concerned, this was the game that addicted me to the "survival shooter" genre and I have never encountered another game with the same realistic-yet-stylised approach which both allowed the feeling of general superiority over enemies while still maintaining a sense of mortality and real danger. Not quite as gritty as S.T.A.L.K.E.R. but also not an overpowered player character experience like Crysis. Both are also great games, but this is the uniquely satisfying middle ground.Being an older game, it is more limited by its engine in many regards, such as enemies' strange ability to see the player from incredible distances and snipe with improbable accuracy, but forgiving it the wrinkles of it's age, it's still a great experience and one I would recommend to anyone interested in a realistically-influenced shooter without the complications of "hyper-realism".

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												I got this after Far Cry 3 just to experience more of the series. This has a different feel than FC3. More of a raw, gritty, type of atmosphere that is frustratingly fun. Good story line and a nice selection of weapons. Guard shacks always respawn so it's never "safe" to just cruise down the road to your next objective. Random enemies patrolling in vehicles will constantly be a thorn in your side but that's part of the fun. Enemies aren't always easy to spot. They'll hide in the trees and shrubs and they're clothing will annoyingly blend in to the environment around them. I can't count the number of times I've nearly died just trying to figure out where the hell I'm being shot from. Nothing like thinking you have an area cleared out and then have a wounded mercenary sit up, pull a side arm and start giving one last ditch effort to off you.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Jumping is crap and several diamond-filled briefcases are either impossible to get, or I lack the creativity and jumping skills to get them.With that out of the way, there is no game like Farcry 2. It is a game about violence. It is not a game about violence. You are the good guy out to kill the bad guy. You are the bad guy out to kill the good guy. You have friends, or do you? There is a moral choice; there is no moral choice. If you don't understand my mutterings, play the game and you will. For a game that provides chaotic combat and satisfying action, it also provides its thoughts on war and human nature. A wonderful game to play mindlessly, and a wonderful game to play knowing full well what you're doing in game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3
												Okay.. It's been a week since finishing FarCry2 and I'm still feeling it... PTSD? I'm some kind of traumatized from the constant barrage of everything breaking and going wrong, all the time. I must say.. I fell in love with it. FarCry2 is a devastating story and the gameplay constantly provoked me to act as one of the worst characters I've ever had to portray. Who knew there would be some moral plot twist in the end where I suddenly didn't feel so conflicted about everything I'd done?That's messed up. I was resigned, I actually had resigned from the game early on, but on returning to it, I was resigned to being the worst person in the world. Questions I was left with..What exactly does the FC2 story have in connection with Far Cry 1?My take away, The user experience has some incredibly refreshing feature. I love the map/gps system and how using it immerses me deeper into the environment instead of removing. I love the guns breaking and jamming. Overall, loved how clean the HUD system is, putting the focus on the environment.All the fetch quests that went back and forth over the same terrain/gaurdposts multiple times made my head spin. And at the same time, I appreciated the opportunity to improve on my routes of travel.Would I recommend this?Conditionally, yes. I would never simply recommend it. It's too brutal, frustrating and simply miserable. But I ended the experience having felt like I endured something that moved me. And that's special.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Beats the ♥♥♥♥ out of 3 in my opinion. This game is a lot like STALKER in that it doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ about you. It sort of throws you out into the world and says "Good luck." This isn't the cinematic "The world revolves around you" type of game FC3 was. There's no skill trees or press Q to heal all your HP (aside from limited syringes you carry 3 of that can only be replenished by finding them) or free wallhack or crafting system, but if you're into the hard as ♥♥♥♥ but extremely rewarding with various ways to be played type of game, then this is for you.There are a few things common complaints about this game for and I think they're exaggerated and full of♥♥♥♥♥♥Malaria - I seriously think people are just looking for♥♥♥♥♥♥to add to their list of ♥♥♥♥♥ing. Malaria turns your screen yellow and eventually killing you, and you have to take a pill to make it go away (you have 5-7 pills I forget exactly how many). This happens every 40 minutes to an hour I think. The game will warn you when you're on your last pill to, and they're easy to get (go to the church, church will tell you to rescue people a.k.a kill the 2-4 guards outside of a house, the people will give you the pills)Weapon jamming - I seriously don't even know how this was an issue for anyone. Heres how it works: If your gun is rusted as ♥♥♥♥ it's prone to jamming, and if it jams too many times it can break. Guns you find lying on the ground are always rusted to hell, and guns get from the store (which gives you an infinite supply to replace yours with) are always in mint condition. They take a LONG time to degrade. So if you run out of ammo and need to use an enemies gun then get ready for the risks.Driving all the way across the map with respawning bases- This is another thing that's exaggerated as ♥♥♥♥. There's a bus system, that's like the stider system in morrowind but free, that can take you to every corner of the map and the center. The only thing that might make it tedious is the respawning checkpoints, but if you use the bus system you'll only have to clear 1-3.Cars breaking down - I think this was an issue for me once every 5 hours of gameplay, and when my car did break down I just jacked the car from whoever shot it up.Here are the ACTUAL flaws with the game IMO:Enemy AI: The AI is so smart it's not even funny, but theres one key problem. If one enemy sees you they ALL see you, this means if one enemy can see you in a shed then his 5 friends know exactly where you are and shoot you through the shed. Not a serious problem unless you're in an area with permeable cover (kinda rare). This is a serious problem though when snipers show up. In farcry 3 the snipers have a laser, but they don't in 2, so later in the game when you get to snipers all the sudden the entire enemy base knows exactly where you are and you have no idea why.Repetition: This wasn't an issue for me because I usually mixed things up, but this game is VERY repetetive. You will visit very different elaborately layed out levels, but to do the same thing. There's basically 4 types of missions they give you (assassinate, blow up convoy, save people, blow up/steal something in a base). Sometimes you'll revisit the same area for a different type of mission. Most of the areas have 3 ways to approach them, and theres a variety of weapons to mix your playing style.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												Having already played far cry 3 and 4 i had a pretty bias/high expectations for this game but it did dissapoint in some areas. The story is fine but it's very linear style gets boring after a few hours and feels more like a call of duty campagin for example get the mission/ kill the guys and repeat. Athough its an open world game some points of the map makes you feel enclosed and forces you to stay near the roads. After 3 hours i got really board of driving everywhere, the game really discourages exploration in my opinion, the outpost can be scouted but the enemies never go away and that get annoying when you just wana get to your destination. the map lacks a lot of interative feature with very few side mission, unlockables, collectables, crafting, etc. in my 20 hours first play through i did very few side mission and barely explored after 3 hours. i will be generous since you can get this game for very cheap but i would not pay a full 60 for something that  in todays market the feels unfinshed. Far cry 3 basically used the same formula but makes an terrific campaign and a immersive world with many things to distract you from doing the main story .final verdict 7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Fun game, as with other posts, the AI is iffy.  But, I think they are trying to get the point across that these people are not trained soldiers and will shoot at shadows, some AI seem to work better than others, i e. the foreign mercs.  This game has a GTA feel to it, except in Africa, so everyone is hostile.  When I started the game I thought people would only be hostile if you were hostile to them.  No no no my friend.  Apparently, in Africa, everyone hates everyone.   The game is more blissful than pleasurable.  It keeps you thinking, the story doesnt explain what to do, it just goes.  My slavic buddy is a bullet magnet resulting in a morphene overdose.  The driving is fun, some of the random AI in Russian Ladas cruising the country side are jokes, as it seems these people are just like you, trying to make their way in a wasteland, only to have their dreams crushed under the weight of my 50 cal mounted machine gun.  IEDs are fun. (dont look too far into that Mr. NSA).  Ambushing is easier with camo upgrade.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Far Cry 2 is an open-world FPS. It's different from the original Far Cry (that was created by Crytek, and not Ubisoft) in that you can do pretty much whatever you want to. There is a story (though I haven't finished it, almost though) which is fairly good, it's not the greatest though. The main draw of the game is that you can wander around a fairly large map, and do nearly anything you want to. Blow up stuff, find animals, run over enemies with their own trucks, etc. It's a really fun game and definetly worth getting.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												It builds itself on being somewhat realistic, instead of hyperstimulating like its sequels. Hindering mechanics allow you to live out your mercenary power fantasy while still feeling vulnerable,and most of the mechanics are handled in game rather than in menus, so there's very little pausing. At the same time, it remains far simpler in formula compared to similar titles, like Stalker. Much of the game's open world has you doing side missions which, while sticking to very repeated formulas, are still very enjoyable. The faction and story missions, which offer choices within them, are sadly often served to the player in a fashion that gives the player very little choice at first, for example, forcing the player to work for a faction he may not want to. Other than that, it is very open-ended, allowing the player to make any decision about loadout, and almost any story choice. This can lead to permanent consequences if the player is not careful. The end of the game, while linear, neatly ties up the depressing (for all the right reasons) story, which is memorable because it is told through a combination of dialogue and the unique faction missions. Most notable is the deuteragonist, the Jackal, and how you learn most about him through the tapes and the dialogue of other characters.The stealth mechanic is something that is often brought up concerning this game. Many people say that stealth is pointless here, but I must disagree. It's not that stealth is futile; It's that stealth sometimes works in a very realistic manner, and sometimes the enemy can't tell when you accidentally almost step on his heel. Variable, yes, but I have not encounted the supposed clairvoyant AI this game has.Cons:-First, the AI. Having AI that relentlessly pursues in vehicles and takes cover when needed is one thing I wish more games of this style did, to make it feel dangerous, like there's really a group of lunatics chasing me. Then I saw a car full of baddies plunge off a cliff into a river, while I was safely standing several hundred feet away. Why they did this, I have no idea.-The graphics. It's not the brown and bloom I have a problem with. In fact, I'd say it sets a very good scene for the atmosphere of the game, and even if you don't want it, you can turn it off in the options. My problem is the pop-in. Maybe it's my toaster of a computer, maybe it's just the game, but it kills my immersion to see everything from billboards to distant hills jump in and out of existence, while enemies and vehicles stay in perfect focus, when I move all of a hundred feet. Also, some of the textures seem stretched, but at least they covered it up with foliage.-The sound. The music is too loud, while the talking is too quiet. This can be fixed in the options menu, but when I'm trying to have a talk with someone in a building while there's a firefight raging outside, and the voice of those outdoors are muffled, the voice of the guy talking indoors gets muffled in an identical way. Like, this dude standing two feet in front of me sounds like we're speaking through a wall.-Invisible walls. I'm not talking about the edges of the map. The game world needs to end somewhere, and it rarely encourages you to go out that far. The invisible walls on hills, ledges, and fences where it looks like I should be able to jump over simply do not allow it. Why these could not have been covered by actual objects, I do not know.-Ubisoft account requirement for a lot of the features. Multiplayer requires a Ubisoft account, as does the promotional content and mapshare (which is sad, because this mapmaker is one of the easiest to use and gives very fine results).-Programming errors. Sometimes music tracks loop endlessly if a game is loaded under certain circumstances, requiring a trip back to the main menu, and then another load to the game.The Jackal Tapes are also a bit bugged. Every tape I picked up after the one about the boy with the boots has been about the boy with the boots. Thank heavens for YouTube.When I take a bus into some of the ceasefire zones, especially later in the game, sometimes a soldier on patrol in the town will just spontaneously die for no reason. It even happened to the APR doorman at Mosate Selao, and the game claimed I broke the ceasefire, so I had to leave and come back to make everyone once again nonhostile.Other than that, the game is an experience like few others. If you want an open world game that gives you something to do, that makes you actually feel in danger, that punishes you for not taking it seriously, this is for you.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Far Cry 2 is a handful of good ideas buried under one of the most repetitive games I've ever played. Given the recent trend of reviewers re-examining it and declaring it some sort of misunderstood masterpiece I decided to buy it again (I'd lost my disk ages back) and give it another go. As I remembered it mostly consists of driving a vehicle backwards and forwards around the same parts of the map with the same 3-4 annoying AI troops respawning in the exact same areas and attacking you. If killed they'll simply respawn in their checkpoint ready to chase you next time and ignoring them simply results in them following you forever.Degradation is a nice idea but once your weapons have degraded you have to DRIVE BACK to the arms dealer again since picking up extra weapons from dead enemies is worthless (they are always in horrible condition). To even get weapons in the armoury you have to:A. Do a side mission to unlock the weapons for purchase (more driving to get there and back).B. Find diamonds to pay for the weapons (even more ♥♥♥♥ing driving).You do get small moments of fun now and then. Stealth, for example, sometimes works brilliantly but just as often the AI decides to spot me at random and then everyone in the area will magically know your position. I've got nothing against harder stealth but STALKER did it better even with its flaws. Some of the missions are fun too but most are fairly forgettable firefights.The game would likely have worked much better as a series of linear missions with a semi-open map for each (i.e. Far Cry 1). As usual open world here just means repetitive and empty.Buddy mechanics and the general atmosphere are the only good points but all the atmosphere in the world couldn't make up for the complete boredom of actually playing this game.Finally to add insult to injury the game is buggy as♥♥♥♥♥♥ particularly the tutorial. Activating the DLC is an annoyance also. You might have to spend 1-2 hours hunting for fixes and replaying the unskippable intro/tutorial until it works (10+ minutes every time). As mentioned above the AI also varies between being completely blind and cheating depending largely on their alert status.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Should have been called driving across Africa.  Fast travel points (bus stations) are scattered and trips to the gun merchant feel unnecessary (should just phone in your order and have them waiting for you at your safe house).  Checkpoints are all over which is okay, but you can't shoot from your car unless on multi-player so you need to hop out at every one in addition to every single car on the road that immediately knows to kill you.  I would have liked an option to bribe guards with uncut diamonds as well, but that isn't an option.  Your safe house weapon crates contain one extra weapon of each type which you have to drop in there from the armory attached to the gun shop - so any of my dozen safe houses magically have a copy of the weapon, but I have to go back to the armory when the weapon breaks after enough use or I'm tired of it jamming all the time?Companions - there doesn't seem to be any point to doing their missions.  They add 1-2 small tasks to gain history with them, but then they easily die and also do not offer anything for having a high history.  Buddy rescue - where they come and save you after you get owned has a long cutscene you can't skip - you also don't cue your buddy rescue up until after you hit the safe house again instead of just automatically after some time.Missions are dull and repetitive - same mission for meds or gun runner every single time!  You also have to appear in person to start every story mission which just drags it out.  Your stealth options are a little limited as well.This game was probably okay in 2008, but really doesn't hold to current standards of a run and gun game.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												This was my absolute favorite game for a time on my Xbox 360, I've probably played atleast 100 hours of the game on Xbox. It's such an immersive world, it really feels like you are in Africa. The guns jamming are a great addition too and the fact that you have malaria is strangely awesome because it adds an element not found in other games; the constant chase for medicine and having to take pills mid-fight. I love the weapon upgrade system and the way that diamonds are the currency too. The game is a bit dated now and some features we are used to today don't exist, for example the world isn't very persistent. If you clear out a whole outpost, the enemies will just respawn so you have to clear it out or just drive straight through everytime you pass the outpost which is very aggrovating sometimes. Nevertheless it's a superb game and imo it's better than Far Cry 3 in some ways, not all though of course. More than absolutley worth it's price.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												This is an awful game in almost every aspect... So let's try and summarise it...- Since you are in Africa, and as we all know it, when you are in Africa, everything must be filtered through some awful brownish/yellowish colour to remind you... That you are in Africa... Or Mexico, or wherever... It is not pleasant for eyes...- Enemy AI goes from completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mushroom IQ to ultra intelligent super computer/robot from far future with integrated infra red/night vision/cat's ears...- About 50% of time fighting, you will turn around like an idiot, trying to pinpoint exact location of enemy who is shooting...- Once you shoot at them, they are able to see you even if you are laying silently in 1 meter high grass...- And, if that was not enough, once you clear out an enemy camp, return 10 minutes later, everyone are alive and kicking! ♥♥♥♥ yeah! :)- Missions... Oh, side missions... Every mission is the same... They tell you some completely irrelevant back story, and tell you to kill/destroy someone... You go to the mission location, there are 2-3 cars and usually a truck going in circles (!?)... Destroy the truck, and TA-DA, diamonds are automatically in your pocket!- Talking about cars... There are, I don't know, maybe 4 different vehicles in game... I cannot find any difference between them when driving...- And talking about driving... Wow, since most of the map is awful brownish terrain, you won't feel like exploring... There is nothing to explore, world is ugly (except for few exceptions), you will end up driving from one part of the map to the other all the time... Especially since missions are almost always as far from as they can be, from the point you took them... There are some bus stations, but they are so rare, it's easier to just drive...- Also, player character has a malaria... So, from time to time, you'll need to take pills, or survive through vertigo effects... It might be important for story, but I still have a feeling that it is too burdensome for gameplay...- As, it is usually a problem with games, main character is a mute retard...And now for Pros;- It has a QUIT button. I really tried to like this game, but...Yeah, it's actually one of the games I cannot find any good thing about; it's boring, repetitive and full of little problems and bugs... It's obnoxious...TL;DR: Don't.... just... Don't...

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												1-3/2016 Original Review:Picture Dead Island.  Now, take away all the zombies, skill trees, interesting characters, and set the game in Africa.  Hey look, you've got Far Cry 2, a game with a meaningless protagonist who loves doing people's chores!  I get why people could enjoy this game, but I really didn't.  I have yet to finish the game and I'm dreading having to press on.  Here's some pros and cons to help you understand why:Pros:-Absolutely beautiful atmosphere/map.  Looking out over a desert, lake, or bayou at sunset is amazing.-This game's multiplayer was my childhood, and the custom maps feature is awesome.  Playing escape maps with friends online holds some great memories for me.  Unfortunately, online play for this game is near dead now, but if you can get a chance to play some custom maps with friends they're fun.Cons:  Oh god, where do I start.  -Gameplay wise, get ready for some repetition.  Talk to an NPC, get a quest, drive to the other side of the damn map (or use the poorly implemented quick travel system), shoot people or blow something up, rinse & repeat.  It feels like a sin for a game with such a vast environment to feel so slow, dry, and outright boring.-This game is literally driving Simulator 2009 edition.  You have to drive so much, only to be interrupted halfway to your destination which feels 35253 miles away by some random mercenary who thought it'd be tactical to literally ram the hell into you.  This occurs WAY too often and gets extremely annoying.  -The game is divided into two acts.  The problem with this, is by the end of act one the game feels like it's ready to end.  But it doesn't.  It goes into act two.  This literally made my jaw drop.  I was so ready to be done with this driving simulator.-If you're looking for a good story, don't come here.  In the beginning of the game, your character gets an idea in their mind of what they want to do.  Without spoiling anything, I'll say that at literally EVERY opportunity they get to carry out their objective, they're hindered physically (in pain, can't move, etc etc).  Total bs.  If this was the main goal of the game, I'd go to think they'd lift a finger a little more.  I think at the point in the game I'm currently at I can see why the protagonist might be changing their mind about killing the Jackal, but since our character doesn't talk we have no way of knowing their intentions.  Overall if you're a fan of the Far Cry series give this a whirl.  Otherwise stay away, stay far away.  5/101-7/2016 UPDATE:I've been trying to finish this game, and oh has it been hard.  Not gameplay difficulty wise, but hard as in difficult to sit through this p.o.s...This game is a perfect example of where a company threw the golden rule of games out the window: Gameplay over Graphics.  This game is gorgeous, but the gameplay is dry and repetative, not fun at all no matter how many different ways there are to approach missions.  This is because they're all the same exact thing, as I discussed in my older review above.  This game crashes constantly for me.  I was able to deal with this, up until now.  I have a few different save files that I've been making throughout the game just as a safety, and boy I'm glad I did.  I was at 88% game completion on my primary save, and I thought, I haven't saved in a while, I better save before end game!  Guess what?  I went to save, the game crashed, my heart sank.  "No," I thought to myself , "please don't let my save be corrupted."  Sure enough, it was.  Back to 73% game completion for me.  I get to do all those repetitious missions over again.  Woo-hoo.  I may add more comments when I do manage to finish this glitchy pile of crap.  But, until then, this is me signing out, advising you to not waste your time on this installment of the Far Cry franchise.1-7/2016 UPDATE 2 (Several hours later):Well, I did it.  I managed to finish the game.  I managed to combat losing my save progress by creating multiple new save files instead of overwriting the same one.  The ending of the game is o.k, but certainly not very good.  Before the ending, the game tries to make you feel as though your choices throughout the second half of the game meant something, but really it just decides slight aesthetic differences (who's present at the end, etc).  I'm in a love/hate relationship with the fact that  all of your friends that you helped throughout the game turn on you and betray you, and you have to in turn murder all of them.   It's a twist that attempts to show the true nature of the world you're in, but also makes little sense after all you've been through.Even the final choice in the game makes no difference whatsoever.  Choice is a complete illusion in this game, which is lame.  I went back to my save just before the final choice and tried the other option, the game ends exactly the same no matter which errand you decide to run.Overall, having finished the game, my opinion isn't very changed.  The ending doesn't redeem the poor gunplay.  It doesn't redeem the annoying as hell A.I. who shoot me on sight without good reason, and who ram my car with their every 5 minutes which made driving so unenjoyable.  The voice acting is shoddy and there's only one or two people who seem to have actually tried to sound convincing.  Neither of this people are the main antagonist, either.It's just not a very good game.Remember Devs, Gameplay over Graphics.Revised score: 3/10P.S:  I hit uninstall on the game and the game opened.  What?
