number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												As far as I'm concerned, Far Cry 2 deserves to be remembered alongside the venerated classics of the genre; Half-Life, Deus Ex, Bioshock, and all those other semi-legendary shooters. But at the same time, it's not entirely surprising that it isn't remembered that way.To use a really crappy pun, Far Cry 2 is, in many ways, a rough diamond. It might not shine, but it's just as solid and precious as any other of its kind.Let's start with the good, and the first good thing right off the bat about the game is the setting and atmosphere. How many other shooters take place in sub-Saharan Africa? It's a brilliant premise that's rarely explored in the genre. A war-torn, hostile, exotic setting populated by power-hungry warlords and psychotic mercs? There aren't many other real-world scenarios that would work better as an environment in which to set a shooter of this style, and I find it much more memorable than the exaggerated, tropical setting of Far Cry 3. By Far Cry 4 I was entirely disinterested in the franchise, and never played that game or any later ones. So I can't say anything about them. Far Cry 2's fictional setting is very believable, and the originality and thought put into it is apparent from the get-go.To go along with the great atmosphere are some genuinely impressive visuals, which might sound weird to those who have only briefly played the game. The vanilla color palette is just plain awful, but the effects, textures, models and shaders are all top-notch for a 2008 title, and the Dunia engine has a few nice tricks up its sleeve. A little tweaking with the Sweetfx shader suite goes a long way towards rectifying the brown, muddy colors and is absolutely essential to getting the most out of the graphics and the overall experience, and with the right tweaks the game has massive visual appeal to this day, even compared to some contemporaries like Crysis that are more well-known for their visuals. The graphics are stylized yet realistic without ever really feeling uncanny or too outdated. Again-aside from the questionable color palette-the care put into the visuals is apparent right from the start.All this would just be academic if not for gameplay to truly make the game worthwhile, and FC2 surely delivers in that regard as well. I've always considered Far Cry 2 to be a minimalist shooter, which might sound bizarre when you consider the massive, open world and whatnot. But at its core, there are only a few core elements driving the gameplay here. No shoehorned RPG elements, no crafting, very little NPC interaction, no player-influenced dialogue, not even much of a story. This minimalist, almost barebones approach to gameplay? Well, quite frankly, it's just plain fantastic. One thing I really disliked about Far Cry 3 was the degree of artificial progression in it. By which I mean the skill trees and crafting- this doesn't add flavor to the game as everyone ends up getting everything by the end and it just limits early-game creativity. One term that frequently comes to mind when I think about Far Cry 2 is "emergent gameplay;" that is, progression that is directed by the player instead of the game. There are unlocks and upgrades, yeah, and there is a reason to get them, but the most prominent progression in the game is that of your own playstyle. You start to learn what weapons, what routes, what tactics work the best for you and work from there- instead of being given a list of skills for your character. I'm a huge fan of the concept of character proficiency, but it just doesn't belong in a game like this, and the fact that Far Cry 2 is so aware of that is really refreshing. You never feel truly forced into a gameplay style or scenario you genuinely dislike, a problem many open-world games suffer from.The AI in Far Cry 2 is absolutely insane, to say the least. It's way too smart for its own good much of the time, and while this might seem cheap at times, it's also an excellent catalyst for the aforementioned emergent gameplay and player-directed progression. I remember starting out my initial play through trying to get up close and personal and stealthy, but the AI just isn't stupid enough for that to work. So I shifted to a more distant playstyle- sniping, picking off enemies, constantly on the move- interspersed with aggressive, ballsy assaults when the situation called for it or my position was compromised. Part of the gameplay is learning the AI's tricks and figuring out what works best for you. The AI is advanced enough that there are no glaring exploits to make the game too easy, but at the same time, if you're expecting a stealth shooter you're going to be disappointed. It really contributes to a feeling of overall cerebrality- you can be great at shooters but if you don't plan your moves you won't get far. It's worth mentioning by now that I've been playing with a realism mod on Infamous difficulty, which really is the only way to play as far as I'm concerned. The enemies are a little too spongy in vanilla, but the setup I use can be brutally difficult yet is rarely ever unfair. The gameplay requires analysis and personal experience and I can admit I was frustrated early game that nothing I did seemed to work- probably one of the biggest reasons this game isn't better remembered- but when you get it down the core gameplay is both elegantly simple and constantly engaging, while always feeling personally rewarding.Moving onto some of the weaker points, the sound design is a mixed bag, with guns sounding stock and animations not always syncing properly with sounds, but the ambient noise, dynamic soundtrack and enemy chatter are all pretty memorable.It was at this point in the review I ran out of mentally pre-rehearsed stuff to say. I'm not good at properly reviewing stuff. But yeah this game's rad so play it if it sounds like something you'd play.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Well, here is a guy, that recommends the game even though he rarely enjoyed it and stuck at the 21. main mission because of a bug, that doesn't let him shoot any gun. I tried to load earlier saves but to no avail. After I got the 21. mission it came back again, so I had to quit.Anyways here is my review:+The graphics are decent.+The environment is really beautiful. You got deserts, forests, mountains, rivers, cliffs. It is a joy to wander about.+There is different types of vehicles, which we are able to fix.+A good variety of weapons and upgrades, that we can unlock with our gems. The gems are gained through missions or searching.+The map is big.+Your old weapons and the ones that you get from your enemies after you killed them can break down or might not function properly, which I found really realistic.+There are buddies, that let you finish the mission some other way and help you sometimes when you are on the verge of getting killed.-As I said earlier, there are some bugs that stop you from completing the game. -Literally three quarter of the game consists of driving. The map is huge and you have to drive to everywhere or use the bus. But there is only five bus stops in the game. They are at the four corner of the map and one in the middle, so not very convenient.-The story isn't that interesting. Classical civil war story. (I can tell because it is my second playthough, I played it once when I was younger)-The voice acting is horrible. The accents are poor and everybody talks very fast without intonation. So it is a little bit hard to understand them, if English is not your native tongue or if you're not very competent.-There is two factions in the game, where we get our missions from. We do missions for both of them but even the soldiers of the faction, that we currently do the mission for, attack us because " it's a classified mission." Well, I could say okay for a couple of missions but every freaking one of them is the same so it doesn't make sense and becomes annoying fighting the both.-There are enemy posts that we can scout after we kill everyone in there BUT they respawn after 5 minutes so you have to kill them every time you pass by and believe me you will pass by a lot because the game is a freaking driving simulator. You can of course pass by without stopping and killing them but they come with vehicles to shoot at you so you can't actually run away if you aren't lucky. I mean it is good because it gives a challenge but it starts to get on the nerves after a while.As I said earlier, I recommend the game even though I couldn't enjoy it that much but I feel like everybody should at least give it a try to see for themselves. I really don't know why I recommend it. :)So this was my review. I hope you enjoyed reading it.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												By far the most boring game I have ever played.I'm still amazed I managed to complete the campaign, despite hours and hours of unbelievably tedious and repetitive missions given by some of the the most uninspired and poorly voice-acted characters in the history of gaming.It's a shame too, because the world Ubisoft Montreal built here was remarkably beautiful.  But such beauty can hardly be appreciated when it's guarded by dozens of outposts populated by ever-respawning enemies who will always shoot you on sight - regardless of your current allegiance to their faction (!!!).Add to that the fact that fast-travelling is very limited in this game, and that most missions require you to go from point A to point B using the same routes over and over, and you got yourself one of the least pleasant experiences you could imagine as far as first-person shooters go.Honestly, I can't stress this enough. Avoid Far Cry 2 at all costs. If you're planning on going through the entire series and are afraid you'll miss out on important bits of story, don't worry: these games aren't connected in any way.

												Pros:- nice safari-jungle-desert atmosphere- fire propagation is nice (but vastly useless once you know how to properly attack the enemies from a distance)- that's all, nothing else is good in that game >_<Cons:- 80% of time spent driving ; the driving doesn't have anything special nor pleasant about it, it's just a damn chore- 15% of the time spent killing guards that will respawn as soon as you step 300 meters away of them (sense of achievement & progression : none)- 5% spent on the actual missions which all can be resumed to : jump into that camp/village/factory and kill everybody in 3 or 4 minutes with nearly zero variety- it takes 3 or 4 headshots to kill someone (fortunately, there's "Dylan's Far Cry 2 Realism Mod" to fix that)- unlike Far Cry 1, there's no indoor fighting- Fast travel is almost useless, as there are very few bus stations where you can activate it- world feels actually empty  : the only inhabitants around are mercenaries shooting you on sight without knowing you're enemy or ally, they just shoot non-stop- story... hum, is there one ?- bugs, plenty of bugs : levitating, teleporting, shaking and/or rotating head NPC ; suiciding soldiers (coz they hit a tree or a stone?!?) ; unresponsive NPC ; etc...- no possibility to walk & fight with an ally (there's only 15 seconds of vaguely team fight when reaching an ally in need for help)I usually never stop to play a game till I reach the end, but this one, I just couldn't bear the non-stop driving anymore...It's hard to believe that only 1 year and half after this FC2, Just Cause 2 was released ; a game that is so so much better & complete & polished & fun than FC2...

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												A great core game clogged up by glitches and poorly designed filler.PROS:+ Guns are FANTASTIC! (Before entering real combat, that is.) Large variety. Animation's decent, sound effects are excellent, and they tear up landscape pretty good. Poorly maintained guns jam and misfire in varying ways. Firing guns in this game leaves me with a headache and ringing ears... in a good way.+ Certain aspects are very immersive. You're stuck in Africa. You haven't much to rely on beyond your non-pausing map, health syringes, and safe havens. Ammo and health can burn quickly. Keep moving and stay alive.+ Asthetically, the map is good. Feels like Africa based on the five or six Nationa Geographic shots I've seen.+ As many have said, fire is fun. Tall grass and foliage burn up quickly and in large quantities.+ Visuals haven't aged too poorly. Very serviceable considering the years this game has on it.+ Some neat dynamic enemy behavior. They talk between each other during combat appropriate to what just happened. They'll sling their wounded buddies over their shoulder and run for cover.+ The malaria pill fetching reminded me of Zombrex in Dead Rising 2... which was a better game I'd been reminded I could be playing.CONS: - Enemy AI sporadically changes between dirt dumb and brilliant. Enemies can miss shots within three feet of you, but nail you in your moving vehicle a hundred yards away. Enemies can not detect you when you crouch right next to them, but discover you crouched in tall grass from a hundred yards away. Weapons they nail you with across the map are pitifully inaccurate when you pick them up and use them youself. They can even detect you THROUGH COVER, often shooting through thinner walls nailing you perfectly.- Not all guns do not behave predictably. Multiple close quarters headshots with 7.62 ammunition can serve to just stun an enemy. An entire pistol magezine loaded into an enemy's body still has him up and about shooting.- The map is littered with enemy holdouts. Not a problem in Far Cry 3. When you invade these incampments in FC3, you can clear them out, permanently. In this game, killing everyone in the outpost means: They all respawn! Not even ten real life minutes later! Over sixty of these ♥♥♥♥ing things are upon every major road and water way. If you want to drive for more than two minutes, you'll run into one of these encampments. Your best bet is to floor it through them, and even that doesn't work well. Enemies chip away at your health every time you drive past. Often they'll scramble a vehicle to follow you. No firing weapons in vehicles, your best defense is to bail out, shoot your persuers, repair your car for the umptenth time, and keep moving.- As many have said, Malaria is an arbitrary difficulty complication. Another example of where this game favors "realism" over "immersion". Every 30 real life minutes you suffer an incurable malaria attack. To not pass out and restart at a safehouse, you need to take Malaria pills. You CAN NOT acquire these pills willingly! You need to progress through the story to get them! Should you decide you want to do the side content for a couple hours, get used to passing out and restarting every once in a while.- Not much to do outside of the main story. Side missions pretty much always consist of killing everyone in an enemy camp or blowing up a vehicle.- Story's thread bare. That doesn't matter too much. What DOES matter pretty much every character is horridly voice acted. The actors sound like text-to-speech machines; monotone and rarely giving appropriate inflections. For some strange reason, the game often speeds up their lines as well. They talk as if commas and periods don't exist.- Random bugs. I've encountered bugs where unpausing causes you to automatically throw a grenade, one where switching to my primary weapon caused my character to start walking to the right for some reason, bugs where vehicles would automatically reverse when I entered them. They all fixed themselves when I restarted the game, but it was rather odd and annoying that they were there in the first place.I wanted to enjoy this game. I was told "Far Cry 3 without the handholding." At its core, this game is solid. Little design flaws like braindead AI and the constant attacks from guard outposts every five minutes become incredibly bothersome when the game is littered with them. Stealth is almost nonfunctional. Loud combat is buggy but sometimes servicable. "Immersion" in this game boils down to something like a Grand Theft Auto game where cops won't come after you for murder but will give you a speeding ticket without fail. The unfun components (malaria, cars frequently breaking down, enemies tracking you) compromise the often-breaking components of fun.My only consolation is I bought this for $2.49. Buy this game on sale if you like unpredictable non-stop hordes of dumb enemies and tearing up the African desert in a boastfully product-placed Jeep.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												This game is made infuriating by the enemies who have perfect aim and will hit you from hundreds of meters away, behind foliage, during the night. There are enemy camps littered all over the map and you can't just drive through them; not only will the enemies start shooting at you instantly, they will even give chase. You can clear out the camps but as far as I can tell they get repopulated as soon as you leave.You have to constantly stop your travels to deal with the camps, and clearing them out isn't even a challenge, it's just boring; it does however make exploration feel like a slog, which is not a good thing in an open world game.At one point I was exploring the wilderness during the night, far away from any camps, when all of a sudden a jeep came at me from nowhere and three guys started shooting at me. Not only is this frustrating but it's also immersion breaking, which is sad because the game really tries to provide an immersive experience. I liked that you have to use a physical map and that the camera stays first person during driving.If the enemies would be less aggressive and they couldn't see you through foliage this game would be a lot more enjoyable. At this point the best thing about it is that it doesn't use Uplay.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												This game was quite a slog to me, and the only reason I finished was because I am a bit of a completist. It is quite a long game, especially if you finish all side missions. Playing on and off for a few weeks and using a map showing all diamond case locations, I got through the campaign in about 25 hours. I think my main issue was that every mission was the exact same. Blow this up or kill that person. I do enjoy 'splosions and assassination missions, but nothing changes in the world as you go through the campaign, so playing them gets mundane quickly. The world itself is large. I loved the day/night cycle and weather. The thing that aggravated me the most about traveling in this world was the rapidly respawning guard shacks. You wipe out everyone in the area, drive down the road for a bit, turn back around, and voila, everyone is back. It feels like an annoying tactic to make the game last longer than it should. I'd understand guards being there after 6 in-game hours or something, but just getting out of sight of the area shouldn't prompt automatic respawns. Far Cry 2 was quite a change from the original. While I appreciated some changes, the lack of an engaging narrative and repetitive missions/opponents made this game more of a bore the longer it lasted.5/10

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												After about a day of playing this, I went to Google and entered "how to have fun in Far Cry 2".  And then I reflected on what a bizarre thing I had just done.  But for such a good-looking game, the fun seems to be hard to find.  I even considered that that might be the point; actually contracting malaria in a war-torn hellhole where you must kill or be killed wouldn't actually be much fun.The game felt repetitive far too quickly for my tastes; you accept a quest from somebody, then drive from point A to point B (walking is far too slow.)  Along the way you'll likely pass two checkpoints on the road; no you can't avoid them by travelling off-road.   Each checkpoint has a few goons who would like to kill you, so you kill them.  Then you arrive at point B, where there are a few goons that would like to kill you, so you kill them.  Killing everyone at Point B usually accomplishes the quest goal, so now you must just return to point A, except that those damned checkpoints have already repopulated, so you need to murderdeathkill their residents over again just to get back.   The majority of the game, as I found it, was shooting my way through the same checkpoints over and over again.Part of the misery of the situation is that you will spend a certain amount of time trying to fight with crappy, unreliable firearms.  You will be able to purchase reliable guns that perform well at your safehouses, but for some reason you are unwilling to bring enough ammo for all the butchery that a typical quest demands, so at some point you will end up dropping your well-maintained and functional firearm in favour of a fallen foe's rusted-out jam-prone piece of scrap metal.  You will then have the joy of finishing the quest with this vaguely gun-like object, because continual weapon jams in difficult situations are an essential part of the experience.That's my Far Cry 2 experience: repetitive, unrewarding shootouts, weapon jams, and malaria.  Subjectively, the experience is cohesive and thematic -- it feels as though the creators successfully realized their vision -- it just wasn't enjoyable to play.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I'm generally a fan of free-roam first-person shooters, but Far Cry 2 was a big disappointment. If you're a hardcore shooter fan that likes a challenge, solid gunplay, diverse gameplay, and refreshing mechanics, this isn't the shooter for you.Nearly every quest boils down to "drive to the other side of the map and kill some people / blow something up". There is no variety in enemies - you face thugs with low health and bad AI toting rifles, or thugs with low health and bad AI toting shotguns, or thugs driving trucks with mounted machine guns on the back. There is very little recoil to any of the automatic weapons, which really hurts the gunplay. As a result, none of the traditional firearms are fun or interesting - if you are in it for the grenade launchers, double-barrel shotguns, and flamethrowers, you might have more fun than I did. The game is pathetically easy even with the difficulty maxed - I had to install a mod that further increases the difficulty and weapon recoil just to feel like I wasn't playing a kids' game. The only moments when the game is difficult are when the AI is cheating - bullets can penetrate sheet metal and thin wood, which is cool, but the enemies can see through anything they can shoot through. Taking cover in a shack or some brush is signing your own death warrant, because your enemies will continue shooting you accurately even though you can't see them. This isn't some intelligent "he went into that shack so I'll shoot at the shack" AI - they can just see through walls, and they'll do it whether or not anyone saw you enter.The game certainly has its moments - the first time I was rescued by a buddy was one of the most memorable experiences I've had in gaming (but the buddy-rescue system quickly gets stale and sometimes becomes a nuisance when you have to babysit your buddy for 20 ****ing minutes so they don't get killed). The large and diverse landscape is a refreshing change from the scenery in most shooters - you certainly feel like you're in Africa. I found the unique realism elements - the map you physically hold in front of you in the game (accurately simulates crashing while looking down at the map!) repairing vehicles, weapons that degrade in quality, and fire propagation, very interesting. There isn't much of a story to the game - you can take random copy-and paste quests all over the map (I am not joking about copy-and-paste) or take story quests from either of the two factions in the central town. Neither faction represents the "good" side, so I felt no connection with the events in place beyond getting paid diamonds to complete missions. I guess that's how a mercenary would look at things, but it doesn't make for an engaging game in my case.Far Cry 2 has some good ideas, but overall the game doesn't quite click for me. On the other hand, there are a lot of positive reviews for it, so your milage may vary.

												Pros:+ Fantastic Engine+ Runs smooth even on weaker pc's+ Excellent Graphics even in 2015+ Large open world+ You can burn the environments and start huge wildfires+ Decent variety of firearms. Negatives:- Everything respawns, if you leave a camp 40 metres the whole camp will respawn and shoot at you again- Change in difficulty just gives enemies more health. - Roaming patrols will regulary shoot your vehicle every few minutes possibly leaving you stranded- Cannot shoot from vehicles- Story is very poorly executed and feels like an after thought. - Game breaking bugs exist that may mean you cannot progress story. - Very repetitive gameplay - Little variety in vehicles/npc's - Buddy missions are poorly implemented.- Malaria- Modding cannot fix the aboveMy suggestion is give this one a miss, My reasoning is that FC2 will likely frustrate you more than give you any type of enjoyment; should you choose to ignore my warning be gentle on yourself and use one of the realism mods. FC2 was very close to something brilliant, but fell short in just a few areas which make it a less than enjoyable experience very quickly.

												Reading the description of this game it sounded great. Open world mercenary shooter in a lawless and rebellious part of Africa. whats not to like. Well, quite a lot actually. From the description i was very much looking forward to discovering some interesting missions and dialogue getting me engrossed in the role of the mercenary that you play. Unfortunately the game just does not deliver. Within about 2 hrs of pay i found myself thinking i've done this before. To give an example, to get better weapons the weapons dealer will send you to blow up his competition, EVERYTIME! Still not sure if his competition ever got the message. Threre are also a lot of go and kill someone missions. You never really know why your going to kill them, but by the time you arrive its kill or be killed so you better get killing. I found this quite droll. It would also be good if the factions would stop shooting at you everytime they see you. There are no civilians so it just seems like the entire continent of Africa wants you dead for no apparent reason. This plus the unconvincing dialog and set locations leaves the game lacking and not giving an convincing open world feel.

												Far Cry 2 ist eines meiner absoluten Lieblingsspiele, einfach weil es immer wieder eine neue Entdeckung ist. Ich muss immer wieder aufs Neue Wege suchen, wie ich hierhin komme um dann möglichst gefahrlos zum nächsten Punkt zu kommen.Grafisch vielleicht nicht up-to-date und kann sicher nicht mit Far Cry3 mithalten, aber ich finde die Grafik immer noch sehr schon und genieße die Umgebung der Wüste, auch bei Nacht sehr schön anzusehen.Ein absolutes Plus sind auch die Kommentare der gegnerischen KI, denen ich immer sehr gerne zuhöre. Auch ein ganz großes Plus gegenüber Far Cry 3, denn dort ist es immer derselbe Synchronsprecher der die einfachen Soldaten vertont.Richtig gut finde ich auch die Verteilung der Diamantenkoffer, denn dadurch muss ich immer etwas haushalten und überlegen. ob ich mir das Gesundheitsupgrade wirklich jetzt kaufe oder lieber später, da mir eine schwierige Mission bevorsteht bei der ich schallgedämpfte Waffen brauche. Bezahlt wird mit Rohdiamanten, die man zwar überall finden kann, die Anzahl der tatsächlich enthaltenen Diamanten aber zwischen 1-3 Steinen variiert.Der einzigste Minuspunkt ist leider die Physik oder was auch immer bei dem Spiel nicht stimmt. Teilweise werden Gegenstände oder Personen wie aus dem Nichts angehoben und fallen dann herunter.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												FC2 is a game that tries very hard to be different from its predecessor (which was developed by Crytek, this isn't) and to be an open world RPG, with choices, secondary missions, buddies and upgradable weapons but, sadly, it's not very good at any of that. The choices feels fake and useless, the gameplay is repetitive, the "story" is forgettable, the protagonist is... let's say not very likable, the environment is not that "open", it's way too long (30-40 hours) for it gameplay style, weapons continuously rust and break (forcing you to repeatly getting new one after every mission) and the enemies take way too many bullets to die (and respawn when you leave and re-enter an area minutes later).So, I don't feel like suggesting this game (if not with a discount). I see that the dev tried to simulate a realistically hostile environment but I believe that the result is way too "serious". A game is supposed to be fun at the very end and to me, FC2, wasn't for a big chunk of it. I keep playing hoping for something new to happen, something interesting, unexpected (no, I wasn't hoping for monsters, mutants or aliens) but no, life is tough in FC2: you are in Africa, sick with Malaria and surrounded by people who wants to kill each other; not a pretty picture but sadly, a realistic one.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												The game delivers a cliché look at Africa as it's presented in popular media. It's a dull and beaten vision with no wonders to uncover or surprises to stumble onto. Though it looked great at it's heyday, the years have not been kind to it. The game has aged terribly having both the design and mechanics feel old and tired. I can see how they wanted to create this huge open-world game but didn't really have anything to fill it with so they just cluttered the map with all the same stuff. As the result you'll get a game where you've seen it all after a couple hours of gameplay. It does have it's moments, like the brutal self-surgeries that you have to perform or the jamming weapons that make the battles feel more real but those sparks are drowned in the myriad of flaws the game has to offer.Every...Single...Misson follows same pattern:1. Get mission.2. Drive to the other side of Africa.3. Grind through endless guard posts.4. Repair car.5. Repeat steps 3 & 4 till you contract malaria from playing the game.6. Take malaria pill.7. Kill a village-full of sharp-shooters.8. Save game or you have to do it all over again because there's no autosave. 9. Get new mission AND DO EXACTLY THE SAME THING ALL OVER AGAIN!The Battles:- A.I. always knows where you are, even if you switch positions.- Enemies have perfect aiming, even from hundreds of meters away, in the middle of the night!- You can not guess from what direction you are being shot at. You could not even tell if you are moving towards the shooter, or away from him!- You get shot the very second you peek from behind a cover. - Enemies who speak to each other sound like they are just around the corner even if they are far away.- Enemies are able to hit you in the middle of the night, with a shotgun, from a hundred meters away, from behind an house!The game's full of bugs too:- Mission givers heads shake like crazy when you interact with them.- Random guy fell from the sky to his death in front of me.- In bar objects floating without table underneath.- Misson givers voice and gestures occasionally out of place.- A.I. shooting you from behind the cover.- Fixed machine guns fail to hit targets at close range, rendering them completely useless.- Enemy shooting AND hitting you while having his back turned towards you.Verdict:I think I would have loved the game back in the time when it came out but it just doesn't compete with anything the industry produces today. Consider modding the game which will improve it enough to look exciting for an extra couple hours. The 10 hours I put in this game feel like an excessive waste of time.

												The game works as intended no crashes etc and the game engine is great.It simulates a degraded part of Africa well.But game design elements are not well thought out and this makes the game a real drag to complete.For example It is not clear how to progress the main missions, there is no option for a persistent hud to show essential info like health.One example: When you need to go to the faction HQ to get missions you need to: drive there, (this can take a long time, get harassed on way a further nuisance), get out of car, walk around concrete barricades, go to front door , get searched, open door, walk into building walk across room up stairs to room with boss and chat for 30 seconds before finally being handed a manila folder with mission, then walk to stairs go down, cross room, open door, walk around concrete obstacle course to your car start car and drive to new mission! Every time you want to do a mission! about 20 plus times. It's boring and a waste of time you should do it once, then new missions just appear after you complete current one. There are many other examples... Only buy this game it if its really cheap and you really love this type of game, the over simulate the real world type of game.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												Ok I am %62 done with this game and I can give you some details about it.First off I think my mistake is that I played FarCry first which was great, and then FarCry 3 which was awesome.I was expecting the same awesomeness with FarCry 2 but I find it more difficult and I am less tolerant with it.You see, fast travel kind of sucks in this game and missions are most of the time at the total opposite ends of the map. So if you are in the bottom left corner to accept a mission, expect to go back way to the top of the map. Unlike FC3 when you liberate a post, it is not the scenario here. There is always bad guys. You can't get from point A to B quickly and quietly, unless you go offroad, and even then, it takes longer. When you come into the game, I was not exactly sure what my objectives were. I had to go on the internet to give myself an idea. It was later after wasting time with side missions that don't really matter (Radio Tower missions) that I eventually learned that I have to get missions from the town and buddies (not real people or your online friends) that you encounter during the game.Then it started getting interesting. But still the fact that fast travel is not great and posts are always fill with bad guys, makes it redundant and a bit frustrating.Now I am not saying the game sucks. I am saying my mistake is that I was thinking of FC3 benefits and how I wished FS2 had it. I am even more sure that if I played them in order, I would be enjoying FC2 a lot better than I am nowGiven that. I do not fault the game. It is what it is and I am sure that anyone playing it will have a lot of fun.But don't do my mistake. Play FarCry 2 before you play FarCry 3.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is a first person shooter that takes place in a war torn country in infamously war torn Africa.  And it speaks to me.  This game is truly a far cry (no pun intended) from the original; the first game being a sci-fi shooter involving genetic mutations that held a very 80's-90's vibe in its approach; but it is by no means a far cry in a negative way.  To be honest this game manages to successfully convey a message that I myself already more or less knew; whether or not it did so on purpose remains to be seen.I have a lot of positive and negative experiences in this game.  The main negative is probably that it is a very long game that does a lot of repeating itself; clear a safe house, track a checkpoint, do a convoy mission here, an assassination mission there, rage at some OP patrol car with a grenade launcher in that direction and so on.  Despite this I managed to finish the game and walked away feeling like it was a great experience.  You essentially go through war-torn Africa on the hunt for an arms dealer whose guns are potentially further aggrivating a very intense and deadly conflict.  You get to see the decay and decadance caused by a society in conflict, one that is trying its hardest to decide whether it should be westernized or remain its own culture but unable to choose between both, and you make friends and enemies along the way.  But you realize as you keep collecting diamonds and using them to buy new weapons and equipment that you slowly are starting to lose yourself, and it's only by the end when you see everything coming to a standstill that you truly realize just how far you've come...and just how much you've lost yourself in the process.I know that's pretty philisophical for a review, but this game has left me feeling philisophical.  It's honestly a great game to play.Now before I close this review I do feel obligated to point a few things out, especially for people looking to play the game.  This game, while old, has the right kind of bugs that makes it YouTube gold.  Probably the most infamous bug in my playthrough was when NPCs wouldn't stand still and kept deciding that they were on a punching bag stand (in my first attempt to play the game I saw a bunch of villagers bobbing up and down and literally thought that they were doing some sort of ritualistic African jumping dance for some reason XD).  Less fun bugs includes the bug involving the Jackal Tapes (which you will find out in the forums), as well as the occasional crashes that occur in between saves (word to the wise, keep extra save files, becuase some people have had corrupted saves occur deep into the game), but there is nothing that's absolutely game breaking.  I will also point out that unlike future Far Cry games the animals aren't hostile and are more of an interactive element, which is a shame considering that I feel like a game set in Africa that didn't include at least one mission involving an African Safari Hunt was a missed opportunity.If you've played any of the other games (3, 4, and Primal) and want to try something closer to the roots, or if you're into old fashioned shooters but want something less linear and more free roam than the original, Far Cry 2 is for you.-Kerian

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
 How to create a astonishingly beautiful world - to fill it with nothing worth playingWell, what can be said about Far Cry 2 ? The follow-up to FC 1 - not developed by Crytek which should focus on the to-be-released first Crysis that would set new standards in graphics and enactment in FPS in the day, but Ubisoft Montreal instead  - which was a great sandbox/openworld shooter promised many things and many hands-on by Game magazines made me long for this game back in the day. It should became some years later until I finally managed to get my hands on it during a steam sale and I was pretty disappointed after the credits rolled.Strange thing is, the Ideas the developers had for this game sounded really great: A breathing, living, open world, choosing a side between different factions, a buddy-system, choices and consequences, degrading weapons (first FPS-game since System Shock 2 that had this mechanic at least from the games I know of), gorgeous visuals... I mean, what's not to love ? Well, Practice turned out different than Theory.Well, first let's focus on the things the Game got right. An open world with gorgeous visuals, day-and-night rhythm, great physics, realistic Fire, vegetation... Really fun fights, great gunplay with degrading weapons, weapon jams, well-balanced that makes for a gritty, ruthless atmosphere  Interesting setting in a nameless african country in civil war with two different factions ..."Buddies" that come to help and give you new missions ... clever AI for the most part... Lots of missions... A great staged kick-off into the game...now the bad and the ugly:... that feels not alive. Aside from some alibi-fauna animals the wolrd is pretty much empty. Where are the citizens ? How come I only encounter the same clone-rebells on the street ? It seems more like a great postcard idyll than a living, breathing world that goes it's way regardless what the player does. ... that quickly becomes very stale because of lousy gamedesign. A country at civil war yet there are no citizens to be encountered in the world apart from a few refugees, the chaplain, a doctor and some others ? Just feels false. It doesn't matter and has no consequences for which faction you decide. Killed the villain on top of the organisation of the other group ? Doesn't matter, they welcome you with open arms for your next mission. Sabotaged something ? Doesn*t feel like it made any difference at all. The other faction becoming weaker because of your actions i.e. less Enemies etc. Not at all. Shooting the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s at the road block that you razed to the ground 5 minutes ago ? Your faction shooting at you because the mission is "secret" (Well by that definition, every mission in FC2 is "secret") ? ♥♥♥♥ it, just shoot anyone ! A Story that seems to unfold while making missions ? Nope. Bad Guy X gets replaced by bad Guy Y, same thing over again.... and are completely useless because you develop no relationship to them and gain nothing by helping them other than having a savegame less bc they come help you in case of death. Buddy dies in a fight with others ? ♥♥♥♥ it, you will get another one at the next bar. So why implement them in the first place ? Cynic, much ? other than a few times where they stand in front of you doing nothing or having wall-hack and sniping you from 2 km away. On hard difficulties, they are bullet sponges, not realistic at all. Shoot someone without kevlar west with an MG 5-7 times ? Doesn't matter to him, he will still shoot at you. Another super annoying issue is that enemies at "liberated" outposts and road-blocks respawn almost immidately. You're on a mission driving from A to B just to drive the same route back having to kill the bad guys twice, dying and repeating the♥♥♥♥♥♥all over again if you're unlucky ? Well, don't say I didn't warn you.  that play out the same: deliver X, kill bad guy Y, Sabotage Z, Deactivate J ... Seriously ? that becomes incredible boring and tedious. Story ? Nope, this game doesn't have one aside from some alibi-characters and twists see coming before.So... Ubisoft wanted to create a real, living, dark, gritty world in which the players actions shall have consequences and he can choose how to approaoch with a interesting story and different factions. The world seems real, dark and gritty, but it isn't because you have restraints. You have NO Story, your choices make NO difference, you can NOT choose how to approach a situation (other than the fights, they are as fun and open as open-world can be, even when stealth is difficult bc. of wallhack AI for example). So in the end, the game is more annoying, frustrating and cynic than fun or interesting. Let's make a stupid comparison: If Ubisoft got the task to paint a picture, they have gotten the most beautiful colors, brushes and pencils, but made one of the worst images I ever saw.Not recommended, try FC3 or FC4 instead.PS: Don't get fooled by the small playtime, I started FC2 in a different way due to problems with steam and so steam didn't count any Gaming hours. Actually I played it twice just to see if it would play any different by choosing other characters, etc. It did not. started FC2 a different way

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												I've played through Far Cry 3 at least four times and recently completed a second play-through of Far Cry 4, so I thought I'd go back to Far Cry 2 since I’ve only played it once before. I've only gotten through a few missions now and I'm already sorry I gave it another shot. While the visuals are fairly impressive, there are so many aspects of this game that make it bad.FC 3 did a great job of addressing the major issues with FC2 which, in when you compare the two games, really makes you aware of how bad FC2 is. The biggest problem is how long it takes to get anywhere. Traveling by vehicle speeds up your travel time, but the terrain is setup so you almost always have to go around any hills, even short ones. The map system is meant to mimic having a real map in your hand, but since you can only get a close-up view of the section you’re currently in, you can’t look around other areas to see if there is anything interesting you may want to explore. You also can’t add a waypoint to where you want to go, so when you’re traveling you constantly need to have the map deployed in order to keep visual track of where you’re trying to get to.The ability to easily kill enemies isn’t consistent with logic. Headshots don’t always instantly kill an enemy, which I can understand if you’re at a distance and you potentially don’t get the shot dead on. However, standing right next to an enemy and shooting them in the head at point-blank range doesn’t always kill them instantly either. It would make sense that a shotgun blast to any part of the body should at least cause them to fall down, but I would frequently unload three shots at point-blank range before they tumble.There are a number of other problems with the game, but just the combination of these two factors make the game difficult to enjoy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												One of the top 5 games I've ever played. Far superior to Far Cry 3.  Certain aspects of this game make me want to hate it, but in turn, drive me to beat it, to be better. Strangly enough, since any other game I would just lower the difficulty or uninstall and call it a crappy game. Not this. Finished the game, doing all the missions and bonus missions in 30 hours on Infamous. Don't play it on any other difficulty or it will ruin the game. Realistic in certain aspects which is great, such as getting killed in one shot and jammed weapons in a firefight. That might not seem fun, but it forces you to become a better player. Scavenging for supplies, ammo, and health is great. You don't carry hundreds of rounds or 10 rockets as in other games. You have to preserve your ammo, and your time.Didn't like driving everywhere, although it adds to the realism. The buddies really added to the game. You have to play to the end to find out why. One of the best endings in any game. Hundred times better than Far Cry 3, whose ending left me saying wtf with three question marks. Far Cry 2's ending ties together the entire game, and is drastically different from any other game.At the end of Far Cry 3, I felt as if I wasted my time, although it was fun. Both endings had no closure, and one of them was plain stupid. It wasn't realistic in many aspects. Far Cry 3 ruined it completely with its voice-over and cutscenes. Far Cry 2 made me feel as if I was in Africa for 30 hours, fighting the fight. At the end of Far Cry 2, I felt as if I died. And you know what, it was worth it.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												First of all: I DARE YOU, I DOUBLE DARE YOU NOT TO USE QUICK SAVES ON THE ENTIRE PLAYTHROUGH IN MAX DIFFICULTY. That's how you'll enjoy this game at its best. Those QS kill the feeling of depsperation and nervousness the game wants to build when you are sorrounded by 3 dudes with shotguns and one in a mounted MG, forcing you to be precise and clean on each shot to fight for not losing ALL YOUR PROGRESS.Easily one of the best FPS games I've ever played. The level of immersion its over 900! So immersive that there is practically no HUD (this immersion is only F-ed up by the fact that there are no predators, lions or hyenas, ITS  A ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AFRICAN COUNTRY FOR CHRIST SAKES). The environment, landscapes and sounds are so AWESOME that I didn't mind the driving (But seriously, not every enjoys driving that F-ing much). This game is not as hard as FC 1 (that one was a PAIN in maximum difficulty in certain parts that I didn't enjoy much), but hard to beat still. This game is hard in a much more entertaining and fun way than its predecessor. Speaking of which... the voice acting is still bad here lol, but the AI is as smart (if not better). You feel a "YES, YES, YEEES I DID IT" instead of the " AT LAST GOD DAMMIT" of FC 1.You'll feel harrased by the enemies and God... you'll become paranoid waiting for an assault truck to come out of nowhere when you have just one health bar and no syringes left. This is the Dark Souls of the FPS (in my opinion). Every mission completed gave me that rewarding feeling. Even more if I did it full-sneak. The only thing that pisses me off is that Ubisoft promised animal DLC (in its time) and never did it. If you want challenging FPS that will make you just jawdrop, helpless and powerless, each time you get killed and watch how you just lost 1 hour of playtime for distracting a fraction of a second (pretty much like Dark Souls if you play it for the first time), then this is for you. You gun jams/breaks, the save points are sometimes so far away that you'll want to cry ( I repeat DO NOT USE QUICK SAVES, it kills the experience) and the ammo is VERY limited.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												The game is decent, but it has major flaws that try even my patience. One of the biggest flaws is the amount of checkpoints that guarantee a shooting war far too often and the enemy spawn rate. The second biggest gripe I have is the fact that you're sent to do this or that mission, but it may be way off the current map you are in and you must constantly be driving all the time - there may be an easier way to do it, but the amount of time and driving it takes repititiously for every mission given by the APR and UFLL to be accomplished the easier way may drive some to just do the mission and ignore the "easy" way. Since there are no fast-travel stations in more key areas of the map, the constant driving may drive some off from this game altogether. - I've seen one person refer to this game as a "driving simulator."The story could be fleshed out more, as well as supporting a coop campaign or giving you an AI traveling partner.The game is fine, but I would like to see more assault/heavy weapons, and the ability to customize your loadout according to how you see fit. For instance, one may like to have an M249 SAW as their primary and a sawed-off shotgun for secondary while keeping their rocket launcher and mortars, for instance.I would give this game an 8/10, but the storyline is too diluted, there are too many spawnpoints for enemies, not enough fast travel points located at strategic points in the map, too much driving and the lack of loadout customization (personal preference) prevent it from achieving this rank.6/10

The second biggest gripe I have is the fact that you're sent to do this or that mission, but it may be way off the current map you are in and you must constantly be driving all the time - there may be an easier way to do it, but the amount of time and driving it takes repititiously for every mission given by the APR and UFLL to be accomplished the easier way may drive some to just do the mission and ignore the "easy" way. Since there are no fast-travel stations in more key areas of the map, the constant driving may drive some off from this game altogether. - I've seen one person refer to this game as a "driving simulator."The story could be fleshed out more, as well as supporting a coop campaign or giving you an AI traveling partner.The game is fine, but I would like to see more assault/heavy weapons, and the ability to customize your loadout according to how you see fit. For instance, one may like to have an M249 SAW as their primary and a sawed-off shotgun for secondary while keeping their rocket launcher and mortars, for instance.I would give this game an 8/10, but the storyline is too diluted, there are too many spawnpoints for enemies, not enough fast travel points located at strategic points in the map, too much driving and the lack of loadout customization (personal preference) prevent it from achieving this rank.6/10

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Oh my god, this game is so tedious.  6+ hours in, I'm spending all my f***ing time driving around, getting into repetitive gun battles from the car, restocking weapons, shooting myself up, and sleeping.  That I even have to mention sleeping tells you how asinine this micromanaging BS is.And Christ, the driving around bit is 90% of my pain right there.  Shooting from a stopped vehicle is terrible, impractical, and boring.  What's more, enemies respawn at every fricking intersection the moment I move away from it, meaning EVERY drive across the map forces me to fight them.  Maybe you can just lose them?  Yeah, good luck with that.  The AI drives much better than you do, and unlike you, they can shoot while they drive.  Never before has just getting to a mission been such an enormous exercise in tedium.Well, at least once you get there, it's just like Far Cry, but with better graphics, right?  Ha!  Try sniping through tall grass from far away, a strategy that worked wonderfully in the original, and works pretty well in real life.  Your first shot will mark you like a g*d*mn beacon.  I don't know why everyone in the game has Superman's telescopic and X-ray vision; they just do.  And it's frustrating, because instead of strategy, like the aforementioned sniping, you're actually better off running in guns blazing.You know what, it might be great once you really get into the story.  Maybe I just needed more time.  And maybe I'll give it another try someday.  Like, after I finish the 170+ games in my queue that are actually enjoyable.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												A bright gem in the world of FPS shooters, Far Cry 2 takes us to a place we all know, or at least the members of our family from generations past knew - the world of struggle, strife and corruption. It comes alive in spectacular style and is one of the most realistic of all the fictional locales used in today´s PC games. The guns, the glory, the greed all merge and create an authentic and powerful story. Driven by an excellent gameplay engine, Far Cry 2 enables you to fight in a variety of ways, from employing stealth to outright firefighting. You can kill you enemies silently from afar, using the vegetation as your cover, or engage in gun battles in a variety of ways. The hillsides offer excellent fallback positions and allow you to plan your next  move. Whether you want to pick everyone out in an area using your sniper rifle, or burrow  your way through their compounds and outposts, Far Cry 2 will offer you ample chances to do both.This installment offers a wide diversity of of weapons,  manual loading, semi automatic  and fully automatic. Explosive weapons are also available. Some come with their own scopes, allowing you to sniper bomb enemy cars before, or after the driver and his fellow soldiers get in.  The grass and trees can be set on fire, allowing you to create a shield of fire to drive the enemies while you reposition yourself and shoot them before they can regain their bearings.A serious game for a veteran player, Far Cry 2 is a haven for the creative killer, the adventurer and the explorer. Get it, if you really want to see the wild side of Africa in all its glory.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2012
												It's nothing like Far Cry 1. This game is.. interesting. It has a lot of cool elements, and a lot of not so cool ones, but the game did a lot right. The story is kind of boring and falls apart almost directly after the intro. The game is highly open world like Far Cry 1, but that's where the similarities end. The game has major AI problems, don't trust Ubisoft. If you walk up behind an enemy, and hit them with your knife, and completely kill them with no one in sight or nearby, all the enemies in the area will know where you are right away. You cannot sneak around enemies, you cannot fool them into thinking you're in another spot. The graphics look nice, the gun play is solid, and the health system is fairly cool. The game just really feels dull at times sadly, and could have used a less linear feel. The quests in the game felt almost randomly generated and lacked any personality. Almost no characters in the game besides the man you're hired to kill have personality. Overall, 8/10.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												One of the top 5 games I've ever played. Far superior to Far Cry 3.  Certain aspects of this game make me want to hate it, but in turn, drive me to beat it, to be better. Strangly enough, since any other game I would just lower the difficulty or uninstall and call it a crappy game. Not this. Finished the game, doing all the missions and bonus missions in 30 hours on Infamous. Don't play it on any other difficulty or it will ruin the game. Realistic in certain aspects which is great, such as getting killed in one shot and jammed weapons in a firefight. That might not seem fun, but it forces you to become a better player. Scavenging for supplies, ammo, and health is great. You don't carry hundreds of rounds or 10 rockets as in other games. You have to preserve your ammo, and your time.Didn't like driving everywhere, although it adds to the realism. The buddies really added to the game. You have to play to the end to find out why. One of the best endings in any game. Hundred times better than Far Cry 3, whose ending left me saying wtf with three question marks. Far Cry 2's ending ties together the entire game, and is drastically different from any other game.At the end of Far Cry 3, I felt as if I wasted my time, although it was fun. Both endings had no closure, and one of them was plain stupid. It wasn't realistic in many aspects. Far Cry 3 ruined it completely with its voice-over and cutscenes. Far Cry 2 made me feel as if I was in Africa for 30 hours, fighting the fight. At the end of Far Cry 2, I felt as if I died. And you know what, it was worth it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I tried for hours, searching the internet, for fixes to a never ending series of problems with this game.  From glitches with characters and the environment all the way to a persistent buzzing I would hear over my speakers...there were far too many to fix and I eventually gave up.  This game is unplayable...  The most game breaking glitch was having characters who, once talked to, would move and thus ruin the speech script.  Ever have a character say one line, move and thus reset itself?  Thereby saying that one line over and over and over and over until you found that one exact sweet spot for it to finish the sentence and start the next sentence, only to have the character move its arm or turn it head and thus repeat the same problem?  That is what happened to me...over and over and over again...  Ugh...  I applied fix after fix to encounter more and more problems.  The opening scene where you are driven around in the taxi was the first problem.  The NPCs would get in front of the car (while literally BOUNCING around the screen) and thus stop the entire sequence.  Only several reloads and pure luck got me through that.  Add in all the glitches with that persistent buzzing I would hear over the speakers (read around, it is a common problem) and the game went from frustrating to ANNOYINGLY frustrating.  All in all, if you luck out and get the game to work for you...you are fortunate.  As for me, I am truly and greatly disappointed with this game.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												The game is odd. It is advertized as open world, but there isn't much open world in it.Sure you can travel all over the map, but there is not much interaction, nothing really to see or do, nothing worth discovering.No NPCs worth any mention, outside the story. The story does not seem bad - the one "Plus" in my mind. But that is not enough. Again - i would say it's ok, but it's not open world!Buddy system is interesting at first, but only for novelty. Repeating stuff will get boring fast. There are generic repeating side quests, to unlock guns and gather money (They "Transfer raw diamonds online to my account" as payment :P ). You seen one, you seen them all, yet you have to do at least a couple, to unlock stuff. Grindy. The graphics are OK, considering the old age of the game. But then - everything looks the same, everything is brown. Might be very realistc for a desolate, poor country somewhere in Africa. Makes for very boring, unimpressive experience however.Certainly not, what i expected from the rather beautifull engine, i was remebering from the original FarCry.The combat AI seems decent. They take cover, take turns advancing. Overall visibility is very bad. You could call it realism. But then the enemies seem to magically see me through buildings, rocks and cover, while i am hiding in high grass.Technical issues. No separate settings for different sounds. Dialog is too silent, shooting too loud.Vehicles (other than the own) are barely audible, untill they park right on top of me. Literally.The FoV is just atrocious. I got sick after 10 minutes of playing and had to look for a 3rd party hack, to increase it. (https://www.widescreenfixer.org/ does work, but sometimes requires more than one try/restart to catch on. Now the hack not working is not the games fault, but the very low original FoV and no settings is).Finally - respawning hostiles at every outpost. Very quickly, sometimes, while i am still standing there, looking for hidden goodies after just having cleared it. (Oh goodies... there is no loot worth any mention, you just look for "hidden" diamonds - the games currency).That respawning wasn't too bad at first - something to do. But with time, doing the rpetetive side quests, passing the same spot on the way there and back and again... It turned into an grindy annoyance really fast.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												The game is odd. It is advertized as open world, but there isn't much open world in it.Sure you can travel all over the map, but there is not much interaction, nothing really to see or do, nothing worth discovering.No NPCs worth any mention, outside the story. The story does not seem bad - the one "Plus" in my mind. But that is not enough. Again - i would say it's ok, but it's not open world!Buddy system is interesting at first, but only for novelty. Repeating stuff will get boring fast. There are generic repeating side quests, to unlock guns and gather money (They "Transfer raw diamonds online to my account" as payment :P ). You seen one, you seen them all, yet you have to do at least a couple, to unlock stuff. Grindy. The graphics are OK, considering the old age of the game. But then - everything looks the same, everything is brown. Might be very realistc for a desolate, poor country somewhere in Africa. Makes for very boring, unimpressive experience however.Certainly not, what i expected from the rather beautifull engine, i was remebering from the original FarCry.The combat AI seems decent. They take cover, take turns advancing. Overall visibility is very bad. You could call it realism. But then the enemies seem to magically see me through buildings, rocks and cover, while i am hiding in high grass.Technical issues. No separate settings for different sounds. Dialog is too silent, shooting too loud.Vehicles (other than the own) are barely audible, untill they park right on top of me. Literally.The FoV is just atrocious. I got sick after 10 minutes of playing and had to look for a 3rd party hack, to increase it. (https://www.widescreenfixer.org/ does work, but sometimes requires more than one try/restart to catch on. Now the hack not working is not the games fault, but the very low original FoV and no settings is).Finally - respawning hostiles at every outpost. Very quickly, sometimes, while i am still standing there, looking for hidden goodies after just having cleared it. (Oh goodies... there is no loot worth any mention, you just look for "hidden" diamonds - the games currency).That respawning wasn't too bad at first - something to do. But with time, doing the rpetetive side quests, passing the same spot on the way there and back and again... It turned into an grindy annoyance really fast.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												I first read about this game in a gaming magazine. Then seen the trailers. Then saw the walkthrough of MajorSlack back in the old days. And only then after a year bought it. And still, it's better then FC3 and 4 just by one paramater that defines it - immersion. I just love when realism and arcade have a a balance between each other, which is in what FC2 excels.Some of the main things I like is:-Minimal HUD, yet informative, and the map is integrated into a hold-em Real Map and GPS.-Amazing realistic textures and nature. I literally can see the bumps, scars, scratches, dirt and dust on the practically anything. And it runs everything smoothly, even for my notebook.-Weapon degradation, detail, sound. Unjam animation for each one, although I don't like the fact that the AK-47 or SVD for example have the shell exractor on the left, instead of right.-Realistic vegetation.-Map Editor/Creator-Atmosphere in terms of how you are a mercenary.-Gameplay. And I suggest to watch the aleardy noticed MajorSlack on youtube and he will tell how to have fun in this game.And all of this is actually VERY good for a game of it's time. Only bad thing is that Ubi will ruin it if they make a remake...

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I don't know exactly what it was that made this game so 'un-fun'; even trying to think of the things that irritated me, they all sound like cool ideas.Many hours have been spent in open-world games but I just couldn't get enthusiastic about FC2.It was probbaly the sheer grind of it all - the incessant struggle against a world out to kill you, even down to the malaria that demands regular treatment.There was some good times to be had with fire and such but they were outweighed by jamming guns, respawning checkpoints and a dozen little aggravations.Overall, I think it was a little too much like real life (less fire and killing, but you know what I mean) to be truly the escape that video games should be.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												I finished only the first act (there is 3 overall). I can't make myself play any longer, this game is really tedious and poorly written, hence there is nothing what could keep me going.This game is ok shooter. But it's not so action filled to actually enjoy the game solely because of this, there is too much gaps in between. The gameplay is rather slow and consists mostly of you driving from point A to point B through copy-pasted enemy controlled checkpoints (which are everywhere) to do your usually absolutely meaningless business. Every action starts from you driving at least a couple of minutes. Don't waste your time cleaning checkpoints, they will respawn as soon as you turn the corner.Quests are all stupid fetch quests and main quests are no different. Story is so disjointed and sparse I was lost in the beginning because game doesn't take time to explain you anything. The only source of information about the situation is your journal, which consist of 1 (one) entry in it, and "accidentally" heard 10 seconds dialogue between bosses when you come to them to take another go-kill quest. Trough the first act Jackal appeared twice for about 1 minute total, saying some cryptic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. That's about all the story I got. This game is extremely poor on content.

Posted: August 28, 2016
												Reccommend with hesitation, only when on sale. Negative review is for the abysmal PC port.The game itself is excellent; the gameplay in general is solid, and it's incredibly immersive. This game is brought down a lot by its terrible PC port, which is why I would only reccomend this game on sale. The FOV is locked at what looks like about 70, and the game switches to windowed mode whenever you Alt+Tab out. Some of the problems might be fixable by messing around with the files, but a customer should not be expected to fix the game themselves, this♥♥♥♥♥♥should have been included by Ubisoft. Since people will buy their games anyway, Ubisoft continues to half♥♥♥♥♥their PC ports, which is a shame because of how good this game is.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												I first read about this game in a gaming magazine. Then seen the trailers. Then saw the walkthrough of MajorSlack back in the old days. And only then after a year bought it. And still, it's better then FC3 and 4 just by one paramater that defines it - immersion. I just love when realism and arcade have a a balance between each other, which is in what FC2 excels.Some of the main things I like is:-Minimal HUD, yet informative, and the map is integrated into a hold-em Real Map and GPS.-Amazing realistic textures and nature. I literally can see the bumps, scars, scratches, dirt and dust on the practically anything. And it runs everything smoothly, even for my notebook.-Weapon degradation, detail, sound. Unjam animation for each one, although I don't like the fact that the AK-47 or SVD for example have the shell exractor on the left, instead of right.-Realistic vegetation.-Map Editor/Creator-Atmosphere in terms of how you are a mercenary.-Gameplay. And I suggest to watch the aleardy noticed MajorSlack on youtube and he will tell how to have fun in this game.And all of this is actually VERY good for a game of it's time. Only bad thing is that Ubi will ruin it if they make a remake...

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												This game is worth every single penny spent on it!The driving bits get a bit tedious after a while as well as the Malaria attacks, but the game was enjoyable all the way to the end.The graphics are nice, the selection of weapons is mostly Cold War era weapons (AKM, G3, FAL etc.) wich is a plus in my book. The combat feels nice & you have lots of ways to approach the outpost you are about to ruin. The weapon you are using may misfire if it gets too old wich is a nice feature.This is mainly a Singleplayer game but there is also a Multiplayer mode thats really fun. Theres still a small but dedicated community playing, so theres a good chance youll run into the same people more than a few times!The story is good with lots of symbolism, although at times it feels a bit confusing as to whats going on.All in all, the game is not without its flaws such as constantly respawning enemy checkpoints & the aforementioned driving bits, but if you manage to see past these flaws, you have a really great game! Its the kind of game that you either love or hate.But would I recommend it? Of course I do! If you ever have the money to spare or its on sale, I say buy it! At least just so you can try it out.Sincerely// Anton

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Far Cry 2 is a pretty game, even today, with an expansive world of reasonable variety. Though players can attempt to tackle the game as they would a sandbox actioner, Far Cry 2 requires a more measured response. There is a lot driving to do, but it feels real to do so. The environment is a harsh and unforgiving place, just as you may expect. Yet, that every living soul outside of a safe zone wants to kill you (and even those in safe zones would love an excuse to kill you) is slightly less 'real'. At the start of the game, your driver negotiates a trade so as to gain passage through a checkpoint. Sadly, that kind of mechanic is for cutscenes only. The only toll is paid in bullets and blood. While exciting at first, the realisation that when next you pass through those enemies will have returned to fight again, can become frustrating. However, those issues aside, the game is rich and fluid. FPS fans will squeeze a lot of fun times from this game, though they may never finish it.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												I believe I made it roughly a third of the way through the main “story” of Far Cry 2 before moving on to greener pastures. Had I been an early adopter to the title, I think it would have blown me away with the size of the playable area, the complexity of ways to approach each obstacle, and that awesome fire spread. However, I found that instead I was frequently infuriated with the enemy AI constantly pinpointing me in a bush at midnight a mile away and I quickly grew tired of the amount of tedious travel required to get from any point of the map to the other.Upon release I’m sure this was a must own title, but with the availability of Far Cry 3 and the (hopefully decent) soon to be released Far Cry 4, I don’t think this game has much to offer anyone anymore.Certainly not a terrible game if you can pick it up for a dollar, but nothing to jump at.

number of helpful: 14 of 30 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Far Cry 2 is a stellar example of a game that appears to have a lot going for it, but isn’t actually worth your time. The open world design feels barren, needlessly large, and pointlessly shoehorned in. Everything in the game boils down to binary decisions. All of the guns feel wimpy and samey. The one-note mission design and unrewarding treasure-hunting collectathon prevents anything interesting from happening within the world, making the entire experience feel rote. None of the characters have any personality, and the plot isn’t memorable. Even the more impressive technological feats, such as fire and the day/night cycle, have little impact on gameplay. At best, Far Cry 2 is generic, boring and forgettable.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												If you are reading this now and wondering if you should spend money on this game, please don't. For the whole duration of my playthrough I was either bored to death by the unnecessarily long drives and dull combat, or kept wondering how such a fundamentaly flawed game was released by a experienced company as Ubisoft.The graphics are technically decent if compared to other games from when Far Cry 2 was released, but they did not age well. The map is huge but you can hardly tell any difference from the places you go apart from the 3 basic biomes (desert, savanna and jungle). Everything is bleached by a clear brown fog, even the jungles are a dull brownish color.  Almost every building on the map looks like it's part of a shanty town and the very few urban settings are minuscle and lame.Sound is mostly mediocre, with a few very annoying sounds playing all the time like some metal banging from the regular cars, or a weird tire screeching sound that's played every other time you get shot (!). The few musics are unremarkable at best. The voice-over dialogues are terrible, the actors seem to have been rushed into reading their lines as fast as possible.The story is terrible and almost non-existent, wasting an excelent opportunity to delve deep in such an important and completely overlooked theme that are the civil wars happening in Africa. The player character is despicable and so are almost everyone you get to interact with throughout the game and you suspension of disbelief is constantly broken by the lack of sense on the assignments given to your character. In a few moments the game seems to give options to the player, but soon after you learn that your choices mean nothing and the story follows it's pre defined path.But the worst of all is the gameplay. 70% of the time spent playing Far Cry 2 involves driving, a few times even walking large distances devoid of anything but the infamous ever respawning enemy guard posts present at every other road crossing. The main missions are very repetitive and are limited to driving to a certain spot, killing someone/taking or giving an item/destroying something and then going somewhere else to repeat this pattern until the mission is completed. The side missions are utterly repetitive and often send you all the way across the map. And to add insult to injury, every now and then you need to drop everything you are doing to go fetch some malarial pills, which is probably one of the dumbest repeteable side quest ever on the history of videogames.Bottom line is, if you have money to spend on a game, there are many other better options on Steam, so do yourself a favour and skip this one.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												I know it's not fair to compare a game made in 2008 to one made four years later. But I started by playing Far Cry 3 and enjoyed it so much I thought I might as well try it's predecessor. Not a good idea. Number two stinks. It lacks almost everything that makes FC3 a great game. FC2 has a dull story line, and most missions are exact copies of earlier ones, especially the side missions. Example: to unlock weapons you have to blow up a convoy coming from the east. And then one from the west. And south. And yes, dealing with the convoy coming from the north is exactly the same; they drive around in circles, you blow the lorry to smithereens and you're done; you can proceed to the next mission. Public transport is the best choice to get there, as driving a car or boat takes about 10 times longer. That's because every 100 meters you have to deal with two homicidal maniacs in a car or ten of them at yet another road block. You have a choice of nine to pick your main character from. It doesn't matter much which one you pick. Every character in the game has a personality as flat as roadkill at a monstertruck show. The feeble attempt at a story line is hard to follow for someone who's not a native speaker, like me. Everyone speaks as if they've just done an ounce of speed, and even the subtitles have a hard time keeping up. From what I picked up, the story basically goes like this: first you work for this person, then you work for that person, then you work for another person, then you kill one of them and another person appears. You work for that person too, and then for another person and then you kill one of them and another person appears. Repeat until everyone dies. Game over.So, no. I do not recommend buying this game, even though the graphics are pretty awesome for a game made in 2008.I do recommend Far Cry 3 though, which was fun, entertaining and trippy.
