number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												This was the first serious FPS I played back in 2007. Basically, thanks to this game, I got interested in PC gaming. It gave me plenty of memories and even emotions.However, now, in 2015, as I started to play this game again, something was wrong. Even though it run on ultra settings, it looked quiet bad. And I'm not talking about that it looks bad because it's old. No. It's way too dark, even in sunlight, the blur gives you eye cancer, shadows are lagging, apart from some crates and other stuff everything is solid and the models change their LOD as you approach them. This was the most frustrating issue from all. Now let's talk about the actual gameplay. It's even worse. I downloaded a Realism Mod, which meant to change on the "shoot 20 bullets into his chest then finally he'll die" situation, and on many oher terrible mistakes. It was still rubbish. You may have heard of the respawning enemies AFTER you liberate a checkpoint. It is utterly stupid, and I'd put the person who programmed this into this situation in real life. In short, I'm talking about this:You drive peacefully on the dusty road, when suddenly, there is a small checkpoint of the local military. They immediately start to shoot at you, without a question. When you killed them all, and occupied it, you drive along. After like 30m, you remember, that you forgot to pick up ammo, so you turn back. What a suprise, there are soldiers again!! And this goes on and on, every 40 something small base works the same. They even chase you if you drive through them. Anyways, back to the rewiev. You can't pick up multiple missions, since the new one would abort the current. How hard could it be to make it possible, and let the player switch between them?The narration and voices are terrible. They are monotone, and world-weary.The game doesn't give you the option to play stealthy. I killed a guard pretty far from the others while crouching, with my machete - stealth kill, as it's called nowdays. Guess what. The others miraculously figured out where I am in the 70cm high grass, and opened fire. There is an expensive body armor called "Camo Suit" which grants more invisibility. I read, it doesn't work either. The story is lame as well. I really hoped, that it'll bring back the good memories, but sadly it couldn't. Everybody said it was a bad game and I didn't believe them. Now I do. Go buy Far Cry 3 or 4, those are masterpieces compared to this.

												Extremely disapointing, I got this game because I had heard a lot of good things about it but the people who recomended it to me failed to mention most of its shortcomings. Weapons feel like they have almost no effect unless you get headshots, missions are extremely repetitive, the lack of  a HUD itself is not a problem but making the in-game map extremely screen covering and at the same tie making you have it out to use the telescope for recon makes it a huge pain to scout out gaurd posts due to not being able to see♥♥♥♥♥♥ Stealth does virtually nothing and even if you manage to stealth kill one guy the whole base swarms you immediatly afterwards. The map has nothing interesting in it and enemies are all virtually identical, resulting in exploration being boring and tedious. There is a lack of any rel progression outside of unlocking new weapons, but with a few exceptions they are all slight varitations of the basic assault rifle, shotgun, pistol, and sniper rifle famillies. The malaria management is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥and adds nothing but annoyance.There are some good things like the buddy system and fire mechanics but aside from a few good points, the game is largely disapointing.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Don't let my steam hours fool you, I played this game alot on disk before I got steam.Be prepared to not have a single dangit thing handed to you. Map? You'll have to hold it in your hand. Stealth? Just as hard as real life would be. Malaria? Watch out son, you got it. Fire? ♥♥♥♥ yeah. For the best experience, I recommend playing on hard, it makes it ever more satisfying. Gameplay wise, it's difficult, but worth every second. The world is very atmospheric, and I loved ever second of my many playthroughs. Story is pretty good, some very interesting moments, The Jackal is great, but some of the story mission characters are pretty one dimensional and bland. I suggest choosing one of the playable characters with interesting tattoos and clothing on the arms, to give you something to look at, such as Xianyong Bai (my personal favorite). Anyway, expect harsh unforgiving enemies, beautiful landscapes, an interesting story, and re-spawning outposts, but don't give up.  Gameplay 92/100   Story 68/100   Fire 101/100

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												I waited to finish the game before writing my review in the hopes that it would change my negative output on it...But it didn't.  When I first played the game (at this point,a minor peeve).I was already put off by the voice acting,which was flatter than a 180 degree angle.Some of the characters spoke as if commas and periods were never invented.Thankfully however,not all.  Next was I was shocked over the level of graphics and physics.Despite being released in 2008,I'd mistaken it for a game that was released in 2005 or 2006.The water in the game seemed as if there was no effort put into the animation as a whole.  But most appallingly of all,as a person who considers himself a ditz for a good story,was the lack of a good narrative. Characterization was endangered if almost non-existant and events unfolded for the sake of formality it would seem. Things seemed to happen just cause.Other things seemed to happen just so there would be an excuse for another thing to happen without any true relevance to the plot or character development.  The potential for the story,as I've said,is depressingly wasted,unexplored and unexpounded despite innumerable opportunities.Generic guards and soldiers disabled any potential for flavor in this so-called civil war.Similarly,the missions were repetitive regardess of who you side with in the game.Any difference is purely aesthetic in nature.The most I could get in major difference were tiny morsels of gossip about the faction's background and the war itself.There was no true point in choosing a side in the world's factions.  Furthermore,events that would seem major to me would happen suddenly without any rising action,falling action or any form of hype whatsoever.Couple this with repetitive gameplay and mission objectives and you end up with dull,wasted surprises for the player.  I want to emphasize the lack of characterization among nearly all characters.They would either just do as they would be told despite being major characters or they would suddenly commit acts that would seem weighty if not for the lack of hype around it.The only thing separating them from the random mooks was the unique character models and the names.I could find more autonomy in a ballpen.Events were almost always too sudden for me to appreciate the deep potential in the story.  All in all,it was a pain for me to play this game.Every hour spent on this game was agonizingly dull and every tidbit of potential in the story I could find was like a droplet of water to a weary desert traveler.Never before has "get it over with" been my objective to play a video game.And again,my main issue was the poor narrative and the unexpounded story.If not for that,then all else could be forgiven.  Despite the negativity in my review,there are 3 aspects that I enjoyed.          ~I loved the ability to choose a player character.          ~The buddy system allowed variety.If ever I (somehow) get the urge to play this again,it would be because of this.          ~The reputation system and how it affected the AI in relation to a firefight with you.  The buddy system offers some tint of retribution and the African Landscape is beautiful if lonely and littered with the occasional random dead body.Thank you and have a nice day :)

												To be honest:  I did not feel like finishing this game.  It looks great, plays great, and has good voice acting.  However driving around everywhere for fetch quests in an open world does not yeild properly in this game.  Basically every quarter mile driving is a check point with arm guards who also have machine gun turrets.  So 80% of this game is driving between fetch quests destinations in an open world with the constant annoyance of arm guard check points.  Three hours into it and I found myself no longer wanting to drive anywhere since I had seen 30 mins of action and 2.5 hours of driving in the desert.  - Looks great, plays great, but you really need to enjoy driving.  I got 16% according to my save file.... oh and if night falls: go find somewhere to sleep: don't waste timing waiting for sunrise - takes an hour or something.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												I finished it the other day. I would not recommend it. The entire time I was playing, I was praying for it to be over so I could move on to trying Far Cry 3 (which I finished a little over an hour ago).Lemme list some grievances with FC2.1. It's an open world game and there's no fast travel or quick means of travelling except for bus stations in opposite corners of the map. You have to drive miles upon miles, having to stop every half mile because there's enemies every half mile that you have to stop to kill. Even if you drive past them, you'll still have to stop to fix your car and they'll probably get in an armed jeep and chase you anyway. You have no idea how tedious that got. I swear half my play time (28 hours as opposed to FC3's 18 hours) came from driving to mission locations.2. The enemies every half mile respawn, so you have no hope of ever escaping having to constantly stop - nor is there any motivation to engage them (save for the ones that chase you in vehicles that you HAVE to get out and kill).3. Weapons wear down. While this was an interesting concept, the weapons wear down way too quickly. They go from brand new to exploding in your hand in like a day.4. Everything is too grayish or brownish. The game made me feel like I was colorblind sometimes.5. For some reason your character doesn't talk in FC2 even though your character talks in FC1 and FC3.6. There wasn't much story to be had, relatively speaking.7. The game would give you choices here and there that wouldn't make any difference. The same cutscenes would still play either way.Anyone thinking of getting FC2, do yourself a favor and skip over to FC3.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Hey all, remember Far Cry 1? That was great.  You were in a big ol' open world, and you could find these shots that gave you animalistic super powers like leaping and attacking.  You took shots and they made you like unto a God.  Far Cry 2 is similar, except now when you take shots they are anti-malarial shots, and the awesome benefit they provide is that as long as you can find them and take them you don't die! So awesome! I love driving around the map, fighting off the stupid AI and searching around for green vials that let me play the game awhile longer.  It's like playing an old arcade game, except instead of running out of quarters, your character just runs out of the will to live.It's really my own fault though, I mean Far Cry 1 had super powers, and I just assumed Far Cry 2 would as well, or at least maybe not a constant life threatening illness.Let's forget the maleria for a second, even though the game never does, is the rest of the game good? No.Here's, honestly, my biggest gripe... ok, second biggest after the lack of super powers as given in the first game... ok, third biggest after they took away those powers and gave you a debilitating illness... So, my third biggest gripe is just how boring this game is, namely, how long it takes to get anywhere.  They gloat about this giant island that you get to sandbox around in, however it seems that half of it is covered by impassable mountains.  You want to go someplace literally two inches away on the map? Have fun driving around the mountains for ten minutes to get there.  Want to do some awesome off roading and just ramp yourself over the mountain like in, literally, EVERY OTHER ♥♥♥♥ING SANDBOX GAME? Too bad friend, because you can't drive there.  Unfortunately your off-road mountain-jeep can really only handle the dirt roads.Ok, I'm getting bored just remembering playing this game, so I'm out.  I just couldn't in good conscience leave all those positive reviews below without doing my part.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												This game has a very interesting Premise, and could have a promising storyline. It has beautiful scenery and effects.But it is little more than a console game ported to PC. You spend more time traveling (and clearing the same guardpost of people 5 minutes later if you have to turn around) than you do anything else. The gameplay is unimaginative, the AI is pretty dumb and predictable (but not always), there is not much as far as interaction beyond shooting, and you have to grind to get any decent weapons. It's a novelty. I played for about 30 hours and decided I really didn't care to keep spending 80% of my time traveling somewhere to get an assignment on the other end of the map and rescuing my idiot "friends" who kept on doing things like trying to assault an entire convoy on their own and getting mortally wounded before I showed up. In short, they should have tried harder. You'll have more fun watching youtube clips than actually playing it.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I feel this is a difficult game to review in 2015, it's a  game that I feel wouldn't be loved if it was released in todays industry. The original game  FarCry was quite a difficult game to complete, there's very little in terms of aids to help the player in  FarCry and FarCry2 takes a similar stance.There's no indicators to tell the player where they're taking damage from, if they're in stealth or not and there's no ability to tag enemies. For me these things only adds to the immersion, it's more brutal that way but for a lot of players not having those indicators would leave them feeling frustrated or that the game is broken. There's no minimap, you need to get the map out from your pocket to have a look, once again for some people this only adds to immersion but to others it's just awkward, I guess it just depends on the type of player you are.The biggest flaws with FarCry2 are the fact it's an open World 1st person shooting game that fails to deliver a decent open World to explore and at the same time having sloppy weapon mechanics and for those 2 reasons I wouldn't recommend FarCry2.I've spent over 30 hours with FarCry2 on the PC and there's aspects of the game I really liked.Visually I find it very pleasing, the setting and atmosphere are rather nice.The fire mechanics I feel are the best in the series and creating mass scale fires to clear out check points never got old. Plant physics, so they move when you touch or drive over them and branches will drop down if you shoot though them.The vehicles although extremely bland to drive with awful sound effects have had some nice little touches added, they get dirty when driven in the jungle and the level of destruction is greater than that in FarCry3 in terms of your car falling apart, lights being smashed, bumpers or bonnets flying off. But in the end FarCry2 feels empty, the map is lifeless and barren. There's no civilians who live there, it's pretty much you and everyone else is your enemy. The check points you clear and even other locations will have guards re-spawning, so it's this never ending army and it's not even that they  re-spawn hours later, they do it with in a couple of minutes and it feels cheap and breaks the immersion. The auto-save system doesn't work very well, you often have to go back an hour in to game after you die. There is the option to press F5 and do a quick save, which is great if you remember to do it every 10 minutes but you're meant to be immersed in the game, not thinking about saving. An open World game should entice you to explore and FarCry2 doesn't. A 1st person shooting game should have solid gun mechanics and FarCry2 doesn't.FarCry2 has a nice physics engine, it's an enjoyable African grassland fire simulator but that's sadly all it has to offer.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												I have come into Far Cry 2 from the unusual perspective of having finished Far Cry 3 recently beforehand, and I have been extremely disappointed by FC2 so far. It's clear to see where Ubisoft have made improvements in FC3 that ruined its predecessor.The game's setting and feel is great; it really captures the feeling of a central African country. But that's where the good ends, unfortunately.My first gripe was the impossibly good AI that can shoot me through undergrowth from 300m away with no problem, and outposts full of guards that instantly turn all their fire on you with unerring accuracy the moment you try and snipe someone. FC3 handled this much better with panicking pirates that fire wildly in your general direction when you snipe them and have far more realistic (i.e. worse) awareness, accuracy and line of sight. I accept that I'm not especially good at FPS games in general, but I find this game punishingly hard, even taking that into account.Enemies are also extremely bullet-spongy, which is disappointing from a game touting some degree of authenticity and realism in its setting. Even the most basic African militia or mercenary seems to be wearing a kevlar t-shirt and takes about 10 rounds of 5.56mm to the chest to die.Next is the crazy respawn rate of enemies. There are times where I've cleared out a guardpost, only to find the enemies shooting at me again from it once I'm barely 100m down the road. I can only assume this wasn't playtested by QA at Ubisoft.Within the first hour these critical game design flaws had killed the game for me. Although I was able to find the useful "Dylan's Realism Mod" to reduce the enemy HP and awareness slightly, it still didn't get rid of the incessant enemy respawns that lead to a lack of permanence and meaning in your actions.Far Cry 3 did everything better except vehicles, which in FC2 actually handle like, well, vehicles; as opposed to FC3, where vehicles are made from rubber and roads lined with goose fat.Overall though, Far Cry 3 highlights what a wasted opportunity Far Cry 2 was - get FC3 instead.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Pros:-Open World-Variety of weapons-Environment interaction (light on fire, explode, break, etc.)Cons:All Pros are limited by poor implementation of each. The Open World is indeed open world, but all you find are more people that want to kill you. There is absolutely no suprise when you run into a Non-Important town and they all attack you.The weapon variety is nice, but most of the weapons are about useless when you are bombarded by snipers and mortars. There is no reason to not use a sniper rifle which reigns supreme in all situations.The environment interaction is a novelty at best. If you are caught in fire it DESTROYS you, but the enemy sits down and lights a cigarette then jerks off when they are covered in flames all at the same time they are shooting at you.I played it simply because it was the next in the series. I played for about 5 hours and disliked this game. I forced myself to beat it because I'm stubborn and it took about 23.Ending sucks, skip this game.

												This seems like it might be a fun game, but it has too many technical issues on my machine. Characters bounce around like they are on a trampoline in all of the cutscenes, there is terrible screen tearing with or without V-Sync, and there is no dialogue or subtitles when I answer the cell phone, so I miss most of the objectives. Apparently, these issues are caused by having a newer OS than when this was released, so I can't reccomend to anyone with Windows 7 or newer.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												If you like bad games, then you'll love Far Cry 2! This game is a mixture of a 1/2 pound of ♥♥♥, and garbage on a hot plate. Pros (Read as Cons):-Overly aggressive AI that knows where you are at all times! Cease fire zone, and holding a map? Nope, you're obviously a threat, so why not blow your ♥♥♥ off?-Broken spawns ahoy, oh joy! When enemys can spawn inside walls and shoot out, of them while still being completely protected by the walls they're in, you know you have a winner! Ever wanted cars full of you're enemies to appear on top of you? No problem!-Stealth system that doesn't work, that's a standard to go by! Whether you're in a bush  behind a rock, or trees, completely consealed, your enemies don't need sight, all they need is to smell your fear, and you'd best bet they'll come running!-Ever bust a cap in someone's ♥♥♥? How about a clip's worth? Don't even trip son, it takes 2 clips to the head to turn anyone ghost in this game. Tell it how it is playah!-Have you ever wanted you're NPC's to be buggy? Are you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? If you answered yes to both questions, you will love the fact that the NPC's in this game have magnetic feilds that push you away from them, violently shake their heads when they have dialouge, and when handing them items, the will vibrate so rapidly, that they vanish into new dimensions and planes of existance!Cons:-I have Malaria.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												The shooting is fine, but that's all in fardrive 2.All mission feel the same, go there, shoot it and go back.Rinse and repeat (even the mission animation/talk is the same).Outpost are extremely annoying and don't bother to see if an npc is an enemy or not, they all are except in yellow zones.Thus shoot first,.. and .. well keep shooting until the game is finished. Ignore any diamonds while you are at it, it's not worth it.The game is also pretty linear in a sense, there is only the road, don't think to go offroad as the smallest stone will brick your car. There are almost no alternative routes into key areas (e.g. a base, village etc), no creativity there whatsoever. So if you  like to torture yourself by playing this game, like I did, then do yourself a favor and use Dylan's Realism Mod!http://www.moddb.com/mods/dylans-far-cry-2-realism-modIt even makes stealth slightly a viable option.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												After having not finished the game after a year and a half I decided to pick it back up and finish it.POSITIVES-The ability to upgrade your weapons at gunshops, it was fun expanding my artillary and improving it.-The choas, blew up one explosie barrel and the entire camp ends up blowing up really fun and cool.-There are some memorable missions/events that can occur.-The music.-The weapon varity.-The knife execution is pretty cool, when you down an enemy and go over to him with the knife you do a 'you shall not pass' execution style to him, pretty cool-Varity of vehicles.-It's a big open world.-The Atmosphere -The Jackal-The collectable tapes, very interesting some of the things said and can learn more about what's going on. (17 total)-The ending.NEGATIVES-Buddy missions are not really useful they are more tedious than fun. Maybe if they were able to make buddies set up and ambush and you lead them to an area, but was more like kill this one guy so another guy stays in this encampment so you can kill him there, but it would've been easier to do it the normal way.-Underground missions, only time I did them was when I needed pills and even considered to not even get the pills despite it was something I needed.-Drving, starts off alright then just gets really boring, and annoying.-Stealth, stealth is very difficult to actually do in the game, damn near impossible actually. Kill a guy inside a house his buddy saw you through the building.-Lack of ways to complete a mission, don't get me wrong blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up is fun, but I would sometimes like to have a different approach to things like snipe them from a mountain completely invisble from them, there were only a handful of times in which I was able to do this.-The missions, most of them are go here kill/destroy this come back and repeat, pretty much the entire game, would've like to see more varity, pretty linear.-Dialogue, the dialogue was pretty bad, felt like I was listening to them talk on x2 speed, and sometimes it would glitch out saying get in here, but you would already be there/say nothing or when they would call on the phone and there's nothing. -Collecting diamonds is useless, you make more than enough from the main missions and then some.-The AI they could drive past you and then they would somehow see you and turn around as if they had eyes in the back of their heads.-Decisions in the game didn't matter, same result.-Guard posts, you could clear a post and go down the road and back all the enemies would've spawned back, very annoying wished they would've had a timer as to when they would respawn.After almost 2 years I finally got back to it and beat it, the ending was satisfying-to me at least-but a good chunck of the game felt like a chore to do, that's why I left it unbeaten originally. So if you were thinking about buying it and can look past the negatives go for it, it has its moments.One of my funnier moments:Shot a guy down, but was still alive and was trying to get back up, shot a propane tank, as was it was spinning around and flayling around it hit him right in the head and his body just flopped down, was pretty funny to see it happen.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												BOR-ING!!!!!!!!!!This game reminds me of Just Cause 2, minus the cool explosions, grapple hook, cool vehicles, or basically anything else.  The "story" is so convoluted and weak, you'll stop caring or paying attention in no time.Yes, the combat system is OK, and the driving isn't the worst- but that's where the positives end. This game is so repetitive, it feels like you're doing the exact same mission over and over again. Every mission starts with the same voice giving the same instructions. The "pay" rarely varies. Stealth is nearly useless, as your enemies will spot you 200 yards away, crouched in the weeds... and of course they'll hit you with every shot, despite their supposedly inferior weapons. The graphics are pretty bland (even for 2008) without a mod installed.Overall, if you're into getting achievements (like find all the diamonds, etc) and just like to hunt and gather, you MIGHT like it. But there are no boss fights; side missions and main missions look and feel the same, and the upgrade system isn't very rewarding.If you have a lot of time to kill and can get it for $5, then maybe... otherwise, you'd be much better off with any of the Red Faction or Borderlands games. I've played hundreds of games, and this was one of the few where I stopped doing many side missions and just wanted it to end.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												The short explanation of this game is that it's kind of the wrong way to do open-world. It's empty, everything is spread out from everything else just to make you wander around more, the constantly respawning enemies and patrols force you to either stop and fight every 250 meters or take long, slow bypasses,the collectables are practically impossible to find except by dumb luck, the RPG elements are almost nil, and there is little actual need to explore or experiment or plan for more than just getting from point A to point B. The story is predictably laughable, it is a Far Cry game after all, but it's not even engaging; there are almost no characters that aren't just 1-dimensional cut-outs, including you. You don't even play a decent guy, you're a mercernary engaging in a civil war that isn't your own to further a pointless job. The only saving grace is that you mostly kill other mercenaries (actually, it's hilarious; I don't know if the intent was to avoid charges or racism or something, but you almost only fight other foreign mercenaries, most of them white or asian, the locals appear to have almost completely fled the entire country). The overall tone of the story is depressing and heartless, all about the horrors of war and the immorality of profiting off of it. The only good things about the game are thus; the gunplay is good and satisfying, it's very beautiful, it has surprising detail in some areas, and it focuses fairly heavily on realism, with a very clean feel and a minimal amount of "game-y" elements. That's really it. It was frustrating at first, then fun for a bit as you play around with the mechanics and enjoy shooting things, then ultimately boring because there's no variety, there's no depth, and there's not even much concentration of those good elements, as you spend most of them in transit. Only get this game if you like the older, more primitive open-world games and have A TON of patience. I tried to force myself to finish it, just to say I did, but no, I can't, I'm done and I'm bored. Back to Far Cry 3 and 4, monumentally superior games despite their flaws (and I confess, there are a few small elements I wish they had kept from this game).

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Grade for singleplayer: 2/10Grade for multiplayer ?/10In short: This game is not an enjoyable adventure. Instead it is extremely frustrating game with predictable storyline, which gives the player almost no ways to affect how the story is going to proceed.Full Review:First I would like to talk about the gameplay, which is very frustrating as I said. Most of the missions the player takes part are relatively identical to each other and are somewhat booring. This especially apllies to missions required to make new guns available. The worst part of this game though are the transitions between the missions. To travel to location of you mission you have to travel trough large amount of roadblocks that are guarded by hostile militia. Clearing these places is very repetitive. You have to keep clearing these roadblocks troughout the game. Even if you had just passed them there are new soldiers there to wait for you return. You can't even enjoy driving your car because these roadblocks are so close to each other that you would almost be faster on foot. On high difficulty levels these roadblocks are actually quite difficult to clear, which increases the frustration even higher. If this isn't enough there is more. Sometimes those militas appear behind your car in their own vehicle and eliminate you with just few bullets before you can do anything. Additionally those militias suck incredible amounts of bullets before they die. To summarise. most of the time you are not really playing the game but instead clearing the extremely annoying and repetitive roadblocks.Next about the Storyline. As I said the storyline is very predictable as I said. I wish I could say more but I would spoil the plot. What is possibly even worse is that although the player is allowed to make choices during the campaign, these choices result in identical or almost identical outcome.Next the multiplayer:I barely touched the multiplayer so i can't give much insight into it, but from the brief time I tested it, the multiplayer part seemed like a very generic FPS game.

content:
Posted: January 3
												I see tons of reviews where people praise this game over Far Cry 3 and 4. I can understand that the realism adds a different layer of depth and immersion that the newer games lack to a high degree, but the gameplay feels far less compelling here. Between having to keep yourself healthy, unjamming your guns, the constant driving all over the map, and the relative lack of direction for what to be doing I found myself being frustrated with the game more than I was enjoying playing.When this game is good, it's actually a lot of fun. Sadly, I found these moments to be too far apart to justify recommending it for anyone else. Maybe if you can catch it on a hefty sale, but keep in mind this game plays extremely differently from the following entries in the series.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												The game is like the Alpha-version to Far Cry 3. There are many good ideas that were very badly executed. The game feels rushed in terms of missions and gaming environment: It is just no fun anymore to run around after an hour or two, since the environment is plainly boring and the travelling system annoying. The missions and tasks repeat over and over with only little variations.Even the combat system is only limited fun: Thanks to the "Fortune's Edition" content you already start off overpowered, since your armory already contains badass weapons, which makes gathering other weapons less fun. Guns wearing off is a neat idea, but they seem to be made out of tin, since they always break after about 50~100 shots. Add bad guys chasing you down on every corner and you can guess that you cannot get very far without having to change your weapons like socks. So, you will end up using your vehicle's cannon, since the law of crappiness doesn't aply to them.Graphics look qute neat on the other side, even though the environment has quite a bunch of graphic bugs hidden here and there, like floating trees or walls that are magic mirros. Generally bugs are quite a huge problem of this game: Even in the intro video, where I couldn't do anything besides looking around, there were bugs already, like people sinking into the ground to their knees and bobbing up and down. After 7h of playing I already had 3 bugs that broke my missions and then I thought: "Ok, that's it. I should have saved my 2,50€ and bought a pound of minced meat instead." - And so should you!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Although this game is pretty okay, I prefer far cry 3 and even far cry 1 over this one. This game is a open world game in Africa, which has some pretty good exploration in some parts while having a lot of dull flat desert with nothing to do. This game also makes you work for every little thing. Everytime your car gets damaged, you have to get out and take a good 10-15 seconds to manually fix it. ALthough the bus travel is helpful, there is still a lot of dull going from point A to point B in this game. And the worst part of it is the outposts. There are a ton of outposts scattered around the map with a good 5-15 enemies at each one. This wouldn't be bad if they didn't respawn after you lost sight of it. So every trip you go (unless you wanna walk which obviously takes way too long) you have to deal with 2 or 3 of these camps.. both ways. The story (although you get to choose which side you are on) is really repetitive, whichever path you choose. "GO kill this guy, or this camp" not to mention several side missions you have to do to get malaria medicine. Oh yeah you get malaria in the beginning. Oh and guns jam.The good in this game though includes the diamond collecting system, the variety of weapons and vehicles but not much else, you are better off getting far cry 3 (or even 1)TL:DR: The game is an okay shooter, but i gets old fast and has a ton of annoying tidbits: respawing camps, jamming guns, and manual vehicle fixing.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												One of the few games I have ever had to just put down after only a few hours. Some people praise this game for its open and beautiful environment, but, after a while, you get tired of it. The game revolves around your character being dropped right in the middle of a developing African civil war and you have to stop it while also finding the man who's responsible for putting you there in the first place. The game is fairly normal, "go here, kill these guys, report back to this guy, claim reward." But the issue arises in the tedious nature of the game. Because you are in African you have malaria, so what do you do? Every thirty minutes or so you have to ingest malaria pills. This isn't bad in itself, but, when you are struggling to find the pills every thirty minutes because it's not to easy to come by, it gets frustrating. I'm told you eventually cure your malaria, but I never got far enough to get there. And then we come to the open world of the game. You travel from wide open savannahs to lush jungles and then to cities ridden by war and poverty. The environments are nice, but it's not so nice when the map is huge and each mission involves you travelling from one corner to the other. As a result, you find yourself constantly driving for long period of the game which gets very boring very quickly. Not only that, because you're in the middle of civil war Africa, you can't just drive anywhere. On your way, you will get assaulted by marauding thugs and wild animals, so you kill them. But you arrive at your destination finally and you're out of both ammo and health packs. This makes the mission incredibly difficult and boring because you have to play extremely carefully. The game just gets caught up in making you worry about menial things which aren't so menial after all and results in a not enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												An open world game based in Africa about warring factions within the country causing it to be closed off to the rest of the world. It certainly sounds like a cool premise to lose oneself in. Unfortunately through most of the game you'll trudge through brown environments and shooting down foes that pop up more often than whack-a-moles in places you thought you cleared out not more than minutes ago. Looking at Farcry 3, one can see how far Ubisoft came from. Play this if you want to experience a vastly inferior version of Farcry 3, otherwise I'd not recommend this unless it's on a insane sale or something like that.

												An open world game based in Africa about warring factions within the country causing it to be closed off to the rest of the world. It certainly sounds like a cool premise to lose oneself in. Unfortunately through most of the game you'll trudge through brown environments and shooting down foes that pop up more often than whack-a-moles in places you thought you cleared out not more than minutes ago. Looking at Farcry 3, one can see how far Ubisoft came from. Play this if you want to experience a vastly inferior version of Farcry 3, otherwise I'd not recommend this unless it's on a insane sale or something like that.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4
												Not sure why it says I have 1.3 hours on the game, I got at least half way through, maybe farther, however, I didn't finish because the game just felt too dated. I forced myself to play through the first far cry game, which was good, but also dated, and wasn't strong enough for this one. Honestly, it is a very good game. If I had played it when it came out, I would probably rank it among my favorite games, however now it just doesn't cut it. Pros:-The graphics were actually pretty good for the age of the game-Collecting diamonds in order to purchase/unlock new weapons gives it a sort of customizable feel-Combat is good. It might not be realistic pulling bullets out of your arm with a pair of needlenose pliers to recover a couple slots of health, but it's fun. You can't just run into an area guns ablazing and expect to live. It is necessary to put some thought into your loadout beforehand, and some strategy when accomplishing missions.Cons:-Travel. if you've played the game you'll understand. There are four or five fast travel locations in the original section of the map. The rest of the time, you just have to find a vehicle, or walk. Of course if your vehicle somehow gets destroyed in the middle of nowhere, you could be walking for 5-10 minutes to try and find another car, which in videogame time seems like an eternity. -Collecting Diamonds. This is also in the pros section. But there are times where it is just simply frustrating that the currency isn't something more reasonable or accessable. Instead your left searching under rocks and inside dilapidated sheds for diamonds like some crack addict trying to get his next fix. -Enemy outposts are always hostile. Seems pretty logical, however in a game this large, it's nice to have some friendly territory. Far Cry 3 and 4 fix this in that you can take over forts and outposts for your "faction" and thus render the entire surrounding areas friendly.Overall the game is good, if you can't stand old games, play far cry 3 or 4 if you like this genre. Otherwise, if you think you can overcome the obstacles layed out here, go for it.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												This game had so much potential, it does things differently than most FPS games. It has graphics that even years later still look great. But what we got is a driving simulator with occasional shooting missions for two indistinguishable generic African factions (none of them really seems to have any interesting agenda).Gunplay is fun and open world is impressive. I love how you can approach objective from different angle, set the grass on fire to prevent enemy from flanking you etc. Great. But there is not enough of it. Average mission looks like this:3 minute drive to the city to get the missionGeneric mission - go there /kill that/blow up this5 minute drive to the site (includes being shot at from outposts that you cleared dozen times, have I mentioned that respawns can be annoying)5 minute of really fun shooting5 minute drive back to the CityRinse and repeatBuddies actually make the problem even worse because more driving.I do not recommend....maybe if driving was more fun.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Far Cry 2 is a game that simulates what it's like to be a gun-for-hire in some war-torn African country.  And it is very good at that, for better or for worse.And from what I've experienced of it, it's for worse.  The constantly-jamming weapons, the fact that everyone's trying to kill you no matter who you align yourself with, a map interface that's clunky at best, and the malaria...oh, god, the malaria.  You have to take malaria pills every half-hour in-game, or you die.  And you only get four doses at a time - you replenish your pills at one specific in-game location.  It's all very frustrating, and all in the name of "a realistic experience."Let Far Cry 2 remain as an example of how realism doesn't always make a game better.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												This is a game that I vaguely recall liking when it was new, but every time I've tried to replay it the experience has been pure boredom.Here's how the game goes:- Go to quest giver.- Have exposition delivered by a third rate voice actor speed reading his lines.- Drive to the mission area.- Have your drive interrupted by an enemy checkpoint, even if it's the same faction that you're doing a mission for.- Drive some more.- Interrupted by another checkpoint.- Get to mission area, kill everyone there, then enter a safe zone building for more story delivered by an auctioneer.- Drive for 10 minutes back to the town to get another quest, clearing out the checkpoints you just cleared out a few minutes earlier.- Repeat.It has some things going for it. The world is beautiful, but it's completely empty with no reason to explore it. The weapon sound effects are fantastic, but the gunplay is unsatisfying because enemies take 10+ hits to die.  The story is interesting in a general sort of way, but it's told in the most boring way possible.This was a prototype for the Ubisoft open world games that they pump out like a factory these days, just like Assassin's Creed was.  And just like Assassins Creed, it's basically a beautiful world with almost no content to fill it.  The developers knew that which is why they designed the game so you spend 50% of your time driving in order to pad the length.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2011
												This game is relentlessly grim, and I mean "grim" in the sense it's hard to feel good while playing. The whole game sees you pushed around like a dumb animal and no matter who you work for you're as welcome as the plague. The "buddies" are harsh too. There are very few innocents and no sympathies to be won. Everyone dislikes you.  This was a notable thing for me because I questioned many times what the hell was motivating my character to continue on with his task.  Every single person was unpleasant and ready to kill me if not actually pulling the trigger the instant I was even slightly visible.The game starts out promising with unbelievably pretty visuals and an enormously strong appreciation for the real-ness of the landscape. The open world presentation is extremely compelling and made me want to go out and explore and admire everywhere, but it's nigh impossible to trave0l more than 2 minutes without being harassed by gunfire. There's no avoiding it either because while you can jitty-bop around trying to explore things (river travel is safest) the game requires you to backtrack through all of creation in order to perform certain missions or find the hidden gems needed to upgrade your weapons.  If the game were short or linear this might not be a problem but it ruins the sense of freedom since it kills your desire to go anywhere when the journey is a constant unyielding grind.  You can't even floor it and speed past the patrol stations in the hopes of actually making fast progress to your ultimate destination because inevitably some crazed vehicle will give chase and follow you FAR beyond all reasonable distances, and even if you manage to avoid the patrol stations there's still the chance you'll encounter a random vehicle and be locked into escape mode yet again.  There is satisfaction to be had if you've got a grenade launcher armed vehicle because you can vent your frustrations into the enemy when the umpteenth chase occurs, but really, it happens SO OFTEN that it just becomes tiresome.Despite that the game does have some rewarding combat shooting, a good driving experience, and a nice treasure hunt mechanic. It's such a pity that the fun to be found is mired in a frustrating slog of irritation.*edit* -played this a lot more than the 2 hours indicated by Steam.

												Even though this is a negative review I understand why many people enjoy Farcry 2.The open world feels rich, the combat is brutal and intense and the story builds up to an interesting point which helps to make it fun.The negative: I find that this game is against you the entire time since there is no real point in liberating outposts like there was in Farcry 3, the world is threating and unforgiving but in a way that makes me feel like the game is constantly being cheap and punishing me for try to play the way that I want which is mostly stealth. Also even though the story is good it doesn't make much sense at times and it just feels like that you want to get a faceless character to survive in a fiery hellhole in the African sahara. I would give this a 6/10 which is something that I really thought hard about but I felt everything in 2 was done better in farcry 1 and 3.

number of helpful: 9 of 24 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Far Cry 2’s greatest enemy is invisible and highly lethal. It is known as Plasmodium and it is the parasite responsible for malaria. Malaria is the most constant threat in Far Cry 2, yet, it feels to me that the disease is utilized half-heartedly as something that only annoys the player, rather than truly limiting them. Randomizing malaria attacks is designed to remove control from the player and provide a boundary to exploring the vastness of Far Cry 2’s carefully crafted countryside. The rapid onset of a malaria attack is coupled with blurred, swirling vision and reductions in stamina, but symptoms can be quickly relieved through the use of an immediate-action miracle pill. Of course, the pill box eventually empties and the malaria attacks keep coming, which sees the player faint and return to one of two locations where they can acquire more pills. There is no harsh punishment for death, because there is no death. The parasite does not kill you, it simply stops you.The quick-fix pill box renders the gameplay mechanic meaningless. It no longer becomes something that has to be micro-managed but something that becomes a frustrating distraction to the core gameplay. The mechanic itself is parasitic, damaging its host every time it randomly blurs the screen with a yellow tinge. If it was designed purely as a plot point, it should have been used as such. If it was designed to be micro-managed, then it should have been implemented with less abandon.Overall, I do not recommend Far Cry 2. It's a really bad Malaria simulator.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												Not quite the hair-tearing pain train of the first Far Cry, but still not yet reaching the now familiar Far Cry formula. The game has a nice, large map, but not much to do in between story missions that I've found. And if you're going to make a huge, empty map, at least let us get around quickly! Between the lack of fast travel, the map you have to hold instead of a weapon (a damn stupid idea, likely for the sake of "realism", and the fact that youcan never find a car when you REALLY need one, this FPS is starting to feel like more of a walking simulator than most walking simulators! The story may have been good, but I can't even begin to describe since I was distracted by the bad voice acting coupled with the ever present NPC glitches! Heads spinning around, teleporting back and forth, restarting lines over and over, jumping up and down for no reason, I've seen it all! I can't say I would have been suprised if the no-face glitch from AC: Unity was in there! Just play Far Cry 3.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game is boring, and the development feels lazy. It's an open world, but enemies constantly respawn over and over. Missions are repetitive. You will find yourself clearing the same interection of the same enemies again and again on your way to complete arbitrary missions in random parts of the world, and again on the way back to base.Fire is absolutely beautiful. Throw a grenade and it starts a fire that spreads realistically through the growth ... and then it stops, having burnt out a perfect and completely immersion-breaking circle centred at where your grenade exploded.You can help factions, but since apparently the devs were too lazy to properly implement this mechanic, you will always be on "secret" missions, such that EVEN THE FACTION MEMBERS will remain hostile. The whole world wants to kill you, and constantly respawns to boot.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												I kind of have a love hate relationship with ubisoft games. On one hand they get a lot of things right, and on the other they screw up the most fundemental elements.I have played Far Cry 1 2 and 3 now. FC1 is by far the best as far as enemy variety. FC2 improved visually but the world while looking beautiful was devoid of life. You never really encounter anything, it was all about your mission. The other big con in FC2 was the voice acting. You can tell they are just rambling words off a piece of paper with no thought or feeling to them which does negative zero for immersion. FC2 probably had one of the worst endings in history. No boss, no nothing. Just get to the end of the path and take out a few ordinary merc's. WTF???Far Cry 3 improved the world by populating it with lots of wildlife and random pirates here and there which is nice, however the NPC's have no life or interactivity to them. They just stay in their spot totally mute or muttering the same BS. Another immersion breaking thing is all the crates and boxes and suitcases and stuff you see in all the FC games are totally there just for show. You can't search them unless it is supposed to be searched. Any interactive item has to be in clear view and in most cases blinking. Even bodies blink. Seriously? is this a arcade game? C'mon!This is the DR Jeckle and Mr Hide that is Ubisoft. Why do these guys make a game so visually stunning and then go right the other way and try to make it as immersion breaking as humanly possible?Will not be gettin FC4. I just have no more faith in these guys anymore. I'm done with this series.Ugh !If you get FC2 or 3 then make sure to get mods that makes the games less stupid, if not then just go with FC1.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												2/10Easily one of the worst games I've had the displeasure of playing. The intro is decent and it seems okay at first but then you slide into the most repetitive, meaningless, copy pasted (literally, there are several locations and buildings you will go to that are the exact same) sad excuse for a game you'll ever play.The plot is basically not there. The entire game could easily be summed up in 20-30 seconds. What little plot there is really only exists at the beginning and end of the game, the middle part is just a bunch of filler fetch quests that have no meaning or impact. There is no resolution at the end, it actually straight up says that nothing that happened mattered.You have malaria through the whole game from the first scene. Because the first Far Cry had a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of awesome mutants at first I had assumed it wasn't really malaria and that at some point this game would have a plot twist and get better but no. It's just malaria and it also has pretty much no weight on anything that happens and it's just there to give you pointless missions to get pills in order to prolong the game.On top of all this there are TONS of bugs. If you don't turn VSync on the game glitches to the point where you can't even complete missions. There are constant glitches with NPCs where they will shake there heads, "slide" back and forth on the ground, or jitter up and down like they are jumping with no animation.The AI is terrible and the gunplay is bad. Not gonna go too into this but if you've played other FPS games it will feel "off" I guarantee it.Really hoping Far Cry 3 is as good as people say because this game was the biggest let down I've ever had. Kept playing hoping it would get better but it never does, it's just a horrid game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 20, 2011
												Far Cry 2 is the perfect mix of truly beautifully awesome vistas and gun-toting baddies. In true open world style you are simply given objectives and how you complete them is 100% up to you. I have done night stealth rescues with a dart rifle and silenced MP5, full on raids with an M249, and taken out convoys with IEDs. Some personal favorite methods of clearing enemy positions include setting a fire in the brush with a flare gun and just picking them off as they run out the front, and injuring one guy with a sniper shot to the legs then taking out his buddies as they try to get him up. FC2 really allows you to play however you want making it a great FPS/Action Adventure/Stealth game. I would give the replay value a rather high rating due to the grate map creation support. The game comes with a map editor and access to a map community in game, also servers can support map sharing allowing people to download maps if they do not have them. I bought FC2 for $7.49 but would vlaue it at 25.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												The American Dream. Mom. Apple Pie. All of this is epitomized in Far Cry 2.  Picking up directly where Far Cry 1 left off, you follow the story of Marcus Cole (voiced by indie-darling Nolan North) , a real American Joe Plumber and space marine.  This lighthearted, often whimsical story follows  Marcus learning to reconect with his teenage daughter through the slaughter of an alien horde.  This game is said to have inspired Joseph Conrad's classic satire, Heart of Darkness, which in turn inspired Francis Ford Coppola's Vietnam epic, M*A*S*H.  The one slander I can lay against this game is the paucity of enemies.  I can drive around for hours and hours without seeing a single enemy.  Despite that, this game is one of the funniest I have ever played and perfect for the 4th of July.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2012
												This is a game I keep coming back to time after time. The game is set in Africa, and  you play as a man hired to hunt down and kill "the Jackal" that is an arms dealer that is selling weapons to the different factions currently in a curfuffle with each other. On your way through the intro, you get malaria and almost die. The Jackal meets you and explains to you why you how you failed your job, and cannot go after him anymore. From there on it's all about getting missions from the different factions in the area, choosing sides, and letting the story play itself out. The world you play in is huge, and gets even bigger after a while. The game mechanics make this game very enjoyable. The missions don't differ too much in what exactly you're supposed to do, but the game makes up for it in story and atmosphere. There are plenty of different vehicles, including cars, trucks, boats, hang gliders, and tons of different weapons for however you want to carry out one of your many many missions.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												This is a game that seriously grows on you, first of all.  It takes a bit of patience to get through the intro, and even then the gameplay feels limited, with jamming guns, slow sprinting, tedious travel, and constantly respawning enemies that will bumrush you at every opportunity, without warning.And yet, this game is my absolute favorite FPS.  The experience is fantastic.  The gunplay's great, the exploration/environment's better, and everything as a whole flows together in a way that delivers.  The AI is ruthless, they'll flank you and surprise you at every turn, and stop at nothing to get rid of you.  Your job is simple, find one man perpetuating a war in South Africa as an arms dealer, and kill him.  That's your only objective, and how you accomplish it is entirely up to you.  Work with(and against) the factions battling, meet others like yourself and work alongside them, and betray whoever you feel necessary to.  The game gives you a world of choice, from rescuing your buddies from certain death, to killing them yourself to save your own medical supplies.  Everything you do is secondary to finding The Jackal.  From the people you meet to the destruction you cause.The game's tone is way darker than that of 3, for sure.  It illustrates what it is to be caught in the middle of a conflict powered only by greed, where innocents are just fresh meat stuck in the crossfire.  Nobody can be trusted, and everyone is your enemy until proven otherwise.  The land is struck by the plague of war and corruption, and at the center is your target.  But you yourself are no different, you work for the same reason as the others, money.  The game emphasizes later that there's no winning, only one who loses first.So if you're looking for a challenging title that presents you with an equally immersive plot and environment, pick this up.  It takes a while to get into, but once you're into it, you're REALLY into it.  I bought this twice, once on console and again on Steam because it's just that good.  Better than 3, honestly.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												It's a great open world game. But there are some issues I honestly didn't like. I understand your character is diagnosed with malaria, but I hate the fact that you have to keep taking pills every now and then, especially in a heavy firefight. Another issue is that all you do is drive over and over across the unnamed country of Africa. There is a fast travel system, but there only in specific places. Lastly, your guns jams in random moments. I understand the realistic feel but jamming guns ruin the fun of the game in my opinion. I recommend getting it on sale. The story is long but can be a bit confusing later on. But it feels great headshotting enemies at night time (especially in a rainy weather) with a silenced pistol. The enemies take forever to kill for some reason. You can empty your entire pistol clip on anyone and they would still survive and attack, so the gunplay is very stiff and different. Good game, but you don't have to play this one if you're planning on playing Far Cry 3. I give it an 8/10.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												Still a GREAT game. If you put in mind this is a 2008's game you will realize that graphics are really detailed for that time, and the mechanics of the game are also really good. I got hooked in the Multiplayer for 2 years long (in PS3) but the lack of players on server made stop to play. Now, I could buy this on Steam Summer Sale for US$1,99 and I got servers w/ players all around (that's not like CS servers, but at least it's not empty). The music are good, the ambient sound also. They don't have detailed Snipers guns or ironsights, but for me, just because the maps, is one of the best Sniper Multiplayer Game in the history. The Map Editor bring so much fun to the game and I remember a map in PS3 where we play over a huge SNES built with the map map editor, but really huge, and Snipers were necessary all time and it's was so much fun. I played on PC and the graphics are really better than the console version (as always...). Just one con: the long distances you have to travel to visit or fight for some spot. Even though the ambient is good, the time spent on it driving is boring and repetitive. This game is definitely worth buying. Multiplayer Game is fun as hell.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 22, 2011
												Look, Far Cry 2 isn't for everyone. BUT, if you're willing to put up with it's few faults (mainly enemies respawning after you clear an area) Far Cry 2 is a gorgeous and immersive single player experience that allows you to 'play it your way' a lot more than most shooters. It also helps if you find it funny when things go sideways on you in the middle of a gunfight.The best way to approach the game is to try doing stuff you'd do in a real situation - it's pleasantly surprising how often this works. :)Tips: Learn how to navigate using your map (also, learn the map locations). Stealth works best in the dark of night. You don't have to take every mission you're offered - the story line will adjust itself to your schedule (mostly). Africa is the LAND of FREE CARS, so don't get too attached to your current ride. Always check the wind direction before starting a fire. ;)Finally, DON'T just follow the roads-- this isn't a corridor shooter!Also, you can set things on fire. :D

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Basically, really fun open world shooter.Set in Africa, Far Cry 2 features really enormous maps to get lost in. The weapons are varied and I quickly found combination for any situation, from full frontal assault with a grenade launcher, crossbow and silenced pistol for sneaking, remote detonated explosives that allow you take out a whole convoy in one button push and even a mortar that, while hard to use, lets you soften up enemy locations before charging in.While the story is not anything special, there are numerous side quests to keep you occupied and directed. The main focus is on the gameplay and it makes for a very fun shooter, rarely limiting you and allowing you to, most times, choose which way you want to finish a mission, though these options are mostly limited to type of approach.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2013
												Far Cry 2 is a great open world game that takes place in Africa. You’re playing a mercenary caught between a bloody civil war between APR and UFLL. Your main objective is to take down an arms dealer that has been funding both sides of war in Africa for several years. The only hint of evidence you have of this arms dealer is his name; The Jackal.I’m quite impressed by the story and character development of this game, it’s very mature and realistic. It takes major cues from real life activities in Africa, so this game is not “just” a run and gun game.There are several missions to choose from besides the main quests. You have your “Buddy” quests and assassination quests where you’re supposed to take some baddies down.If you’re into an open world game where you can travel in Africa by foot, truck, bus, quad-bike and even a buggy and see the savanna and jungle of Africa, then I recommend this game.One aspect of the game that confused me majorly was the AI of the enemies. There were several times where they shoot you through walls. The bullets weren’t hitting me, but it confused the hell out of me since I couldn’t judge whether the enemies could see me or not.Peace.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Compared to its predecessor, the gameplay is infinitely better, and pretty much every other area as well. Almost all the weapons are very fun to use and the fact that weapons gradually wear out in use -- making them less reliable to a point where they simply break -- is a neat little touch, though the guns sometimes feel perhaps too flimsy.The enemy AI feels very poorly designed, every single enemy having the tenacity and willpower you would only see in the most battle-hardened movie heroes. No matter what you do or where you are, they will see you, they will chase you, they will appear in sometimes seemingly endless numbers in incoming vehicles.The missions are all frustrating, either in their simplicity or when you decide to do the extra missions by your partners, always making the missions end in you having to save them like damsels in distress. The story is rather dull, you're just a random mercenary, doing what you're told to do (rather poorly).The game has a lot of potential to be an entertaining sandbox game, but it lacks in some critical areas, making it a very mediocre game overall. Only get this game if it's on sale for chickenfeed.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												NOTE: I've already completed this game three times on PS3.Far Cry 2 is one of the most immersive, engrossing and daring first-person shooters I've ever played. It dares to be realistic. It dares to be unforgiving. It dares to be different. The result is an experience that's truly unlike any other in the market (well, aside from STALKER, a personal favorite of mine that happens to be similar to Far Cry 2.) Far Cry 3 might get all the attention these days, but it eschewed the identity and "raw" nature of Far Cry 2 in favor of having more OTT action and frankly, playing it safe. Far Cry 2 might not be the funnest game on the market, but it is one of the boldest gaming experiences of the last gaming generation (along with STALKER) and an excellent shooter to boot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												The only reason you don't have to press Y to eat or 'use the facilities' is because you've mainlined so much morphine you're still digesting the meal you ate before the first cutscene. Ruined my life; five stars. :PSeriously, though, this is a game you either love or hate, and as far as I can tell how you feel about it depends on what you were expecting.What it's not:A scripted, linear power fantasy with clear objectives, frequent checkpoints, lots of hand-holding, and jingoistic moral certainty backed up by a cinematic orchestral score (I'm looking at you, COD).What it is:An open-world survival game that gives you shooting, driving, and stealth mechanics so you can go from point A to point Z using whatever combination of the other letters you see fit. It has all the hallmarks of a shooter, but I hesitate to call it one because shooting is only the means to an end; in many cases, your interests (and the interests of your employer) are best served by minimizing or avoiding enemy contact. It's best described as a survival/horror title disguised as a cross between GTA and COD.The game is set in an unnamed African country, a pastiche of every African civil war of the last few decades. Everyone you meet is either an enemy or a potential enemy, and there are far more of the former than the latter. You're not such a great guy yourself; you're a mercenary hired through unofficial channels to find and kill the Jackal, an internationally notorious arms dealer who has been supplying all sides of a conflict that has killed thousands and displaced hundreds of thousands.At the very beginning of the game you find the Jackal (or rather, he finds you) after you're incapacitated by a bout of malaria. Since you've failed in your mission and are no longer being paid to kill him, the Jackal taunts you and leaves you to die. You're rescued by one of the factions in the war, and, since you're now trapped in-country, you start doing missions and sidequests for the various factions and individuals you come across.You will be very glad to come across some of them. One of the game's most interesting mechanics is the Buddy system. Buddies offer alternative solutions to faction missions. These solutions are more convoluted than the original mission, but are sometimes easier and always result in an upgrade to the player's safehouses. Buddies also save your life. The first time you're killed in a firefight, you're only wounded. Your buddy drives up, drags you to safety, and helps you finish off nearby enemies.This is good, because the penalty for dying is severe. Save points are located only in safe areas, which are few and far between. This really ratchets up the tension; you're a lot less likely to try something stupid if you know it will cost you half an hour of progress. For me, at least, that's a good thing: the crazy moments are exhiliarating /because/ they're not spoon-fed to you.Edit: just discovered the quick-save function. I wish they hadn't included it. This game is all about punishment; if you want something easier, you're playing the wrong game. I'm not saying this as a snob. There are plenty of games where this function would be welcome, but it doesn't belong here. :(The shooting mechanics are decent. Aim, shoot, repeat. Enemies take way too many shots to put down on the highest difficulty, but if you're running and gunning you're playing it wrong. The whole point of an open world is that it doesn't funnel you through a series of checkpoints; if you hit each checkpoint just because it's there, you might as well be playing Halo. Guns in this game degrade, jam, and eventually break. This increases tension, especially because of how often it happens, but once I learned to stop by the armory between missions, I never had another jam.The stealth in this game works well, but it doesn't hold your hand. There are no on-screen detection indicators or mini-radar to show you who's spotted you; you just have to listen for footsteps, engines, and enemy chatter. Enemies react to gunfire, near misses (even from silenced weapons), engine noise, and of course, direct visual contact. If you want to be stealthy you're going to have to stay low, still, and in the dark. Even then you're not perfectly invisible, and the enemy will search your last known location if they lose sight of you. They're not actually cheating; on multiple occasions I've fooled the AI by firing an unsuppressed weapon and relocating. The AI is just very good, especially on the higher difficulty levels.The driving mechanics are "meh". You point the car, hit the gas, let off the gas when you get there. Hit the brakes if you're going faster than you meant to. Not complicated. Vehicles take damage but can be repaired, which is good since you will be doing a LOT of driving. Fast travel is limited to some bus stops spaced roughly equally around the map. You're going to do some walking and some driving even if you take the bus, which is probably for the best since the game rewards exploration with conflict diamonds (the only in-game currency) hidden all over the map.Player progression is indirect; there are no experience points. You earn diamonds, buy better equipment, become more effective. Enemies become more effective as their factions also gain access to better equipment. You never permanently depopulate an area, but you can unlock safehouses all over the map and upgrades for those safehouses. I personally prefer it this way, but your mileage may vary.Plot-wise, you really have to pay attention to what's going on, or all the different factions and missions blur together. I think this was intentional. One of the game's central themes is that in wars like this there aren't any good guys. The pointless violence and constant danger wear you down because they're /supposed/ to. It's a survival game, not an action movie. Or rather, it's an action game about all the things that action games usually glamorize, ignore, or gloss over. It's Game of Thrones with AK47s and IEDs.TL;DR:This game is a little rough around the edges because the developers were trying to do something new and unique instead of publishing new missions for an old game with minor tweaks to the gameplay. This turns a lot of people off, not because it's bad, but just because it was a different kind of awesome than they were expecting. (In case you can't tell, I despise the COD/Halo crowd for what they've done to gaming. >:( ) FC2 is only $10, including the DLC/preorder bonus, so give it a go. The setting is imaginary, but the PTSD is only too real. :)

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												Played this after playing Far Cry 3 and Blood Dragon.Things I like:- "Buddy system" where people you meet come help you when you're in trouble- Cool healing mechanics (digging out bullets, syringes, etc.)- Enemies are non-descript and combat is difficult- Open world feel with one objective, "do what you want" atmosphere- Pulling up map and GPS is very inventive and immersiveThings I dislike:- Voice acting is very fast paced and sounds unnatural- Takes a LOT of bullets to down an enemy- No melee, only if you pull out your knife and whack 'em, which is pretty useless in a fight- Map is bothersome if you're trying to walk around with it, pops up and down while you're walking- Blur effects on aim and sprint. OMG the sprint. It made me sick every time I tried to move faster. It focuses in and out while you sprint and it's nauseating. - No direction as to what I'm supposed to do- "Scouting" outposts is confusing as even after eliminating all enemies I have to walk around the whole place several times to get it to trigger- Currency is in Diamonds - you have to find diamonds using your GPS, which is annoying and distracting - no other way to get diamonds (?) besides missions maybe? I didn't really have any motivation to do anythingMostly I just couldn't play long enough because the blurring effects were hurting my eyes. This was with bloom and "post" (which I'm assuming is post processing) off/low. Also, I didn't really have any motivation to do anything, the rewards weren't tangible.At this point in time you'd be better off playing Far Cry 3 and/or Blood Dragon, I honestly think they're more fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Far Cry 2 gives you a set of tools (guns, explosives, stealth, vehicles, the environment, etc...) and puts you in scenarios (getting through checkpoints, avoiding/destroying patrols, assaulting shanty towns, villas, or hunting lodges, blowing up convoys, etc...) wherein you are free to use those tools in any way you wish. If this sounds appealing, give the game a shot.Keep in mind though, that the game is hard: Encounters quickly spiral out of control. Enemies can kill you in a single shot. The A.I. tries to pin you down and flank you. When things go right, you'll want to jump up and down and spike a football into the nearest endzone. When things go wrong (and they often go wrong), you'll have 5-10 minutes of the tensest gameplay imaginable as you try to regain the upper hand. Expect to ragequit a few times.Unlike Dark Souls, however, the difficulty doesn't make the game a tedious process of trial and error. When you fail, you will know why you failed. If you take some time and think through your options, you'll come up with something that will work. The game is cool like that.The story is nothing to write home about, but it does have a few interesting things to say about the arms trade in post-colonial Africa where war is often a product manufactured for export. One more thing; a small thing. The voice overs are good. I hate games with American/Canadian actors doing bad, inconsistent, European accents (I'm looking at you Skyrim). All the voice overs were recorded in South Africa, so the accents at least sound... African.

												This game is a far cry from what I call realistic and or playable. I purchased this game at the extremely unreasonably price of $4.99, an amount of money much better spent on 2 cans of soda or a large packet of salt and vinegar chips at your local over-priced milk bar. Not only is the colour pallet utterly unpalatable, but the combat become repetitive and forced in later missions. The unrealism starts when you are driving in a car with a negro man. I myself, am not racist, but my character in Far Cry 2 I imagine, would have a distinct racist attitude towards Africans. And pulling a gun on the African whilst he is driving, crashing the car and killing  both him and myself, would not be a opportunity wasted in my characters eyes. I was considering giving them game at 10/10 because of the realistic healing mechanic, but the points I have made earlier clearly present a VERY REASONABLE  final score of -3/10.

												I think Far Cry 2 was made for a very specific kind of gamer. People who like respawning enemies, smart AI and not being stuck on a rail but aren't really in it for the story will probably like Far Cry 2. The core mechanics are pretty solid. The story isn't bad but it's not really all that intriguing.Of all the games being previewed at E3 this year I thought Far Cry 3 was the most epic.
