number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												None of the Far Cry sequels follow each other. I played Far Cry 1, 2, and 3 a little bit. They all seem to have a different unconnected story to the lastr one. I found Far Cry 1 story line to be the best because it had a meaning and a cause. A secret agent (not really so secret because everyone knew who he was) trying to save the world from maniacal domination.  Far Cry 2 shows a mercenary (Afflict3ed with a bad case of malaria) making money as a hired gun and finding diamonds to buy better guns and ammunitions. His only purpose is to complete tasks and survive. Did I mention he was supposed to work secretly for a govermenbt agency? What agency would hire (dosen't really pay him or supply him with any weaponry) an afflicted person with malaria?Now I did mention I played Far Cry 3 a little bit. I don't kknow what I expected, but, from what I gather, there seems to be some sort of revenge game playing out. It starts out with someone's younger brother, with no formal qualifications, (unlike the two previous versions where at least the main characters had some training in combat), managers to accumulate weaponry and skillsets almost instantly. He then has to complete some tasks to get better weapons and ammunitions before going on the hunt for killers and saving his friends. So it kind of falls back to the level of Far Cry 2 after awhile.After all, I do recommend all of The Far Cry series. Just bring your imagination!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Far Cry 2 is a solid shooter set in a beautiful world where awareness and control of the environment are important. Unfortunately the game is severely bogged down by tedious repetitive missions, slow and annoying travel, fast-spawning enemies, lack of stuff to do, and a general lack of direction or sense of progress. Honestly, when I was looking at reviews to write this article after giving up on the game, I was shocked to see a Metacritic rating of 85%. This is a game that could have been great with a few tweaks, but instead packs in too many annoyances to be fun. There's a phenomenal core but it's obscured by a lot of flaws.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2014/01/far-cry-2.html

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Still a GREAT game. If you put in mind this is a 2008's game you will realize that graphics are really detailed for that time, and the mechanics of the game are also really good. I got hooked in the Multiplayer for 2 years long (in PS3) but the lack of players on server made stop to play. Now, I could buy this on Steam Summer Sale for US$1,99 and I got servers w/ players all around (that's not like CS servers, but at least it's not empty). The music are good, the ambient sound also. They don't have detailed Snipers guns or ironsights, but for me, just because the maps, is one of the best Sniper Multiplayer Game in the history. The Map Editor bring so much fun to the game and I remember a map in PS3 where we play over a huge SNES built with the map map editor, but really huge, and Snipers were necessary all time and it's was so much fun. I played on PC and the graphics are really better than the console version (as always...). Just one con: the long distances you have to travel to visit or fight for some spot. Even though the ambient is good, the time spent on it driving is boring and repetitive. This game is definitely worth buying. Multiplayer Game is fun as hell.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												I've enjoyed Far Cry 2 for the most part. The map is huge, and the graphics are great for a game that was made in 2008. Unfortunately, I played Far Cry 3 before touching this one, and that was my downfall. Right off the bat I was confused about the story, what was going on, and what I needed to do. I actually had to read about the game's story on the Far Cry Wiki to get a grasp on the situation. The voice acting is bland and it just doesn't feel like there is any life in the game. The weapon jamming system has gotten on my nerves more than enough. Even though it adds a great taste of realism to the game, it makes me rage when I'm in the middle of a firefight and POOF, there goes my gun! Oh, and speaking of firefights, the enemy AI in this game is your typical mid 2000s AI...expert marksmen. That, and they know exactly where the ♥♥♥♥ you are at all times once they spot you. There is no point in being stealthy in the game. I'm enjoying my experience with Far Cry 2 as best as I can, but sadly, this seems like a game I'm just going to shelve once I'm finished. I give Far Cry 2 a 6 out of 10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Far Cry 2 does an incredible job not at turning you into a hero, but in making you feel like a weak, desperate mercenary, hunted by an entire populace of a region.  Not just in the story, the AI scripting, mission structure and locales make you realize that one likes you here.  In most case, the only thing from keeping you from being shot on sight is that either you are beign used (and then will be shot) or that they still haven't physically seen you.  This slowly adds to an unnerving, tense and unforgiving experience.  I can honestly say that no game has made me feel that harsh cold feeling of shooting someone down and then feeling a slow pang in  my gut, not because I am sorry, but because a part of me realizes "...it was either me or him".

												After finishing this game, Kiwi laid down in a corner and cried, wondering how a loving God could allow such things. After a few hours of crying, Kiwi had an epiphany, if this exists, then there can be no God. Then Kiwi read some depressing poetry and cried in a corner for a few more hours. This game uses what some considers "flaws" or "really bad design" (such as the realistic "Africa is actually a giant rust monster" mechanic) to its advantage to be the best "Africa is a Terrible Place" simulator. If you're a masochist, buy this game. If you want to convert a "friend" to atheism, buy this game for them.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												It's one of the most immersive shooters ever made. No hand holding, no fancy HUD or minimap,... just you, your gun and some malaria pills.The guns feel very real, if you stick to old guns and battlefield pickup weapons, you'll be clearing jams quite often. It's also one of the only Far Cry games in which all guns really had a place. I've used them all instead of just buying the "best" one as soon as I could.The storyline isn't the best, but it manages to make you doubt the decisions you're making and adds to the immersive feeling of being a gun for hire in Africa.Gameplay can be a little repetitive, as outposts don't stay cleared like in later FC games, but if you try out new ways of passing them, they stay fun IMO.I'd rate this game a solid 9/10, and wish that Ubisoft would go back to making FC games like this.

												With an emphasis on realism and dirty, African politics rather than sex and drugs, I feel that this game's setting makes it superior to Far Cry 3. However, it is not without its faults. People who like respawning enemies, smart AI and not being stuck on a rail but aren't really in it for the story will probably like Far Cry 2. The core mechanics are pretty solid. The story isn't bad but it's not really all that intriguing.Of all the games being previewed at E3 this year I thought Far Cry 3 was the most epic. Unfortunately for some reason no one else seems to share my enthusiasm and I'm not entirely sure why. Maybe for the same reasons above.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Far Cry 2 gives you a set of tools (guns, explosives, stealth, vehicles, the environment, etc...) and puts you in scenarios (getting through checkpoints, avoiding/destroying patrols, assaulting shanty towns, villas, or hunting lodges, blowing up convoys, etc...) wherein you are free to use those tools in any way you wish. If this sounds appealing, give the game a shot.Keep in mind though, that the game is hard: Encounters quickly spiral out of control. Enemies can kill you in a single shot. The A.I. tries to pin you down and flank you. When things go right, you'll want to jump up and down and spike a football into the nearest endzone. When things go wrong (and they often go wrong), you'll have 5-10 minutes of the tensest gameplay imaginable as you try to regain the upper hand. Expect to ragequit a few times.Unlike Dark Souls, however, the difficulty doesn't make the game a tedious process of trial and error. When you fail, you will know why you failed. If you take some time and think through your options, you'll come up with something that will work. The game is cool like that.The story is nothing to write home about, but it does have a few interesting things to say about the arms trade in post-colonial Africa where war is often a product manufactured for export. One more thing; a small thing. The voice overs are good. I hate games with American/Canadian actors doing bad, inconsistent, European accents (I'm looking at you Skyrim). All the voice overs were recorded in South Africa, so the accents at least sound... African.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2012
												Hmmmm, I don't know about this. The game has a very cool atmosphere and plenty of beautiful landscapes. The fire spreading element of attack is very cool as well. But then you have the very annoying suicide AI drivers that want to run you over and have more than enough accelerating power to do it (0 to Top Speed, less than 1 second) who only get worse when there's a machine gun mounted on top of the vehicle they're driving. There's also the inhuman aim that every enemy has as well, making every weapon into a sniper for them. And the fact that clearing enemy hideouts does nothing to stop them from being there and shooting at you the next time you come by. The travel in the game can get tedious, and the missions repetitive. But despite the flaws, I still like the game. Must be the over-the-top nature of all its flaws. Only buy the game if you enjoy cool game environments, it's cheap, and/or you don't mind driving for 5 minutes one-way to kill someone for every mission.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												I bought it on a whim, on sale.  The graphics are really pretty despite its age. The story lineis very immersive, and the open ended nature of open world play gives me a sense of setting myown story. The combat is basically a series of ambush style attacks. You either sneak in, or recon by fire your way in, depending on your mood.  You can expect frequent ambushes by Jeep henchmen every 5 minutes if you are moving around the world. Its the best Fiver I have spent of lately and I really enjoy the combat mechanic of dealing with a wounded and hiding target. The AI seems when under fire can just hide instead. They flank really well and can be a royal pain. You have to be tactically aware and ready to fall back to a secondary position or you will be outflankedvery quickly. During the firefights where I am moving and trying to outflank 4-5 aggressive targets, you can really lose yourself in the game. There are no shortage of Jeeps in this game, and with the ability to repair them, you are never going to need to, unless you prefer to, walk a long distance. Some of these older gem games give you so much fun for so little. My lunch cost more than I paid for this game.10/10 Would start a Jeep dealership in Africa again and again.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2013
												A fantastic, immersive experience that sets the player as one of a number of characters in the dusty African plains, surviving as best he or she can. The game rarely holds your hand during your time in it and though it has tutorials for the games main functions, once you're out there, you're dealing with an imperfect body and an imperfect world. From the weapon breaking, vehicle repairs, checkpoints being repopulated soon after take over, your own malaria and limitations, enemies that are unpredictable and eagle eyed and the sun drenched atmosphere, it all adds up to one hell of a game. Negatives include a make of it what you will storyline, character dialogue that has no breaks and the fact it's not like any other shooter. Right, not much really. Word has it FC2's main complaint about respawning checkpoint / enemy bases is about to be repatched into Farcry 3. Not so bad after all is it naysayers?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												Farcry 2 is a great game at first glance. Beautiful graphics, decently inteligent AI and plenty of missions.But diving deeper into everything, it's apparant that it isn't really all that great. There is no autosaving from what I can tell; I just end up saving everytime I do something I don't want to have to do over, or if I spend more than 3 minutes doing anything. And when I forget to save I end up seriously regretting it, or I just quit for the day. The storyline essentially consists of doing dirtywork for a bunch of forgettable characters that have commercial-like sped up voices as if they have no time to slow down and are on cocaine. And pretty everything the two major factions will have you do involves blowing up something that only one faction has because if we can't have it, no one can - why not just steal it?!? Luckily(?) your 'buddies' will offer up alternatives such as stealing something so you can move the explosion somewhere where it can blow up something else that also deserves being blown up. In the end, all you've really done is generally destablized a country just so you can gain info on some guy who is trying to destabilize the country so you can kill him - beacause he is a bad man... at least his hidden collectible tapes offer some interesting moral thoughts.The graphics are beautiful, the fire spread mechanics are awesome. Unfortunatly it seems as though the developers thought they could get away with making the game so distractingly gorgeous that players would forget about things like plot and variety and gameplay and....The missions are all very dull; blow up convoys to unlock new weapons to purchase, kill guys in suits to get diamonds, blow up stuff for factions to get more diamonds, blow up other stuff to help out your buddies(' egos), deliver passports to get malaria drugs.Traveling in the beautiful world isn't super fun either. Your safest bet is to take a bus anywhere, but then you have to deal with loading screens and the possibility that it didn't really save you any time due to their not-so-perfect placement. The alternative is to follow the roads and run into checkpoints that are still full of guards after being cleared out, or stray from the roads and get your unimog stuck on a tiny rock (HOW?!?) and still have the chance of being chased by guards with grenade launchers or machine guns with extreme catch-up ability. I try to avoid roads and checkpoint at all costs, just because there is no fun in jumping out of your vehicle and quickly gunning them down; it happens way to often and feels like a chore more than anything else.The enemies are pretty smart, taking advantage of cover to flank you and then unleash all their shotgun ammo on you. Snipers and guided rocket launcher equipped enemies have amazing sightlines and will take advantage of their distance between you to knock you down a few bars of health. It is possible to stealth with the camo suit and some silenced weapons, but once you kill someone, there isn't much you can do but hide.Finding and earning diamonds is your gateway to new weapons, equuipment and upgrades, which all help substantially. It is worth finding diamonds that pop up while traveling or gunning down bases, but with all the diamonds you'll get from missions, it isn't really necessary to go hunting for the last few hidden stashes unless you just have to have every weapon.The level design itself is very good, but they should have focused more on making the enemy AI and travel mechanics more player friendly. If I had looked into the developer's office while this game was under development, I'd wager a guess that the story writers and graphic designers were the serious driving force behind this game while the programmers just threw together some code without giving it a real playtest beyond looking at the trailer material. I'm giving this game a 65/100 mainly because it isn't as fun as it could be.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Farcry 2 is an FPS ,with slight RPG qualities, game set in a fictional African country currently engaged in a civil war. You play as one of the few preset characters that you can choose from. As a mecenary and gun for hire, tasked to kill the infamous arms dealer " The Jackal ", you'll be traversing and fighting your way through the grim of civil war, waged by the APR and UFLL factions, and the natural beauty of the African savanah and jungle. However, upon your arrival to the nearest hotel, you discover you have a severe case of malaria and are hindered by it occasionally through out your game experience. It impedes your mission, but you will have to overcome it and the civil war to get your target, and possibly find a way out of the country. Gameplay:The game is an FPS and as such you'll be seeing the world through the characters POV. From this perspective you'll be able to see your characters health, ammo, healing syringes and throwable weapons (grenades and molotoves) count. You can also bring up your handheld map to see your current location, objectives and available missions. However, you are unarmed while you have your map in hand.The gameworld is divided into two main zones: The Northern district ( Leboa-Sako ) and the Southern District ( Bowa-Seko ), the latter only being accesible during the later half of the game. Each zone is sub-divided into 9-grid squares, namely NW,N,NE,E,SE,S,SW,W and Central, with the exception of the one grid connecting the two main zones. Each zone is free for you to explore at your own pace and leisure. The game also features a day and night cycle that will affect your visibility and that of the AI.The main missions follow the story and will have you doing unique missions for which ever faction gave it to you. You'll also meet and aquire buddies, othere mecenaries and foreigners, that will help give optional missions to do as well as affect how you finish a main mission. They will also rescue you should you get knocked out. Currency:As this is a civil war, paper and any official money is trash, as one man puts it: "I wound't wrap a fish with it." Diamonds are used as the only currency worth anything and you aquire them through either doing main missions or finding diamond cases ( which give from 1-3 diamonds ). Diamond cases are scattered around the map and you'll need your tracker, which is equiped with your map or when driving, to identify their presence and locate them. In the top left corner of each grind is a number indicating the amount of diamonds in that area. There are 221 diamond cases in total, 1 is given to you in the tutorial part of the game and shows how to work the tracker at the same time.Traveling:As this is a quite a large map to explore you'll often more than not be taking a vehicle to get to your destination or simply to drive in. the game has a small selection of vehicles ( including jeeps, a car, trucks, a quadbike, a buggy and boats ) that you can use to traverse around and get about to where you need to go. Each vehicle is unique in its properties as some are more practical, having mounted weapons but being slightly more bulky, while others are more simple and smoother to drive. There are also fixed bus stations located in the NW,NE,SW,SE and central grids of the map that will allow a form of fast-travel between them. In anycase, it's up to you on how you want to go about getting to places. Driving is solid with a firm handling on steering, but the speed of your vehicle can only go to a certain limit.Combat:The AI in this game are quite aggresive and perceptive. They will fight and chase you ( if you drive away and they have a vehicle nearby ) "till death, no matter which faction your working for at the moment. They will flank you if you stay too long in one spot and thier snipars have a sharp eye for things moving a good distance away from them ( thankfully they are poor shots ). The AI will also respawn, whether it be at key outpost that you have already cleared or just a patrol vehicle on the road, and very quickly I will add. You can move a good half km from an outpost only to return to it and find it filled with enemies again. This can both a nuisance and problem at times, depending on your difficulty, playstyle and general mood. This is why I stated that vehicles with mounted weapons are more practical as you can easily use them to clear out outpost or patrols and move on. Alternatively you can avoid outposts by giving them a good distance and at night their perception is much lower.Weapons:You have 4 weapons in the game that you can carry on you at a once: Your melee weapon ( a Machette ), your primary weapon ( Assualt rifles, SMG, shotguns and snipar rifles ), your secondary weapon ( pistols, IED's, semi-automatics and a grenade luancher ) and your special weapons ( flamerthrower, mortar, RPG's, LMG's ect ). You'll start out with the basics, but you'll be able to aquire and purchase more weapons and upgrades as you do special missions given at the weapon stores/storages. Weapons handle well in the game and feel as powerful as they should, accordingly. Upgrades:You can upgrade your weapons ( after you purchase them ) as well as purchase some general upgrades to your equipment and gear. Weapon upgrades include accuracy, reliability and total ammunition count. General upgrades include increased syringe count, camo suit, vehicle repair speed and degradation reduction.Degradation:Weapons and vehicles will deteriorate over time and use. As weapons become more broken they will jam more often and miss fire occasionally, while vehicles will tend to break down more quickly and appear "rekt" after constant assualt. ( Literally, your vehicle will look as if it was vandalised and striped of any useful parts and then driven through a mound of♥♥♥♥♥♥) Weapons can easily be replaced for new ones at your weapon stores/storages. As for vehicles, simply steal a new one.DLC content:This simply adds two new vehicles , the quadbike and the armored assualt truck, as well as 3 new unique, free weapons to your storage ( a sawn-off shotgun, a silenced, pump-action shotgun and an explosive bolt crossbow ). Not very game changing, but nice to have non the less.Bugs:There are a few bugs i've noticed, but non break the game or how you play it. Oddly enough, I don't recall these bugs on my retail version of the game that I bought back when this came out. Sometimes a NPC will "slide" up a wall or vertical surface, often when leaning agaisnt it, other times they will seem to randomly burst around the room if they are performing an animation ( such as giving malaria pills ) and their model colides with a fixed asset. It happens occasionaly, but I just find these bugs funny.Tips and Hints>If you have to drive a good distance that is on the path of a few outposts, simply move along the edge of the outer grids, in that way you can avoid them until you reach your point.>If you want to find all the diamonds in the game, you can find the maps on the Farcry 2 wiki with all the locations listed.>Note that even with all the diamonds found and main missions done, you won't be able to purchase every weapon and upgrade, so spend wisely.>Purchasing the primary,secondary and special storage crates is very situational. It simply allows you to universally store that weapon type in a specific crate that can be accessed at any of your safe houses that you have unlocked. However, you will have to replace the weapon once it has been taken out.>If a buddy has rescued you recently, he/she will be on a cooldown of sorts. You can reset this cooldown by finding them at any one of your unlocked safe houses and talking to them.>Beware of veldt fires.>Golden AK-47's do not rust, and do not respawn.>The Machette will insta-kill any enemy.Thanks for reading :)

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												I can't recommend this game. Driving around to missions takes forever. Constant checkpoint wars, gun fights just to unlock save points, "buddies" that will help you once then you are on your own, gun jams with brand new guns (vs used enemy guns) and getting ran over by cars happens way too much (instant death). A mission ends up taking 30 minutes mostly due to driving and not the actual shooting. The maps are always too big or too large and searching for diamonds gets old after finding 20 of them in briefcases. I just can't stand this game. I love GTA and FPS like games but this just doesn't work for me. If you don't have a car in the game then you're stuck running an in-game marathon (it could take 10 minutes of just walking in the middle of nowhere to find a place with a car). The amount of checkpoints  with sissy sniping taking place is just sad. I really liked the start of the game with story and all but after getting ran over several times in an hour trying to do several missions led to a rage quit and uninstall. If you like driving with fragile cars in the jungle, checkpoints where you'll be in a gun fight for at least 10 minutes, missions that lead to almost no story development, no radio (while driving for 10+ minutes I could use some music), a buddy system worse than GTA IV and gun jams that lead to almost instant death then this may be your game (real life may be like this but for a game it just isn't fun).

												I kinda have to be in the right mood to deliberately elect to play this game over my other options, but every time I play it, I enjoy it. I've spent hours playing this game, and I doubt if I'm even halfway through the main story.Best features:- A visually interesting (come on, it takes place in Africa, so it's gorgeous)- Dynamic questlines- Open-world map- Player-guided character development (can be a goodguy-type or a badguy-type)- Fun vehiclesWorst features:- Maddeningly unrealistic weaponry- Having to get to certain spots to have a "good stopping point" and be able to save- Relatively limited carrying capacityOverall a very enjoyable game to play, just not on my list of tops.///////////////////////BLACK3Y3 rating: 8/10

												I've Had this game for a year. At first I was like "I CANT STAND THIS GAME. IT SUXS WORST FAR CRY GAME EVAAAAAAR!!!" Then a year later, I came back to this game with the jackal mod, and it becomes a good far cry game. It puts you in Africa in an unknow part of it and you must hunt and kill The Jackal. You can play as a wider variety of characters and you have a buddie system that allows AI to help revive you if you go down. They can also die and never respawn. This game isn't made for everybody, If you loved Far cry 3 and 4 and you come to this game, you will hate it. It's nothing like its future games, but if you played Far Cry 3 with the Ziggy Mod on the hardest difficulty, you might love this game. I loved this game and Im in the process of beating it soon. 8/10

Posted: June 24, 2015
												Driving Sim 2008: Africa Edition was a great addition to my library of games. I enjoyed the many different cars to choose from like compacts, 4x4 Trucks with .50cal machine guns, 8x8s with large anti vehicle guns, and even some different Jeep models like the Libery and Wrangler 4 door! Althought the physics and handling as well as the engine sounds could use some improvement, it was overall a good game. I also didn't like the police in this game, even if i did the speed limit and stopped at all the signs, they would always shoot at me, but that's all negotiable because off roading in this game is pretty fun, plus if you get your vehicle stuck you can always go get one from somehwere near you and come back and shove your vehicle free! This game also has boats and a hang glider too! Free roaming on foot is ok too, you get guns which is useful if you need to escape the police. Also for some reason you have malaria and have to take pills a lot and if the police shoot you a lot you have to pull out the bullets. Also I don't like how the weapons have a personal touch to them. If i take a weapon off of a police officer it almost immeadiatly jams even though they were just spam firing at me fine 5 seconds ago.This game is pretty good, very enjoyable, makes you realize the importance of using OFF bug repellant so you don't have to take pills every couple hours.8.9/10 "one of the most complete overall gaming packages" -IGN

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Great game. Enemies are always a danger so you don't want to lower your guard, there's a lot of land on the map which makes it to bypass most (but not all, depending on where you're trying to go) guard posts, you can use stealth and silenced weapons if you want and the weather, terrain, grass height, and time of day has a strong effect on how easy or not easy stealth is, you can upgrade your safe houses until they're practically mini-armories by subverting missions with your best buddy, your second best buddy can save your life once if you get into trouble (you'll need to rest in a safe house afterwards in order for him to become rescue-ready and able to save you again), and weapons can degrade so you want to keep an eye on how rusty your weapons are looking like and want to refresh your weapons at the gun store frequently (for better or for worse, it's not worth picking up used weapons from dead enemies).Weapons have a nice variety, for example, regarding sniper rifles the SVD Dragunov has a large clip so you can shoot several enemies in quick succession while the AS50 has a smaller clip but fires rounds that are powerful enough to go through most man-made obstacles and kill the enemy trying to take cover behind them. While starting weapons are admittedly basic, the weapons you unlock either later in the game or by complete supply convoy missions available at the gun stores are much better with benefits and weaknesses...which of the later weapons you like will be more determined by your tastes and playstyle as the weapons aren't clearly better or worse than each other, just different.As far as length of the game goes, it's again determined largely by your playstyle. You can either play slowly, subvert every mission for your best buddy, scout out the map for diamonds and check guard posts (the ones that store ammo or health are very useful and I find myself going to those posts rather than the gun stores to re-supply) or stick to the storyline and only complete your objectives. I'd recommend trying to take it slow though since, while the story isn't bad I wouldn't rate it above Far Cry 3's, IMO, this is a game that's best enjoyed for its gameplay rather than story. Also, Far Cry 3 players should keep in mind that enemies at guard posts respawn.There's also a rare bug that's still not fixed where, when getting a mission from one of the factions, the door to the room of the mission giver won't open. I remember reading that if you go on another mission (buddy, underground, assassination, or supply convoy) then the problem will fix itself. Or, if you don't have any missions available you can go rest in a safe house for 3-4 days and the door will open afterwards. It is rare though, you'll probably have to play multiple times to see it and if you keep multiple saves then you can load a different save as well (as long as the save took place in a different map area).There's also some excellent guides at http://farcry2.zsg.dk/ and http://majorslack.com/games-tips-tricks/far-cry-2-primary-weapons-1/ should you need more help and you can find some more technical information at http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Far_Cry_2 in case you want to do something like disable the Depth of Field. Hope this review helps!

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Pros + Large open world+ Great shooting mechanics, especially for the time+ Varied amounts of weapons, including but not limited to Assault Rifles, SMGs, Snipers and a Flamethrower.+ Side missions are available away from the main story that can earn you extra diamonds or weapons.+ There are always two ways to approach a mission, with one being easier but giving less rewards and the latter being     more convoluted but unlocking items for your safehouse.+ No Uplay!!+ Comes with the Fortune pack included, the weapons in the pack are extreamly useful throughout the game.Cons- Stealth is a feature, though lacks proper implementation- The plot is lacking in this far cry. You choose from a selection of characters, though your choice really only affects the color of you character models hands. You then go around blowing up things and killing people for money, and that's practically it.OverallFar Cry 2 is a great open world shooter that is definitely worth picking up. You'll get a good amount of hours out of it for the price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Far Cry 2 is the predecessor to the amazing game known as Far Cry 3. In FC3 you had access to weapons and ammo as fast traveled the wilderness and would sometimes die from a tiger only to respawn in another place.  In Far Cry 2 you have to scavenge for weapons and ammo, only to have the gun jam and break in your own hands while in the midst of fighting a military outpost. Theres no tigers to maim you, but there is malaria that will follow you from the beginning to the end of the game.  Positives:-Decent Graphics-Hard Gameplay-Extremely long (I had 52 hours and i barely did any buddy missions)-ACTUAL stealth (Its not broken its realistic)-Large open areas that makes sniping actually useful -There are much more difficulties, that are MUCH harder than FC3-No Regenerating Health, No fast travel, No respawns-Choices, This game is the definition of "open world"-Story, it seems pretty boring and simple at first, and then the OH SH*T moment happensNegatives-Colors are very absent, due to being Africa-Gameplay can be repetitive-No Regenerating Health, No fast travel, No respawns-Gunplay is both better and worse, no skills, but much more realistic gunfights-Missions are very repetitive, always seems to be the same thingOverall Far Cry 2 is probably a defining game of the series.  It appeals more to the hardcore players who are ok with having to drive EVERYWHERE, even if you die on a mission.  This game is not for casual play, but if you want a challenge load it up on a harder diffuculty. DO NOT PLAY INFAMOUS UNTILL 2nd PLAYTHROUGH. You have been warned!
